data.title: Cedar Grove Amphitheater
data.listingDescription: Join a ranger at this outdoor theater for programs on a wide variety of park topics. It is wheelchair accessible, and the visitor center has assistive-listening devices. Check local bulletin boards and the visitor center for schedules.

images.altText: Wooden benches sit in front of many trees facing a podium
images.title: Cedar Grove Amphitheater
images.caption: The amphitheater at Cedar Grove

data.bodyText:
Join a ranger at this outdoor theater for programs on a wide variety of park topics. It is wheelchair accessible, and the visitor center has assistive-listening devices. Check local bulletin boards and the visitor center for schedules.

Accessibility

Cedar Grove Amphitheater has a paved path that leads to seating from the parking area. Wheelchair seating is available at the front and halfway back from the screen. Ask for assistive-listening devices for ranger programs. Neck loops are available for those with T-coil hearing aids.
data.audioDescription: A smooth paved path leads you to the edge of a lighted outdoor amphitheater, surrounded by tall pine and incense-cedar trees. Beyond the trees you may hear a rushing river when the water level is high. To your left, and downslope, is a tall wood-planked projection wall with a white projection screen and a v-shaped roof. To the left of the screen is a campfire ring made of stones that stick up about one foot above the ground. Starting 15 feet from the wall, there are rows of 20-foot-long wood benches for seating. They are lined up in two sets of eleven, with a five-foot-wide dirt aisle running down the center. The path to the amphitheater ends by splitting in three directions. Straight ahead goes into an area cut into the sixth row, providing space for wheelchairs next to benches. The left fork continues down to and in front of the screen, providing access to another cut out for space for wheelchairs, on the closest side of the first row. The right fork goes upslope, behind the bench seating, to a small wood-planked projection building with log pole framing and a stone foundation. It has a sign that reads, "Cedar Grove Amphitheater". Two windows face the screen.

data.bodyText:

This wayside exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, Changing Scenes, Changing Sounds," discusses human-caused sounds and their effects on humans and wildlife.
data.audioDescription: You may hear Peregrine falcons, birds that nest on this rock. A peregrine falcon's call sounds like "key, key, key, key". This wayside exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, Changing Scenes, Changing Sounds", discusses human-caused sounds and their effects on humans and wildlife. A photo of your view - a falcon's eye view from this peak, on Moro Rock. Through the clouds below is a tree and grass covered valley, with a light brown roadway, weaving across the hillside in switchback curves. The text reads, Prior to 1925, you couldn't have seen the dramatic zigzag of Generals Highway below- it wasn't there. Visitors came up a one-way road two canyons farther northwest. Cars would make the steep drive uphill in the morning and downhill in the afternoon. By 1925, visitors on this rock could see, and hear, traffic on the Generals Highway. Can you hear it? Whether you think of it as a sound or as noise is up to you. This is historic road has become part of the landscape and soundscape of this park. A photo of a peregrine falcon flying towards us with outstretched wings. Most of its body is grey with black stripes that widen at the tips of the wings and tail. Its head appears hooded with black feathers. The beak, throat and neck are white. The tail is spread open like an upside-down fan. The caption reads, Listen... natural sounds can reveal inner workings of ecosystems. Parks work to protect these soundscapes. Animals use sound to find food, defend territory, call mates, protect young, and avoid predators. Disruptive sound can change animal behavior. Peregrine falcons, which nest on Moro Rock, may leave the nest of disturbed by noise.

data.title: Cherry Gap
data.listingDescription: This Forest Service area 3 miles (4.8 kilometer) north of Grant Grove is part of the Converse Basin sequoia grove. From Cherry Gap, you can take roads to the Chicago Stump.

images.altText: A dirt road cuts between tall trees
images.title: Cherry Gap
images.caption: Cherry Gap Road leads to the Twin Stump and Converse Basin.

data.bodyText:
This Forest Service area 3 miles (4.8 kilometer) north of Grant Grove is part of the Converse Basin sequoia grove. From Cherry Gap, you can take roads to the Chicago Stump. Once the General Noble Tree, it was cut into pieces in 1897, shipped to the Chicago World's Fair, and reassembled. This effort to share the huge size of these trees with the world was met with disbelief; it became known as the "California Hoax." Go 2.8 miles (4.5 kilometer) on Forest Road 13S03 to the Chicago Stump trailhead (do not drive past here). Walk the 0.5-mile loop (0.8 kilometer) to the stump along a meadow ringed by young sequoias.

This road is often closed. Please check the Forest Service's website to determine whether this road is open.
data.audioDescription: You are in a conifer forest with small trees. Some are charred, with no leaves. A brass plaque with engraved lettering on a stacked stone pedestal reads, Converse Basin Grove One of the largest stands of giant sequoias. It contained some of the finest big trees. The grove was logged as private land between 1897 and 1907. First by the Sanger Lumber Company, and later by Hume-Bennett Lumber Company, which in 1909 developed Hume Lake for a mill. Converse Basin, two miles northeast of this monument, has its own mill and narrow-gauge rail connection to the logging town of Millwood, from which lumber was sent to Sanger in the valley by flume, although they never realized any profit. The companies cut several thousand big trees and left only the largest, The Boole Tree, unfelled. The area today is part of Sequoia National Forest, which regulates all uses including logging, but none of the ancient sequoias will ever be commercially cut again. Jim Savage, Chapter 1852 and E. Clampus Vitus. October 23, 1977

The top of the trunk is jagged and charred, and the tree has no leaves or branches. A vertical opening along one side extends from the ground to the top of the trunk, creating a space large enough for a person to walk through. Another opening in the base is wider but lower. data.title: Clara Barton Tree
data.listingDescription: Trees throughout Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks are named for a variety of extraordinary people. The Clara Barton Tree, near the beginning of the Big Trees Trail, honors this Civil War nurse, a teacher, and patent clerk and the founder of the American Red Cross, who lived from 1821 to 1912. It is one of only two trees named for women. The other, the Susan B. Anthony Tree, can be seen from this trail if you know where to look. Clara Barton's contemporary, Susan B.

images.altText: A majestic Giant Sequoia stands out among the surrounding trees
images.title: The Clara Barton Tree
images.caption: The Clara Barton Tree, named after the founder of the American Red Cross.

data.bodyText:
Trees throughout Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks are named for a variety of extraordinary people. The Clara Barton Tree, near the beginning of the Big Trees Trail, honors this Civil War nurse, a teacher, and patent clerk and the founder of the American Red Cross, who lived from 1821 to 1912. It is one of only two trees named for women. The other, the Susan B. Anthony Tree, can be seen from this trail if you know where to look. Clara Barton's contemporary, Susan B. Anthony worked tirelessly to secure for women the right to vote.

Sequoia Facts

Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks are home to seven of the ten largest trees in the world. Out of the largest 30, 18 can be found here.
What counts? In this system, trees are measured by trunk volume onlyï¹˜ not branches, leaves, or roots.
Because trees grow, branches fall, and fires burn, tree dimensions change year to year.
Until 2003, the Washington Tree in Giant Forest (Sequoia National Park) was the second-largest sequoia. After being reduced by fire, it no longer ranks among the top 30.
If branches are also measured, the President Tree is the second largest tree, bumping General Grant to third.
data.audioDescription: You are in the Giant Forest, before you is a gigantic sequoia tree. At the base of the massive trunk is an embossed wood sign that reads, "Clara Barton Tree". If you walk to the tree you will need to be careful because there are many fallen branches around it. The trunk of the tree has a fibrous, shaggy bark. The base has irregular curves. Above the curves, starting at about five feet up, there many holes peppering the trunk, each about one foot across, about the size of a bowling ball. If you reach into a hole, the walls of the hole have deep gouges and the bottom is covered with a layer of shredded bark. There are thick spider webs in several of these holes.

data.title: Cold Springs Nature Trail - Western Trailhead
data.listingDescription:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of Cold Springs Nature Trail.

Cold Springs Nature Trail is 2.0 miles round-trip (3.2 kilometer) at an easy incline. It travels through meadows and aspen groves to the site of the former mining town of Beulah. The trail features interpretive panels, which give more information about your surroundings. This trail is for day-use only; overnight camping is available at the Cold Springs Campground.

images.altText: A brown sign with text on it stands next to a dirt trail
images.title: Cold Springs Nature Trail
images.caption: The trailhead sign for Cold Springs Trail

data.bodyText:
This trailhead is located within Cold Springs Campground, look for a wooden trailhead sign between sites 6 and 7.

Cold Springs Nature Trail is 2.0 miles round-trip (3.2 kilometer) at an easy incline. It travels through meadows and aspen groves to the site of the former mining town of Beulah. The trail features interpretive panels, which give more information about your surroundings. This trail is for day-use only; overnight camping is available at the Cold Springs Campground.
data.audioDescription: Close-up of a green meadow with tiny purple and yellow blossoms, and red feathery flowers. A 1 mile (or 1.6 km) hike for beginning hikers.

data.title: Colonel Young: A Buffalo Soldier
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Shaping a Park, Colonel Young: A Buffalo Soldier," shows photos and text about Colonel Charles Young.

images.altText: A wayside sign explaining Colonel Young: A Buffalo Soldier
images.title: Colonel Young: A Buffalo Soldier
images.caption: Colonel Young: A Buffalo Soldier Wayside

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Shaping a Park, Colonel Young: A Buffalo Soldier," shows photos and text about Colonel Charles Young.
data.audioDescription: The View: You are surrounded by large sequoia trees. Their green canopy provides welcome shade. The text explains that the road to Moro Rock is part of the legacy of America's first black national park superintendent. Captain Charles Young, a West Point graduate, commanded the cavalry units of Buffalo Soldiers who were assigned here in 1903. Before there were park rangers, the military guarded national parks. Young's troops were the first African-Americans to do so. In just one summer, he and his men completed many projects. They took some of the first vital steps towards long- term protection of this park. Captain Young later earned the rank of Colonel, and became a national figure. A sequoia named for him stands a short distance along the trail. A black and white photo of a man mounted on a horse standing on a wooden bridge. His saddle rests on a thick blanket. The saddle's foot strap has a leather flap that wraps around the ankle of his boot. He is dressed in a dark long-sleeved shirt and light-colored pants, and wears a brimmed felt hat. He wears long leather gloves that come up to his forearm. His pants are tucked into buttoned knee boots. In this rare 1903 photo, a Buffalo soldier poses on the Marble Fork Bridge in Sequoia National Park. A black and white photo portrait of Charles Young. He is clean shaven. He wears a white shirt under a buttoned jacket. On his collar are the letters "U.S." and a U.S. Calvary pin of two crossed swords with a number "9" in the center. A quote by Charles Young next to his portrait reads, "The people of the adjoining country and tourists are awakening to the benefits and beauties of the park and desire to protect the game and Forest...." Text to the right reads, Who were the Buffalo soldiers? Buffalo soldiers were African Americans who served in the United States cavalry after the Civil War, primarily in the American West. It is believed that American Indians- who revered the buffalo- gave the name and tribute to the soldiers' courage, skill, and appearance. These soldiers carried the name with pride.

data.title: Columbine Picnic Area and Snowplay Area
data.listingDescription: This picnic spot near the Grant Grove campgrounds and Visitor Center offer a good slope for sledding in the winter.

images.altText: Columbine Picnic Area and Snowplay Area
images.title: Columbine Picnic Area and Snowplay Area
images.caption: Columbine Picnic Area and Snowplay Area

data.bodyText:
This picnic spot near the Grant Grove campgrounds and Visitor Center offer a good slope for sledding in the winter.

Winter Snowplay

As soon as snow falls, this area is a great place for snowplay. Parking is limited in winter. Please stay in the picnic area and not the nearby campground.

Sled Safely

Every winter, people get hurt badly while sledding in the park. Sledding accidents send over 20,000 people to emergency rooms each year in this country. The most common reason people get hurt is they sled when conditions are bad (icy snow, rock or tree hazards exposed, poor visibility), so if the snow isn't great or you can't see, don't sled!

Don’t let an accident ruin your winter fun.

  • When sledding, slide feet first.
  • Consider wearing a helmet.
  • Make sure your path is clear. Don’t slide near rocks, trees, branches, or other people.
  • After sliding, look uphill. Move out of the way of people coming downhill after you.
  • Don’t slide into roads or parking lots.
  • Avoid hard-packed snow or ice, where speed and direction get out of control.
  • Sliding devices that can be steered may be safer than others.

In an emergency, contact a ranger or call 911. There is a public telephone at Wolverton Snowplay Area. The closest telephone to Columbine and Big Stump snowplay areas is at Kings Canyon Visitor Center in Grant Grove Village.

Services Nearby

Parking, restrooms, and picnic tables available year-round. This becomes a snow-play area in winter.

Acessibility

Although there is no designated accessible parking here, routes from the parking area to the restrooms and picnic area are firm and stable with gentle slopes. The restrooms are mostly, though not fully, accessible. The picnic area includes extended picnic tables and accessible grills.
data.audioDescription: This shaded area has conifer trees and a few low rock boulders. The ground is flat near the picnic area. Picnic tables, made of thick slabs of wood on raised wooden bases, provide easy access. A nearby flat grassy area offers an open area for relaxation and play. Beyond that are low hills with scattered trees.

data.title: Community
data.listingDescription:
Sequoia groves grow within the larger conifer--or conebearing--forest. Their neighbors are as important, fascinating, and beautiful as sequoias -- just not as big!

This wayside exhibit, titled "Community", shows four different types of conifer trees.

images.altText: A metal panel with images and text stands in front of a wooden fence.
images.title: Community
images.caption: The community wayside exhibit on conifer forests

data.bodyText:
Sequoia groves grow within the larger conifer--or conebearing--forest. Their neighbors are as important, fascinating, and beautiful as sequoias -- just not as big!

This wayside exhibit, titled "Community", shows four different types of conifer trees.
data.audioDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Community", shows four different types of conifer trees. The View: The forest is canopied with pine, incense-cedar, fir, and, of course, sequoia trees. The text reads, Community Look at the canopy above you. This forest is a diverse neighborhood that supports more than sequoias. How many different kinds of trees can you count? Look for differences in cones, leaves, and silhouettes. Protecting sequoias means safeguarding this entire forest. Across the exhibit are four indented rectangles, each showing a different tree. Each rectangle has a raised cone outline on the left. Next to it is a raised outline of the shape of the leaves (also called needles). Both of these are in true scale. There is a silhouette of the mature tree on the right of each rectangle, but it is not tactile or to scale. Going from left to right the trees are: 1. Incense-cedar, or Calocedrus decurrens. The raised cone does not have a typical cone shape; its two outer scales open into a v shape, leaving a thin central structure inside the v. The shape next to it illustrates the thick, short, flattened leaves on a cluster of tiny branches, forming a broom-like spray. The tree has a long thin trunk with a conical top. The text reads, Often mistaken for a sequoia, its leaves are flatter and its bark is harder and rougher. 2. Giant sequoia, or Sequoiadendron giganteum. You can feel a raised cone outline on the left. The cone is brown, with dark ridges crisscrossing it. The leaf to the right has what looks like long thin twigs, covered in small overlapping green scales, which are the needles. These needles are tiny and hard to see. The text reads, Its short sharp needles overlap each other, completely covering the twigs. The tree has a tall thick trunk, with short stubby branches starting two-thirds of the way up. 3. White fir, or Abies concolor. The cone stands upright on the branch, above the short needles that grow along the sides of the branches. Horizontal ridges tightly crisscross the cone. Inside the raised leaf outline, the photo shows needles in a row on either side of the twig. The tall narrow tree has branches pointing downward. The text reads, Needles grow in neat rows along the twigs. Cones grow upright and fall apart while still on the branch. 4. Sugar pine, or Pinus lambertiana. Inside the raised cone outline, the photo shows the cone opening. Dozens of fan-shaped segments, like scales on a fish, are open, having released the seeds within. The raised leaf outline on the upper right shows a cluster of five long thin needles, coming out of a central point. The text reads, Long slender branches extend far from the trunk. Needles grow in bunches of five. The Braille information provided on this exhibit has already been explained in this Audio Description.

data.title: Community Kitchen
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Community Kitchen," shows how American Indian women prepared acorns.

images.altText: A panel explains the meaning of community kitchen. Behind the panel, we see the rock with divets.
images.title: Community Kitchen
images.caption: This exhibit explains the meaning of the "Community Kitchen."

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Community Kitchen," shows how American Indian women prepared acorns.
data.audioDescription: The View: To the left of the wayside exhibit is a large rock with mortar holes embedded into it, where Native American people once pounded acorns into meal. Each hole is between 4 and 12 inches wide, in a conical shape. On the left side of the rock, is a Bay Laurel tree, with long, dark green, pointy leaves. The leaves are aromatic when crushed. Overhead are Canyon Live Oak trees, with oval leaves that are jagged and pointy on the outer edge. A large Sumac bush on the right has olive green leaves that are oval with a pointed tip. From this site, you can often hear the river flowing through the canyon below this exhibit. The text reads, This site once served as a busy kitchen for a village. It provided Native American people everything they needed for cooking: rocks and sticks to shape into bowls and utensils, river water, and nutritious acorns from oak trees. Women chipped the hollow bedrock mortars into these rocks to pound acorns into flour. Baked into cakes or boiled to make mush or soup, acorn meal sustained the village. The main image is a black and white photo of an older American Indian woman seated crossed legged in a printed dress, with an apron around her waist. Around her are three deep rounded baskets made of woven grasses or reeds. Two are striped and one has a zigzagged pattern. Two long narrow sticks rest atop the largest basket. To her right is a large cloth laid out on the ground. Two shallower plain baskets lie on the cloth. A building made of upright slatted wood boards is seen behind her. The caption reads, Western Mono tribe member Hi a inh, also called Jane Whaley, sits with traditional baskets and stirring tool (1929 to 1930). Another black and white photo shows a middle-aged American Indian woman at work. Her dark hair pulled back in a bun and she's wearing a dress with a ruffled collar, seated on a blanket on a large flat rock. With arms bent, she holds a conical shaped stone the size of a bread loaf above a round hole in the stone next to her. The caption reads, Women used a shaped stone to pound acorns into meal or flour. A time-consuming process, preparing acorns gave friends time to talk, laugh, and socialize. Yokuts tribe member Mary Pohot, 1925. Below there is an image of an acorn- a brown thumb sized oval nut with a light brown textured "cap".

data.title: Competition
data.listingDescription: This outdoor exhibit, titled “Competition,“ shares information about giant sequoia ecology.

images.altText: A metal-framed, two-legged outdoor exhibit is found in a forested area.
images.title: Competition
images.caption: Learn more about giant sequoias and the forests where they grow.

data.bodyText: This outdoor exhibit, titled “Competition,“ shares information about giant sequoia ecology.
data.audioDescription: This outdoor exhibit panel is titled, "Competition" and features two photos with captions and additional text about giant sequoia ecology. This exhibit features a photograph of the brown trunk, a very large trunk of a mature giant sequoia tree. Other mature firs trees are seen in the background, and a cluster of small fir seedlings are in the photo’s foreground. The photo’s caption reads, “White fir seedlings grow thickly around the base of this mature sequoia.” The exhibit text reads, “Where sequoias grow, white firs can usually be found nearby. These two tree species compete for space and sunlight on the forest floor. Both trees begin as seeds that are dropped on the forest floor from cones high above. Once the seeds sprout, their roots must reach bare soil to get nourishment to survive. White firs have larger seeds that provide energy to grow longer roots. Tiny sequoia seeds sprout shorter roots that often die before reaching nutrients and water. Without the frequent fires that are natural to sequoia groves, white firs would take over. When fire moves through the forest, sequoias gain the advantage. Fire clears away dead leaves and exposes bare mineral soil. Heat triggers sequoia cones to release their seeds, resulting in masses of seedlings when conditions are right for them to survive. Thick bark protects older sequoias from fire. To the right of the giant sequoia photograph is a smaller photo of a small, brown-tinged sequoia seedling and a sequoia cone, found atop incense cedar twigs and plant material on the forest floor. The photo’s caption reads, “A Warming Forest“, “In this sequoia grove, winter’s storms build a deep snowpack that melts continuously through spring. If the forest becomes warmer, more precipitation will fall as rain, not snow. The snowy season would shorten, resulting in drier summers. Sequoias may struggle to reproduce in these conditions. If temperatures climb, the youngest trees may disappear, threatening the future of the grove.”

data.title: Congress Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Congress Trail. Congress Trail is a 2.7 mile round-trip lollipop-shaped trail on a gentle, paved incline. It begins near the General Sherman Tree, the largest living tree on Earth. Along the path, you'll also see excellent examples of mature sequoias, including the House and Senate groups, and the President Tree.

images.altText: A paved path runs inbetween a wooden fence. On the other sides of the fence are giant sequoia trees
images.title: Congress Trail
images.caption: The Congress Trail

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Congress Trail.

Congress Trail is a 2.7 mile round-trip lollipop-shaped trail on a gentle, paved incline. It begins near the General Sherman Tree, the largest living tree on Earth. Along the path, you'll also see excellent examples of mature sequoias, including the House and Senate groups, and the President Tree.

Acessibility

For accessible access to the Congress Trail and General Sherman Tree, park at the small parking area along the Generals Highway two miles (3.2 km) north of the Giant Forest Museum.

Parking in this lot is designated accessible only. If you do not have a placard, but cannot manage a steep slope or stairs on the main trail to the Sherman Tree, stop at a visitor center for a temporary pass. In summer, if parking here is unavailable, park instead at Lodgepole Visitor Center, Giant Forest Museum, or General Sherman Tree Main Trail and Parking and take the wheelchair accessible park shuttle (Green Route 1).

From here, the trail to the General Sherman Tree is paved with inclines of up to 5% and limited cross-slopes. There are benches along the trail.

data.bodyText:
Convict Flat Campground is in Sequoia National Forest at an elevation of 3,000 feet. It features stunning views of granite cliffs. The campground is subject to fire restrictions. Check with the Forest Service to get a free fire permit and learn more.

Campground Information

Please consult the USFS on facility availability.
Five sites available for tents and small to mid-sized trailers. Sites are available on a first-come, first served basis. Camping is free, but no water is available.

The first campsite along the trail is at 4 miles at Lower Tent Meadow. This is a hot, steep climb, so you may want to plan your hiking fo

images.altText: A sunlit dirt trail leads to the shade of tall trees
images.title: Copper Creek Trailhead
images.caption: Copper Creek Trailhead

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Copper Creek Trail area.

Copper Creek Trail is 10 miles one-way (20 miles round-trip) at a difficult incline. The trail travels through several aspen forests and meadows, ending at Granite Lake, a stop that offers beautiful vistas of Mount Hutchings, Goat Mountain, and Comb Spur. The first campsite along the trail is at 4 miles at Lower Tent Meadow. This is a hot, steep climb, so you may want to plan your hiking for early in the day or late in the evening.
data.audioDescription: The text reads, Spectacular views of the Kings Canyon reward those who climb this trail. Lower Tent Meadows offers a welcome rest halfway to the top. After ascending steeply over 5,000 feet (or 1525 m), the trail levels out in Granite Basin. Like most park trails, Copper Creek Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. A photo of a grassy flat area, surrounded by rocky hillsides dotted with conifers. A steep white mountain range is seen in the distance. The caption reads, Granite Basin and Granite Lake. 1.8 miles (or 12.9 km) to The Lip. Elevation: 10,348 feet (or 3,152 m). "The Lip" marks the entrance to Granite Basin. Granite Lake lies about 2 miles (or 3.2 km) farther. Monarch Ranger Station, which is intermittently staffed, is a short way down the trail near Granite Pass. A photo of a meadow of green grass and shrubs, lined with tall trees. Steep mountain walls rise beyond the trees. The caption reads, Simpson Meadow. 22.8 miles (or 36.7 km) one way. Elevation: 5,990 feet (or 1,826 m). After Granite Pass, the trail passes through forested canyons, and then descends quickly to the Middle Fork of the Kings River and Simpson Meadow. Side trails along the way lead to State and Horseshoe Lakes. A map shows the location of the Copper Creek Trailhead, The bottom photo shows a rocky slope dotted with trees. The top of a mountain range, in the distance, is covered with snow. The caption reads, A view from Copper Creek Trail. A quote by Willa Cather, "We come and go, but the land is always here."

quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Correct Climate
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Correct Climate," shows how temperature changes can affect sequoia growth.

images.altText: a metal panel has text and images on it informing visitors about giant sequoias and climate
images.title: Correct Climate
images.caption: This exhibit can be found on the Big Trees Trail

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Correct Climate," shows how temperature changes can affect sequoia growth.
data.audioDescription: The View: To your left are the grasses of Round Meadow and to your right are the sequoias of Giant Forest. The text on the panel reads, Correct Climate Sequoias need a climate like the Giant Forest has now, lots of precipitation but not very cold temperatures. Yet this area was not always ideal sequoia habitat. This meadow reveals that, until about 4,000 years ago, very few sequoias grew here. It was either too dry or too cold. This meadow records the history of local climate. Over thousands of years its soil formed in layers as plants decomposed. Scientists can identify these plants and know what type of climate they require. That tells us what the climate was like when they were growing here. A background photo, taken from the meadow, shows a dense line of giant sequoias against a dark sky. An illustration, layered on top of the photo, shows a cross section of the meadow's soil, with bright green grass on top of a brown layer, a dark green layer below that, then a grey layer at the bottom. The text reads from top to bottom, Meadow Layers Reveal Sequoia's Past Bright green layer: Ideal for Sequoias. Today to 4,000 years ago. There is enough rain and snow to support sequoias and their forest neighbors. Brown layer: Too Dry. 4,000 to 12,000 years ago. Sagebrush and dry climate pines grew then. Dark Green layer: Too Cold. Before 12,000 years ago. An ice age dominated the landscape. A glacier 500 feet thick (or 152 m) filled the canyon at Lodgepole just north of here. Cold tolerant plants that lived here then now grow 3,000 to 4,000 feet higher in elevation. Grey layer: Solid Bedrock.

data.title: Crescent Meadow Picnic Area and Trailhead
data.listingDescription: The Crescent Meadow Picnic Area is 2.6 miles from the Giant Forest Museum, near Moro Rock and several trailheads. The picnic area rests at the edge of a lush meadow.

images.altText: A wooden sign labeled "Crescent Meadow" stands in front of a lush, green meadow.
images.title: Crescent Meadow
images.caption: Crescent Meadow

data.bodyText:
The Crescent Meadow Picnic Area is 2.6 miles from the Giant Forest Museum, near Moro Rock and several trailheads. The picnic area rests at the edge of a lush meadow, surrounded by giant sequoias. 

From here, you can follow the High Sierra Trail deep in the wilderness, or hike a short loop around Crescent or Log meadows. 

Winter Access

To access this area in winter, you will need to hike, snowshoe, or ski into the area.

Accessibility

Crescent Meadow Picnic Area has accessible restrooms and designated accessible (but steep) parking stalls. There are no extended picnic tables.

Crescent Meadow Trail is partially paved and may be accessible, depending on abilities.
data.audioDescription:
You are standing before a large crescent shaped meadow, a wide-open swath of greenery circled by a dense forest of towering sequoia trees and conifers. Filled with grasses and ferns, the meadow view changes dramatically with the season. If you're here in the spring and early summer, it is green and lush with burgeoning wildflowers such as violet lupine, deep red Indian paintbrush, and green corn lilies. In late summer, a brownish tinge comes over the floor of the meadow as the area starts to dry. Autumn brings a splash a yellow from goldenrods. In the winter, the meadow is often snow covered.

Ravens, golden-crowned kinglets, mountain chickadees, and warblers frequent the meadow; listen for their calls. You may even hear woodpeckers drilling holes in trees.

A rectangular carved wooden sign, on two supporting wood posts, with white and orange embossed lettering reads,

Crescent Meadow

A quote by John Muir,
"Gem of the Sierras"

quickFacts.value: Located at the end of the Moro Rock / Crescent Meadow Road.
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Crescent Meadow Shuttle Stop
data.listingDescription: This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at Crescent Meadow, one of the larger meadows in these parks and the starting point for several hikes. Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks. Shuttles within the park are free; round-trip shuttles from Visalia are $20, which includes the park entrance fee.

data.bodyText:
This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at Crescent Meadow, one of the larger meadows in these parks and the starting point for several hikes, including the historic High Sierra Trail.

Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks.

Shuttles within the park are free; round-trip shuttles from Visalia are $20, which includes the park entrance fee.

All buses are wheelchair accessible, and either kneel or have lifts.

Visit the park shuttles page for more information, including a route map.

data.title: Cross-Section Story
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Cross Section Story" provides information about the tree section in front of you.

images.altText: A metal panel sits in front of a large slab of giant sequoia wood
images.title: Cross Section Story
images.caption: This wayside is found near the General Sherman Tree

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Cross Section Story" provides information about the tree section in front of you.
data.audioDescription: The View: A giant cross section of a sequoia trunk stands before you, tilted up, like a wall, behind the wayside panel. The section is about 15 feet in diameter. A thick crack runs through its center. Thick bark is seen on the top but has been worn away lower down. You can feel how uneven the outer edge of the trunk is. Thin cracks run roughly parallel to the outer edge. On the wood around the outer edges of these cracks, you may feel very subtle ridges, running perpendicular to the cracks. Each ridge represents one year of growth after the fire, as the tree wraps around the edge of the scar to cover the opening, and protect the tree. The text reads, Cross-Section Story This slab from the stump of a giant sequoia tells a story of fire and survival. The annual growth rings show that the tree lived about 2,210 years. Marks within some rings show that, during that time, at least 80 different fires burned hot enough to leave a scar. Mature sequoias survive all but the very hottest fires. Thick, fibrous bark insulates the tree from killing heat. The bark holds very little sap or pitch, so it is not very flammable. As you can see in the slab, even if fire does penetrate the bark on occasion, it doesn't often kill the tree. Mature sequoias live quite well despite large fire scars. A photo of the trunk section. The caption reads, This slab was sliced from the base of a giant sequoia that grew not far from here. In 1950 the park cut the tree down because it threatened to fall on rental cabins. Recognizing the hazard to both visitors and trees, the park eventually moved overnight facilities out of the sequoia grove. Visitors no longer risk having sequoias fall on them while they sleep. Two-thousand-year -old sequoias no longer risk being felled because they lean over little cabins. An inset circular photo shows a close up of the trunk section, entitled, Scars and Healing It shows two dark curved cracks. The cracks are highlighted in red and the wood outside the cracks is highlighted in yellow. The caption for the red highlights reads, These scars reveal how many fires were hot enough to damage the word beneath the bark. A typical sequoia here has survived several such fires during each century of its life. The caption for the yellow highlights reads, Notice wider growth rings next to the cracks. After fire, sequoias often grow faster for a few years. It may be due to decreased competition for nutrients and water for several years after surrounding plants are burned away. A black and white photo of this sequoia tree starting to lean to one side as loggers cut the base. The caption reads, The tree from which this slab was cut was photographed as it fell in 1950.

data.title: Crystal Cave
data.listingDescription: Crystal Cave is an excellent example of a marble cavern. There is a moderately steep (but paved) half-mile trail from the parking area to the cave entrance. The trail through the cave is also one half mile. Because of fragile formations, the only way to visit the cave is on a guided tour.

images.altText: A large room made of marble walls with a group of 9 people in the distance
images.title: Crystal Cave
images.caption: A view of Marble Hall, the largest room in Crystal Cave.

data.bodyText:
Crystal Cave is an excellent example of a marble cavern. There is a moderately steep (but paved) half-mile trail from the parking area to the cave entrance. The trail through the cave is also one half mile. Because of fragile formations, the only way to visit the cave is on a guided tour. Tours are suitable for all ages. If you decide to get a reservation to see the cave, plan on spending about half a day traveling to the cave, walking to the entrance, and taking the 50-minute tour.

Getting There

The Crystal Cave Road is gated and closed at its junction with Generals Highway except when tours are being offered. Vehicles with a cumulative length of over 22 feet (the length of a vehicle plus the length of any trailer) are not allowed on the narrow and curving Crystal Cave Road.

Cave Tours Require Tickets Purchased In Advance  

Tours are available from late spring through fall and typically are offered between 9 am and 3 pm. Visit Sequoia Parks Conservancy's Crystal Cave webpage for tour availability, important information about tours, and a link to purchase tickets. Tours are roughly 50 minutes and tickets are available from our parner, the Sequoia Parks Conservancy. Tickets must be purchased in advance, online, at least 36 hoours in advance. Tickets frequently sell out, so it is recommended that you book three weeks in advance of your visit. 

Tickets are not available at the cave.

Services

No services are available at Crystal Cave itself. Restrooms and food storage lockers are available at the Crystal Cave Parking lot . Everyone is required to remove all foods and scented items from cars and place them in the food storage boxes.

Accessibility

The trail to Crystal Cave, though paved, is very steep and narrow, and not recommended for visitors using mobility assistive devices. For an American Sign Language (ASL) translation of the Crystal Cave tour, please ask at the information booth at the Crystal Cave trailhead for a tablet with ASL interpretation. For an in-person ASL interpreter, please email the SPC Field Institute at SFI@sequoiaparks.org. Assistive Listening Devices with SM receivers are available at the Crystal Cave Entrance Booth located at the Crystal Cave Trailhead. Neck loops are available for those with T-coil hearing aids.
data.audioDescription: This bulletin board has information notices, program schedules, and photos of Crystal Cave. It also has safety information. A black and white historic photo of a cave filled with rough and polished marble, including icicle like stalactites and mounds of stalagmites. A large tour group of all ages is intently focused on what the ranger is pointing to. Many women are wearing skirts that fall below their knees. A few men wear short brimmed hats. The caption reads, A 1950s tour group views Marble Hall, the largest room in Crystal Cave. The text below reads, Welcome the Crystal Cave Wild Cave Tour Learn proper caving techniques as you explore off trail and crawl and climb through passageways on this four to six-hour tour. Limited to 6 people, ages 16 and up. Before your Tour Remove all food and scented items from your vehicle and place them in food storage lockers in the parking area. Store all food, coolers, related items, and anything with an odor (even if it's not food) including unopened cans and bottles. Deposit garbage immediately in bear proof containers or store it like food. Take infant seats out of cars; the smells they absorb may attract bears. If You See a Bear Don't let a bear approach you or your food. Wave your arms. Make loud noises, and throw small rocks in its direction (avoid hitting the face or head). Keep a safe distance but be persistent. If a bear does get food, never try to take it back. On the right side of the board is a photo of a rectangular solar panel, with a shiny black surface with a grid of thin metal lines. It sits on a rod, tilting upward. The text reads, Going Solar With the help of a grant, the Crystal Cave lightening system received an important upgrade. Solar panels replaced the old propane generator, eliminating noise and operating costs. New efficient lights reduce energy use. More importantly, the new system will protect the cave and its watershed. A photo of a man installing lighting cables in the cave. The caption reads, LED bulbs are bright and efficient. They also do less harm to sensitive cave dwelling animals that are sensitive to light and heat. A photo shows a close-up of a flat tan surface, separated from a foamy looking green surface, by a curved line of tiny white crystals. The caption reads, Less algae and moss grow under LED lights than under the old lighting system. This lets you enjoy the natural colors of the delicate cave formations and helps to protect the cave ecosystem.

data.title: Crystal Cave Parking & Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Here, you will find an expansive parking lot, restrooms, and an orientation panel that shows a map and images of Crystal Cave. The Crystal Cave Trail descends 0.5 miles at a moderately steep incline to Crystal Cave.

images.altText: Two upright panels provide Crystal Cave trail orientation and historical information.
images.title: Crystal Cave Check-in Booth & Gift Shop
images.caption: Crystal Cave orientation signs

data.bodyText:
Sequoia Parks Conservancy has announced that Crystal Cave will be open for guided tours during the 2025 season.

The road, trail, and visitor facilities at Crystal Cave have been repaired after sustaining damage during the 2021 KNP Complex wildfire and extreme winter weather in early 2023.


Here, you will find an expansive parking lot, restrooms, and an orientation panel that shows a map and images of Crystal Cave.

The Crystal Cave Trail descends 0.5 miles at a moderately steep incline to Crystal Cave. The trail is paved, but is uneven. Beware for rockfall from the steep slopes above.

Crystal Cave is a marble cave filled with delecate formations that look almost as though they belong underwater.

The cave is only accessible by guided tours, which are available May through September. Tickets can only be purchased online at the Sequoia Parks Conservancy website. Tours meet in the parking lot, and then you will hike down to the cave.
data.audioDescription: The text explains that Crystal Cave is a dark, beautiful, fragile underground world. It is paved and lit. The trail winds through large and small cave passages. There is a photo of the historic Spider Web Gate, a metal gate made to look like a web across the cave's opening. Others include a brimstone dam in a cave room and water polished marble bedrock. A map of this area shows our location in the parking area. Safety information, Getting to Crystal Cave It is a half mile walk from here to the cave where the tour starts. The downhill trip to the cave entrance takes approximately 20 minutes. The trail is paved but has stairs, uneven ground, steep drop offs, and can be slippery. It can be icy in early summer or late fall, or slippery at any time. After the tour, the uphill return trip is steep and strenuous, with a 320-foot (or 100 m) elevation gain; take your time and enjoy the scenery. Consider the strenuous nature of the trail before participating in a cave tour, especially if you have heart, respiratory, or mobility concerns. The total walking distance, including the tour, is 1.5 miles (or 2.4 km) There are no restrooms on the trail to the cave or at the cave. From the time you leave this parking area, no restrooms will be available for at least 1 and a half hours. Use restrooms here before heading down the trail. Drinking water is not available at the cave. Bottled water can be purchased at the information booth. On future visits, consider bringing drinking water in a reusable bottle. Protect Crystal Cave Do not touch cave formations. These "growing rocks" are easily damaged by touching. Oils and dirt from human hands discolor them and prevent them from growing. Leave bulky items in your car or at the cave entrance. Backpacks, tripods, hiking sticks, and other items that can damage cave formations cannot be carried into the cave. Child carriers of any kind are not allowed; babies are safest when carried in front. Pets are not allowed on the trail or in the cave. Pets may not be left unattended in the parking area or in your vehicle. Food and drink cannot be consumed in the cave (except water). Leave all natural and historic objects undisturbed. Please do not take rocks, cones, cultural artifacts, or other items. Protect Yourself All natural areas pose risks. You are responsible for your own safety. Rattlesnakes and bees may be seen along the trail to the cave. If you see them, keep your distance and inform cave staff. Poison oak, which can cause a rash, grows here. Avoid touching plants along the trail and near the cave. Stay on trails. Watch out for uneven or slippery footing. The trail is paved, but can be uneven, wet, or even icy. It is not brightly lit. Watch for stairs, narrow passageways, and low ceilings. The cave trail is steep and strenuous for some visitors. If you have physical limitations that will make it difficult for you to complete the cave tour and return trip, reconsider your plans to visit.

data.title: Don Cecil Trailhead
data.listingDescription: The 4.4 mile one-way (8.8 mile round-trip) Don Cecil Trail is a steep climb along the north-facing slope of Kings Canyon. If you're looking for a shorter hike, Sheep Creek Cascade is about a mile up the trail and offers a shady spot to sit and relax. This historic trail was the major access route to Cedar Grove prior to the completion of Highway 180 in 1939. This trail is for day-use only; overnight camping is not allowed.

images.altText: A metal sign sits next to a dirt trail that leads through trees
images.title: Don Cecil Trailhead
images.caption: The former highway, now trailhead

data.bodyText:
The 4.4 mile one-way (8.8 mile round-trip) Don Cecil Trail is a steep climb along the north-facing slope of Kings Canyon. If you're looking for a shorter hike, Sheep Creek Cascade is about a mile up the trail and offers a shady spot to sit and relax.

This historic trail was the major access route to Cedar Grove prior to the completion of Highway 180 in 1939. This trail is for day-use only; overnight camping is not allowed.
data.audioDescription: The text reads, Don Cecil Trail Named for a sheepherder of the 1800s, this historic trail provided the earliest access into the Kings Canyon. Today, it connects Kings Canyon National Park's Cedar Grove with the Big Meadows area of Sequoia National Forest. A photo shows a creek flowing through a forested area, with a rustic bridge crossing in the distance. The caption reads, Sheep Creek Cascade. 1.0 miles (or 1.6 km) one way. Elevation: 5160 feet (or 1573 m). The Sheep Creek crossing provides a place to rest after a gentle climb. Ferns and a series of cascading waterfalls decorate this shady canyon. A photo of a green meadow surrounded by sequoia trees. The caption reads, Summit Meadow (Sequoia National Forest). 5.0 miles (or 8.0 km) one way. Elevation: 7900 feet (or 2408 m). The meadow lies at the junction of Don Cecil Trail and the unpaved Big Meadows Road, near the boundary between park and forest. A faint half mile trail leads from the meadow to the top of Lookout Peak; be prepared to scramble over rocks if you choose to go to the summit. A map shows the Trailhead at your current location. The bottom photo shows a stretch of rounded rocky mountain peaks with conifer trees on the lower slopes. The caption reads, A view from Lookout Peak A quote by John Muir, describing a hike on the Don Cecil Trail, "Here at length we gain a general view of the great canyon of King's River lying far below..."

data.audioDescription: Dorst Creek Amphitheater is about 100 feet from the parking area, on a paved trail. There is a drinking fountain on the right just before you get to the Amphitheater, which is also on your right. There is seating for about 300 people along three rows of log benches. The center row has 14 benches. The outer rows have 13 benches that angle inward, to provide a better view of the presentation area. The rows are about four feet apart. The presentation area has a small stage in front where someone can stand and give a talk. A rear projection screen behind it is framed in wood. To the left of the stage is a campfire circle on the ground, enclosed by large rocks.

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the area around Eagle Trail and Mosquito Trail.

Eagle and Mosquito Lakes trails share the same route for the first 2 miles. At Eagle Basin, Eagle Lake Trail travels to the left for 3.4 miles one way. Mosquito Lake Trail travels right 3.6 miles to Mosquito Lake #1. The first campsite along the trail is 4 miles from the junction (6 miles from the trailhead) at Mosquito Lake #2. Both trails are moderately strenuous and offer mountain lakes and views.
data.audioDescription:
The text reads, This trail has three forks that lead, at times steeply, to Mosquito and Eagle Lakes and White Chief Canyon. Watch for fissures and sinkholes due to local karst geology (limestone metamorphosed to a rough marble). Like most park trails, these lead into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Possible destinations include: The top photo shows a tranquil lake with snow and foxtail pines lining its bank, beyond it are towering granite walls. The caption reads, Eagle Lake 3.6 miles (or 5.8 km) one way
Elevation: 10,010 feet (or 3,051 m) Eagle lake lies in a cirque, surrounded by towering granitic walls and ancient foxtail pines. Like several other lakes in this area, Eagle Lake has a small dam. The next photo is a reflective lake surrounded by forest. The caption reads, Mosquito Lakes 3.6 miles (or 5.8 km) one way to first lake Elevation: 9,586 feet (or 2,922m) at second lake Forest surrounds Lake #1, the lower lake, there is no camping here. Climb an unmaintained trail to the open upper lakes to camp. A map of the Mineral King area shows our location at the beginning of the Eagle Mosquito trail. The bottom photo is of a valley and cliffs are sprinkled with snow. The caption reads, The upper Mosquito Lakes basin A quote: President Barack Obama, in support of John Krebs Wilderness. "...we will set (wilderness lands) aside and guard their sanctity for everyone to share."

data.title: Eleven Range Overlook
data.listingDescription: Located along the Generals Highway between Hospital Rock and the Giant Forest Museum, Eleven Range Overlook features an outdoor exhibit and a spectacular vista overlooking the Kaweah Canyon toward the San Joaquin Valley.

images.altText: The brown sign for the Eleven Range Overlook with pine trees behind it.
images.title: Eleven Range Overlook
images.caption: The view from above

data.bodyText:
Located along the Generals Highway between Hospital Rock and the Giant Forest Museum, Eleven Range Overlook features an outdoor exhibit and a spectacular vista overlooking the Kaweah Canyon toward the San Joaquin Valley. Visibility from this point changes remarkably depending on season, temperature, and the presence of smoke from nearby fires. At times, air pollution from far away can obscure distant views of mountain peaks and the valley.

The KNP Complex Fire: High-Severity Fire In A Mixed-Conifer/Black Oak Forest
Across the KNP Fire Complex area, there is a mosaic, or patchwork, of fire severity and effects. Just up the road from here, you can see where fire killed numerous incense-cedar, ponderosa pine, and black oaks on both sides of the road. In the Marble Fork of the Kaweah River drainage that this slope rises above, fire severity was high in many areas due to high forest density; accumulated logs, sticks, and debris on the forest floor; many drought-killed trees; and steep terrain. How does the fire severity here compare to the severity in areas with a history of prescribed fire, such as the Giant Forest?
data.audioDescription: A highway barrier forms a low wall in front of a stone exhibit base. Walking around the barrier on a flat unpaved path leads to the exhibit. A large, low-profile panel has the title, Meeting the National Park Mission: Protecting Scenery. Main text reads: Named for the rows of rugged ridges visible on clear days, Eleven Range Overlook offers great views day and night. At times, however, two kinds of pollution from outside the park affect the view. Polluted air blurs scenery and harms trees. Unnatural light turns night skies gray and dims the stars. Your help in reducing these pollutants outside the park protects the scenery here. Behind that text is a photo showing a view similar to what can be seen from the exhibit area. Hills, or ranges, are covered with shrubby vegetation and descend into the distance. A horizontal dashed line marks a spot on the horizon below the hills, with text that says: Dashed line indicates approximate location of Coast Range. About 100 miles away, it is visible only on clear days. All of the text is repeated in Spanish. Below the main photo is a sidebar. One section shows two photos of the same location, one with very hazy air and one with clear air. text reads: Limited Scenery: Summer smog rises into the park, obscuring vistas. Photographs (right) show the same view on a smoggy and a clear day from the western edge of the Giant Forest.

data.title: Even in Good Habitat
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Even in Good Habitat," shows why sequoias fall.

images.altText: A metal panel has text and images on it explaining why giant sequoia trees fall over
images.title: Even in good habitat
images.caption: This exhibit can be found on the Big Trees Trail

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Even in Good Habitat," shows why sequoias fall.
data.audioDescription: The View: To your left are the grasses of Round Meadow and to your right are the sequoias of Giant Forest. A whale sized tree trunk lies between several smaller sequoias. A photo on the panel shows a line of giant sequoias at the meadow's edge. The text reads, Most sequoias die by falling, as the one in for of you did in 1992. Even in the best sequoia habitat these giants are not immortal. Soft soil, heavy snows, or root damage may unbalance a tree and cause it to lean. If it leans too much, its shallow roots cannot hold its huge weight, and the tree falls. In this tree's case, people may have hastened the process. A road cut near its base in the early 20th century severed some of its roots. It was tall enough that, had it fallen the other way, it would have hit the restaurant that once stood across the meadow. Additional text reads, I Heard a Sequoia Fall A quote by Bill Tweed, Park Ranger at Sequoia National Park, in July 1974: "It was a calm, sunny day in the Giant Forest. Out of the clear blue came loud cracks as the roots snapped, and then a crash like thunder. We found the tree shattered, with an amazing amount of water flowing from the broken wood. Touching the inside of the sequoia was startling, it was ice cold." A photo of a destroyed building, the walls and roof demolished and topped with tree debris. The caption reads, It's not wise to build beneath sequoias. They don't fall often but when they do, watch out. This photo shows the devastating effects of a falling sequoia. In 1941, it crushed the park superintendents' house not far from here.

data.title: Expanding Park Horizons
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, Expanding Park Horizons," identifies the mountain peaks that you can see from this location.

images.altText: A metal panel sits in a metal frame. In the distance tall trees and mountains can be seen.
images.title: Expanding Park Horizons
images.caption: How far can you see from this spot?

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, Expanding Park Horizons," identifies the mountain peaks that you can see from this location.
data.audioDescription: The View: In front of you is a steep drop off, as the stairway cuts into the rocks to the left and right. The tree filled valley below stretches into the distance, it frames a set of distant mountain peaks. The text reads, Before you stands the Great Western divide. The rigid peaks "divides" the Kaweah River drainage in front of you from the Kern River drainage on the other side. The Great Western divide rises high enough to block the view of Mount Whitney, tallest of the Sierran peaks at 14,494 feet (4417 m). In 1890, Sequoia National Park included the Giant Forest but not the peaks you see in the distance. Over time, ideas of what should be preserved in the national park changed. In 1926, this view became park scenery when Congress enlarged the boundary of the crest of the Sierra Nevada. A photo of the view of mountain peaks visible from this spot. The peaks and other features are identified from left to right: Triple Divide Peak 12,634' Lion Rock Little Blue Dome Mt. Stewart 12,205' Bearpaw Meadows 7,800' Mount Whitney 14,494' (not visible) Lawson Peak 13,140' Kaweah Gap Sugarbowl Dome Kaweah Queen 13,382' Black Kaweah 13,765' Lippincott Mountain 12,260' Mount Eisen 12,160' Black Rock Pass 11,600'

data.title: Farewell Gap-Franklin Lakes Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the area around Farewell Gap Trail and Franklin Lakes Trail.

images.altText: Trailhead sign next to trail with mountains in the distance
images.title: Farewell Gap Franklin Lakes Trailhead
images.caption: Farewell Gap Franklin Lakes Trailhead Sign

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the area around Farewell Gap Trail and Franklin Lakes Trail.

Farewell Gap Trail and Franklin Lakes Trail share the same route for the first 2.8 miles. From there, Farewell Gap Trail travels to the right for 2.7 miles one-way. To the left, Franklin Lakes Trail travels 2.6 miles one-way to a pair of lakes. Explore the rainbow-colored rocks that attracted miners to this area in the 1870s along Franklin Lakes Trail or see evidence of these miners as you view mineshafts (from a safe distance) along Farewell Gap Trail.

The first campsite along the trail is 4 miles from the trailhead at the junction between Franklin Lakes and Farewell Gap Trails. Although each of these hikes can be done as a day trip, many backpackers make Franklin Lakes their first stop on their way over Franklin Pass to Rattlesnake Canyon, the Kern Canyon and Mt. Whitney.
data.audioDescription:
The text reads, Take one fork of this trail to Franklin Lakes or beyond to the Kern Canyon. Another trail branches toward Farewell Gap, leading out of the park and into national forest lands. Like most park trails, these lead into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Possible destinations include: The top photo shows a tranquil lake surrounded by gray granite and Florence Peak. The caption reads, Franklin Lakes. 5.7 miles (or 9.2 km) one way Elevation: 10,331 feet (or 3,149 m) at first lake. Colorful metamorphic rocks skirt the trail but, at the lakes, the gray granitic presence of Florence Peak dominates. Franklin Pass lies almost three miles beyond the lakes. The next photo shows a green valley with patches of snow. The caption reads, Farewell Gap. 6.4 miles (or 9.8 km) one way. Elevation: 10,587 feet (3,227 m).

Farewell Gap, the low point in the prominent "V" to the south, marks the boundary between Sequoia National Park and Sequoia National Forest. A map of the Mineral King area shows our location at the beginning of the Franklin Farewell trail. The bottom photo is of a rocky "v" shaped valley dotted with trees and small patches of snow. A rocky mountain range lies beyond. The caption reads, View toward Franklin Pass A quote by Hanshan, Poet: "Who can leap the world's ties And sit with me among the white clouds?"

data.title: Feeding the Foothills
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit discusses the ways that changing temperatures could affect food chains in the foothills.

images.altText: An exhibit sign and a "picture post" are featured with native oak/chaparral vegetation in background
images.title: Feeding the Foothills outdoor exhibit
images.caption: Feeding the Foothills outdoor exhibit

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit discusses the ways that changing temperatures could affect food chains in the foothills.
data.audioDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Feeding the Foothills," shows color photos and text about blue oaks. About three feet to the left of the exhibit is a picture post, a metal post about four feet tall. The View: In front of the sign are two mature blue oak trees, and to your right is a California buckeye tree. Landscaped native flowers and plants surround the path. On the wayside is a large background image of a green, grassy hillside dotted with trees. A caption identifies the trees as "Blue oak trees." The text is written in both English and Spanish. The English text reads, Tough blue oaks, like the tree before you, are key to most life in the foothills. Well-adapted to survive summer's heat, they produce abundant acorns. Many birds, mammals, and insects rely on acorns, especially in fall. In turn, others rely on the acorn-eating species. Climate is key to acorn production. If climate change brings hotter weather or less rain, the timing, quantity, or quality of acorns will shift. Help scientists track changes in these trees and in their ecosystem by taking photos using the nearby picture post. On the bottom left are two photos. The first is of an acorn woodpecker with an acorn in its beak on a tree trunk filled with acorns in holes. The next is of a black bear climbing a tree. The caption reads, Some animals depend entirely on fall's nutrient-rich blue oak acorns. To survive winter, black bears gorge on acorns and woodpeckers cache them in trees. On the top right is a large inset with four photos. The header reads, Rain falls mostly December through March, with very little summer or fall moisture. A photo of bright green, round leaves has three large illustrated raindrops overlayed on the top edge. The caption reads, New Leaves. Bright green leaves usually burst from leaf buds in February through March. Blue oaks rely on winter rain to produce this growth. A photo of small, round, yellow-green blossoms among leaves has two large illustrated raindrops overlayed on the top edge. The caption reads, Tiny Blossoms. Oak flowers aren't very flower-like. They're catkins, hanging clusters of blooms with no petals. Look for these small green flowers in spring. A photo of small green acorns on a leafy branch has an illustrated sun overlayed on the top edge. The caption reads, Fruit of the Oak. From catkins come acorns, the blue oak's prized product. With too little rain, acorns may drop before maturing. A photo of small, brown acorns on a sparse branch has one illustrated raindrop overlayed on the top edge. The caption reads, Fall Harvest. Some animals travel miles for the ripe, brown acorns. Look for this vital food on oak branches and the ground below and in animal scat (poop). Below the captions, footer text reads, Find its Phase. Look at the blue oak in front of you. What seasonal phase do you see? On the bottom right of the wayside is a QR code. Text reads, How else does climate change affect life in these parks? Scan the code or visit go.nps.gov/cycle2 About three feet to your left is the picture post. On top of the pole is an eight-sided platform. Each side has an illustrated outline of a camera pointed outward and arrows to indicate clockwise movement, as well as a number and direction label. Side 1 is N, side 2 is NE, side 3 is E, side 4 is SE, side 5 is S, side 6 is SW, side 7 is W, side 8 is NW. On top is an outline of the front of a camera with the labels 9 and Up. On the post is a sign with instructions, a QR code and the url go.nps.gov/post5, and a diagram of the top of the post. The text reads, Picture Post. Instructions: 1. Place camera on post at N (north) position. 2. Take a photo at all nine positions, moving clockwise. Photo 9 captures the sky. 3. Use the code or link to upload your photos. Thank you for being a Citizen Scientist!

data.title: Foothills Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: Foothills Picnic Area is across the highway from Foothills Visitor Center. In winter and spring, this is a comfortable place to stop on the way up into the mountains, or on the return trip. In summer, the foothills are hot and dry, and fire restrictions may be in effect.

images.altText: Picnic tables, garbage bins, and a food storage box are scattered across a meadow of brown grass,
images.title: Foothills Picnic Area
images.caption: Foothills Picnic Area

data.bodyText:
Foothills Picnic Area is across the highway from Foothills Visitor Center. In winter and spring, this is a comfortable place to stop on the way up into the mountains, or on the return trip. In summer, the foothills are hot and dry, and fire restrictions may be in effect.

Public restrooms, a visitor center, and other services are available across the stree from the picnic area.

The KNP Complex Fire: How it Started

On September 9, 2021, lightning started three fires in Sequoia National Park. Two of the fires burning in remote, rugged terrain and heavy fuels, presented challenges to firefighting and spread rapidly. By mid-September, they joined to form a single fire called the KNP Complex. From here you can see a steep, burned slope behind the Foothills administrative buildings where the fire burned in mixed hardwood and shrub vegetation.  You’ll notice a range of conditions, from blackened, standing-dead trees or bare ground, to areas sprouting grasses or containing live green trees.  At other locations in the app, learn more about how fire history, terrain, vegetation, and weather affect how a fire burns.

data.title: For the Good of the Giants
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "For the Good of the Giants," shows what the Giant Forest area looked like in the 1950s.

images.altText: metal framed sign sits across from the giant forest museum
images.title: For the good of the giants
images.caption: This exhibit is found across the road from the Giant Forest Museum

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "For the Good of the Giants," shows what the Giant Forest area looked like in the 1950s.
data.audioDescription: A View: In front of you is a low bush with a two-lane road just beyond it. Across the road is a grassy area with a low fence surrounding a giant sequoia tree. To the right of the tree is a peaked wooden shade structure and a long brown wood building with a peaked green roof. On the panel, a black and white photo shows the same long brown wood building, with a parking lot in front of it. In the foreground are several old-fashioned gas pumps. Two long lines of 1950s cars, waiting for gas, stretch back through the parking lot, past the end of the building, and out of sight. The caption reads, Until 1970 the gas station shown here in the 1950s stood just across the road. It was one of the facilities removed to protect the sequoias of Giant Forest. The text reads, Try to imagine yourself standing here in the 1950s. You would have been facing a service station and a parking lot. Behind you stood almost 100 cabins and motel units. Development in the Giant Forest began long ago. As early as the 1890s people began building here. Campgrounds, hotels, shops, a post office, park headquarters, parking lots, a gas station, and a sewage treatment plant all stood on the roots of the sequoias. Over time, people recognized the damage being done to the grove's ecology and beauty. In the 1970s the park began to move services to less sensitive areas. In 1999 the last buildings came down. Today, the only facilities left here are those dedicated to one thing, helping you learn about the giant sequoias.
