data.title: Forests of Life
data.listingDescription: Dramatic, ancient trees such as sequoias are often thought of as Trees of Life. People tend to perceive them as eternal, or even magical. They are not eternal, of course, but evolve with natural systems that they need to thrive and regenerate. If we can care for those systems, the forest can go on as it has for thousands of years.

images.altText: A metal panel with text and images informs visitors about the longevity of forests
images.title: Forests of Life
images.caption: This exhibit can be found on the General Grant Tree Trail.

data.bodyText: Dramatic, ancient trees such as sequoias are often thought of as trees of Life. People tend to perceive them as eternal, or even magical. They are not eternal, of course, but evolve with natural systems that they need to thrive and regenerate. If we can care for those systems, the forest can go on as it has for thousands of years.
data.audioDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Forests of Life", shows you a view of an immense sequoia tree, looking up through green-leaved branches to its large trunk. There are six photos of different types of trees below it. The text reads, To people around the world, large old trees symbolize wisdom, fruitfulness, and strength. Because they live so long we imagine that they are eternal. However, giant sequoias and other "trees of life" are not immortal. They rely on natural processes to create habitat where they can reproduce and thrive. As long as we protect the sequoia's ecosystem, this tribe of ancients will live on. Is there an honored tree where you live? A photo shows two monks, wearing orange robes, seated before a large old tree. The caption reads, India: Monks meditate under one of the three most holy Bodhi trees in Buddhism. A photo shows a huge oak tree supported by scaffolding. The caption reads, England: The Major Oak, one of 50 Great British Trees, may have sheltered Robin Hood. A photo shows two large tree trunks, with a railed wooden walkway between them. The caption reads, Japan: The Great Sugi, a Cryptomeria tree, is honored as a Special Natural Monument. A photo shows a tall tree, with a thick trunk and fat, stubby branches at the top. The caption reads, Africa: A cultural and religious symbol, the baobab represents long life and endurance. A photo shows the view upward at a broad smooth tree trunk, with smaller branches of green leaves. The caption reads, New Zealand: All forest animals are said to be children of Tane mahuta (Lord of the Forest), a kauri tree. The last photo shows a tree with a massive trunk. Two people on the left are dwarfed by its size. The caption reads, Mexico: The revered El Tule, the thickest tree in the world, is a Montezuma cypress.

data.title: Frequent Fire
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Frequent Fire," shows how fire can affect sequoia growth.

images.altText: A metal panel sits in a metal frame. The metal frame stands in front of a burned giant sequoia tree
images.title: Frequent Fire
images.caption: This exhibit can be found on the Big Trees Trail

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Frequent Fire," shows how fire can affect sequoia growth.
data.audioDescription: The View: To your left are the grasses of Round Meadow and to your right are the sequoias of Giant Forest. You are standing near a giant sequoia that has an enormous black triangular scar at the base of the trunk that is about 15 feet high and 10 feet wide. The text on the panel reads, Frequent Fire Numerous fires created the large scar on the sequoia in front of you. Frequent fire is common in good sequoia habitat, and mature trees have ways to survive. Most large sequoias survive fire and live well despite large scars. Thick bark with many air pockets insulates the wood from heat. With little sap or pitch in it, the bark is not very flammable. High branches hold foliage well above most fires. With competing plants burned away, surviving trees get more water, nutrients, and sun. A photo of a fire worker inspecting the charred scar on a sequoia tree. He wears a yellow shirt, a white safety helmet, a backpack, and has a two-way radio on his belt. He touches the tree trunk with his left hand. His right hand is gloved, holding what looks like a shovel. The caption reads, A fire worker examines the base of a larger fire scar. A typical sequoia here might have survived several fires each century. New wood grows from either side of a fire scar, covering a little more each year. This healing growth leaves telltale marks on the tree's annual growth rings. These marks reveal how many fires a tree has survived.

data.title: From Hurt to Healing
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "From Hurt to Healing," shows the importance of preservation in Round Meadow.

images.altText: A metal panel sits in a metal frame. The metal frame stands in front of green grasses.
images.title: From hurt to healing wayside
images.caption: This exhibit can be found on the Big Trees Trail

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "From Hurt to Healing," shows the importance of preservation in Round Meadow.
data.audioDescription: The View: To your left are the grasses of Round Meadow and to your right are the sequoias of Giant Forest. No buildings obstruct your view. A background photo on the panel, taken from the meadow, shows a dense line of giant sequoia trees against a dark sky. The text reads, From Hurt to Healing Across this meadow, a restaurant, campground, and dozens of cabins once crowded the sequoias. Behind you stood the early park headquarters. Cars once drove where you now stand. Round Meadows's sequoias have been threatened by development more than once, yet people ultimately chose preservation. Preserving the Sequoia Habitat Late 1800s. There were plans to log the giant sequoias. Local citizens saved them by demanding the creation of Sequoia National Park in 1890. Early 1900s. Round Meadow, ringed by cabins, was still privately owned. In 1916 donations to the National Geographic Society bought Round Meadows for public use. Late 1900s. As the park became more popular, roads, campground, utilities, and public cabins spread around the meadow. In the 1970's the public began to support efforts to repair years of ecological damage. The park began eliminating facilities, removing the last building in 1999. Today. It's up to us to carry on. If we want to save sequoias, we must preserve their habitat, the natural places and processes that allow these amazing trees to thrive. A photo of the view before you, except that it shows a brown wood planked building on the far side of the meadow. A truck is parked on the road in front of it. A red circle has been drawn around the building. The caption reads, For decades, sequoias suffered so that this restaurant, which stood directly across from you, and more than 100 other buildings and their associated utilities could operate here.

data.title: Gamlin Cabin
data.listingDescription: Imagine life in a cabin like this in the shadow of trees like these. What would you come to value most about this place and the sequoias?

images.altText: An old cabin sits in the shade of the tall trees
images.title: Gamlin Cabin
images.caption: Gamlin Cabin as seen in summer

data.bodyText: Imagine life in a cabin like this in the shadow of trees like these. What would you come to value most about this place and the sequoias?
data.audioDescription: The View: In front of you is a dark brown log cabin about 24' wide by 18' deep. The outer walls are made of logs that have been cut down the length on four sides, to create long square beams, about two feet thick. These are stacked on top of each other to form the walls, and connected to each other with notches at the corners of the building. The top of the front wall is covered with wide wooden planks, and the peaked roof is covered with wooden shingles. The cabin has a double door at the entrance, divided by a post in the middle. Inside, the cabin has a dirt floor. There is a window on each side wall, and a stone fireplace on the back wall. The fireplace stones are rough cut, with a thin layer of mortar in between them. The stone base juts out in front. The fireplace is about ten feet across, with a five-foot opening in the center for burning wood in the inner hearth. A metal beam supports the rocks above the opening. A large squared off log forms the mantelpiece above the fireplace. The cabin framing for the roof is visible. It is mostly built out of round peeled logs, with a few squared off. Daylight shines through cracks in between the logs and planks, including a few spots in the roof. A wayside exhibit mounted on the fence outside is titled "Changing Values" and shows black and white photos and text about the adjacent Gamlin Cabin. A photo of people posing in front of this cabin, except that the cabin has only one door. The men wear hats, pants and shirts with vests. The women wear long skirts and puffy blouses. Additional detail, from left to right: A man with a bushy beard and a pocket watch. A donkey with two barefoot children astride its back. The boy is about 5 years old, in overalls, and the girl is about 10, in a dress. Both wear large straw hats. A woman holding the donkey's reins wears a ruffled apron, and a hat with decorations. In the doorway are two women in calf-length skirts, one with a scarf around her neck, like a tie. A man wearing a hat and watch chain, pets a dog. Another man wearing knee high boots leans against the building with his foot on a wagon. A caption notes, The logs of the Gamlin Cabin are sugar pine, and the roof shakes are sequoia wood. The text reads, Built before these sequoias were protected as a park, this cabin has seen many changes. How people used it varied with why they came to the grove. A timeline of pictures and history along the bottom reads, from left to right,Uses of the Gamlin Cabin. An oval portrait photo of a man with a light-colored mustache and beard, wearing a rounded short brimmed hat and a suit with a vest and tie. The caption reads, 1872. Israel Gamlin and his brother Thomas built the cabin, then lived in it for two summers while grazing sheep. Before living here, they lived in the Fallen Monarch, a downed sequoia further along this trail. A photo of a man in a uniform and hat, mounted on a horse in front of a massive sequoia tree trunk. The caption reads, 1890. After the park was created, the U.S. Cavalry came to protect the trees. They stored hay and grain for their horses in the cabin. A photo of a man with his hands on his hips. He has dark hair and a thick moustache, and wears a hat, white shirt, a dark vest with a badge and watch chain, and dark trousers. The caption reads, 1902 through 1909. The first civilian park ranger lived in the cabin for seven years. Lewis L. Davies not only patrolled the grove, he raised sequoia seedlings, learning about their relationship with fire.

data.title: Garfield Grove Trailhead
data.listingDescription:
If you'd like to experience a remote sequoia grove, consider the Garfield-Hockett Trail. It's a relatively steep 5-mile one-way climb to the Garfield Sequoia Grove, then levels out beyond the grove as it approaches the Hockett Plateau. The first campsite along the trail is 4 miles from the trailhead at Snowslide.

As you hike, look for views of Homer's Nose, a prominent granite dome that can be seen from Visalia.

images.altText: Signs on a trail in a densely forested area.

data.bodyText:
This trailhead is currently inaccessible by vehicle (see Road Conditions below). The trail was heavily damaged by flooding and landlslides during extreme winter storms of 2022-2023 and has not been repaired . Anyone wishing to travel the trail should be self-reliant and expect significant flood and landslide damage, including sections of trail that are completely gone near all drainages.

If you'd like to experience a remote sequoia grove, consider the Garfield-Hockett Trail. It's a relatively steep 5-mile one-way climb to the Garfield Sequoia Grove, then levels out beyond the grove as it approaches the Hockett Plateau. The first campsite along the trail is 4 miles from the trailhead at Snowslide.

As you hike, look for views of Homer's Nose, a prominent granite dome that can be seen from Visalia.

Road Conditions

The South Fork Road is currently impassable within the national park due to extensive, heavy damage from flooding and landslides during winter storms in 2022-2023. No trailhead parking is available. When the road was open, it was a very rugged, backcountry road. Many sections of the road are one-lane with limited visibility. There are also stretches with steep drop-offs and no shoulder. High clearance vehicles are recommended.
data.audioDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the South Fork area. The text reads, two trails from this secluded area lead to low-elevation sequoia groves. One of these, Garfield Grove, formed the heart of the original 1890 Sequoia National Park. Only later was the park enlarged to include other groves and, later still, the high peaks. Like most park trails, these lead into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. A map shows the location of the South Fork Trail. A photo shows a creek cascading through a bank of large rocks, surrounded by trees. The caption reads, Ladybug Trail 4.2 miles (or 6.8 km) one way. This relatively easy trail begins at the end of the parking area and ends at Whiskey Log Camp in the South Fork sequoia grove. As you hike, look along the ridge to the north for views of Homer's Nose, a prominent granite dome. The first permitted camping spot on this trail is Ladybug Camp (1.7 miles, or 2.7 km). A photo shows a row of large reddish-brown sequoia trunks in a lush grove. The caption reads, Garfield Grove Trail, 2.9 miles (or 4.7 km) one way to first sequoias. This trail begins along the road, just before the parking area. It climbs across north facing slopes into Garfield Grove, one of the largest sequoia groves in this park. The first permitted camping is at Snowslide Creek (3.6 miles or 5.8 km). Beyond Garfield Grove, the trail levels out as it approaches Hockett Meadow, 11.1 miles (or 17.9 km) from here. A quote by Joseph Wood Krutch, "The idea of wilderness is one of the permanent homes of the human spirit." A bottom photo shows tree covered mountains with a granite peak with traces of snow in the distance. The caption reads, "A view from Ladybug Trail."

data.title: General Grant Tree
data.listingDescription: Before you stands the second-largest tree in the world. The General Grant Tree is not one of the oldest, but it has the advantage of growing in a spot with bright sunlight and plenty of water, so it grew larger quickly. It holds two additional titles: the Nation's Christmas Tree (not the National Christmas Tree, which gets decorated in Washington, D.C.) and the country's only living national shrine. Sequoia FactsSequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks are home to seven of th

images.altText: A reddish brown giant sequoia tree stands in front of a wooden sign labeled the General Grant Tree
images.title: General Grant Tree
images.caption: The General Grant Tree

data.bodyText:
Before you stands the second-largest tree in the world. The General Grant Tree is not one of the oldest, but it has the advantage of growing in a spot with bright sunlight and plenty of water, so it grew larger quickly. It holds two additional titles: the Nation's Christmas Tree (not the National Christmas Tree, which gets decorated in Washington, D.C.) and the country's only living national shrine.

Sequoia Facts

Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks are home to seven of the ten largest trees in the world. Out of the largest 30 trees, 18 can be found here.

How is tree size determined? In this system, trees are measured by trunk volume only, not branches, leaves, or roots. 

Tree dimensions change year to year because trees grow, branches fall, and fires can burn and remove a portion of a tree. Until 2003, the Washington Tree in Giant Forest (Sequoia National Park) was the second-largest sequoia. After being reduced by fire, it no longer ranks among the top 30.

If branches are also measured, the President Tree is the second largest tree, bumping General Grant to third.

Tree Facts

Height: 268.1 feet (88.7 meters)
Ground circumference: 107.5 feet (32.8 meters)
Trunk volume: 46,608 cubic feet (1320 cubic meters)
data.audioDescription: In front of you is an enormous sequoia tree. The tree has deep crevices and a flared base. Its massive trunk is covered with a shaggy reddish-brown bark that is thick and fibrous. Its thick stubby branches with oval clusters of green leaves, start high above the ground, about halfway up the trunk. The branches are so short that the tree is shaped more like a pointed cylinder than a regular tree. The shape could also be compared to a fat carrot with a few broccoli florets sticking out near the top. Looking up from this angle, so close to the massive tree, almost all one can see is trunk, with a few branches very high in the air. The ground in front of the tree is fenced off. Just beyond the fence is a brown wooden sign. The white carved lettering on it reads, General Grant. The Nation's Christmas tree.

data.title: General Grant Tree Trailhead
data.listingDescription: You are about to travel among some of the giants of the world. The General Grant Trail is an easy, 0.5 mile loop through the Grant Grove of sequoias.The grove's namesake, the General Grant Tree, is the second-largest tree by volume in the world. (The largest is the General Sherman Tree, also in Sequoia Kings Canyon National Parks.) President Coolidge proclaimed the General Grant Tree as the Nation's Christmas tree in 1926. You can also visit the historic Gamlin Cabin here.

images.altText: An aspalt path forks in two directions. The left is to the parking lot , the right is to the trail
images.title: General Grant Tree Trailhead
images.caption: The start of the General Grant Trail

data.bodyText:
You are about to travel among some of the giants of the world. The General Grant Trail is an easy, 0.5 mile loop through the Grant Grove of sequoias.

The grove's namesake, the General Grant Tree, is the second-largest tree by volume in the world. (The largest is the General Sherman Tree, also in Sequoia Kings Canyon National Parks.)

President Coolidge proclaimed the General Grant Tree as the Nation's Christmas tree in 1926. You can also visit the historic Gamlin Cabin and walk inside the Fallen Monarch sequoia as you travel along this paved trail. Wayside exhibits along the trail offer insights into the history and natural wonders of this area in both English and Spanish. After you witness these giant sequoias, you can also explore other nearby groves, such as Redwood Mountain and North Grove.

Visiting in Winter

The Grant Tree Trail is a good choice in winter, as long as you're prepared. If trail conditions are icy, you may wish to use snowshoes, which are available for rent at the Grant Grove Gift Shop (check for final decision on availability).
data.audioDescription: Forest Description: You are at the beginning of a trail through a conifer forest that leads to the General Grant Tree. The forest is canopied with pine, incense-cedar, fir, and, of course, sequoia trees. The branches of young sequoias give them the cone shape of most other conifer trees, like a Christmas tree. In mature sequoias, however, the trunk becomes much bigger than the branches. In fact, the top of the tree might only be about twice the width of the base, so it is shaped more like a pointed bottle brush than a regular tree. Branches only start about halfway up the trunk. The mature trees, called monarchs, are nature's skyscrapers. They can grow as tall as a 26-story building. Trying to glimpse their tippy tops could give you a sore neck. Their trunks are reddish brown, with thick layers of deeply furrowed bark that is soft and fibrous on the surface, like shredded wheat cereal. Some trunks have dark, indented triangular scars, caused by fire. These are widest at the bottom, and point upward. The forest floor is covered with a thick, soft carpet of pine needles. Around large sequoias, the ground is also covered with thin strips of bark that have shredded away from the tree trunks. The forest creates a rich habitat for a large variety of wildlife, including black bears, coyotes, mule deer, beavers, chickarees, and gray squirrels. Depending upon the season, you may also hear the sounds of forest birds: ravens, (insert birdsong?), nuthatches, (insert birdsong?), and Steller's jays. As the seasons change, so does the look of the forest. Spring brings warming temperatures and small colorful wildflowers on the forest floor. Winter brings a blanket of snow. Text along this trail is shown in English and Spanish but for this audio description we will only read English, and any additional information provided by Braille. This trailhead orientation panel features a tactile map of the trail, and an illustration of a giant sequoia, with a thick trunk, with reddish brown bark, and short stubby branches with clusters of small green leaves, that start high above the ground. The text reads, This grove showcases some of the best sequoia habitat anywhere, producing some of the world's largest trees. Allow 30 minutes to complete this Â½ mile (or 0.8 km) paved loop. Relatively easy, it has no steep slopes or stairs on the main trail. Halfway around the loop stands the General Grant Tree, one of the largest trees on Earth. Please, for the sake of the sequoias' shallow roots, stay on the trail. A tactile map of the Grant Grove area, generally described from the bottom to the top. A depressed surface with small round dots represents the paved road. Two paved oval areas have a raised letter "P" to indicate parking. A raised circle with a star above one of the parking lots shows where you are right now. Stretching out from either side is a deep groove that represents Grant Tree Trail loop. Little bars across the trail represent where tactile exhibits with Braille are located. There is also a stretch of trail, with raised square bumps, that cuts across the loop trail. It leads through a fallen hollow sequoia tree called the Fallen Monarch. It is a dirt trail with steps, which is not accessible. Please exercise caution! Near the top of the loop trail, on the right side, is a depressed circle with a raise dot in the center. This represents the General Grant Tree. A legend on top identifies six tactile shapes used on the map, already described. In the lower left corner, a depressed horizontal bar that represents 300 feet (or 91 m) in length. A few inches above it is a depressed arrow pointing upward to represent north. The text reads, Trail safety All natural areas pose risks. You are responsible for your own safety. Watch for uneven or slippery surfaces. Be aware of what is around you and overhead. Branches, heavy cones, and entire trees may fall. Listen for cracking, snapping sounds and get out of the way. A free Braille copy of the entire exhibit text is available at Kings Canyon Visitor Center. On the lower right corner of the panel, an indented black arrow points right toward the Loop Trail. Additional Braille information reads, Welcome. This half mile, paved loop is about ten feet wide. Above is a tactile map. Above that is a legend that defines the symbols. However, please note that the legend is actually below the tactile map, not above it.

data.title: General Sherman Tree
data.listingDescription: There are taller trees, and wider trees, but the General Sherman Tree contains more wood (volume) in its trunk than any other tree on Earth. Behind the Sherman Tree are the General Grant, President, Lincoln, and Stagg trees. Another measure of tree volume is the total biomass of the tree-trunk, branches, roots, and foliage. If we measure the biomass, the Sherman Tree still ranks at #1, but the General Grant Tree loses second place to the President Tree.

images.altText: The largest tree in the world stands behind a wooden fence
images.title: General Sherman Tree
images.caption: The General Sherman Tree, named after William Tecumseh Sherman

data.bodyText:
There are taller trees, and wider trees, but the General Sherman Tree contains more wood (volume) in its trunk than any other tree on Earth. Behind the Sherman Tree are the General Grant, President, Lincoln, and Stagg trees. Another measure of tree volume is the total biomass of the tree-trunk, branches, roots, and foliage. If we measure the biomass, the Sherman Tree still ranks at #1, but the General Grant Tree loses second place to the President Tree.

Rapid growth over a long life accounts for the size of these trees, but they are not as old as once thought. The most recent age estimate of the Sherman Tree is about 2200 years old.

Sequoia roots are shallow but spread wide. They entangle with the roots of other sequoias, forming a kind of mesh that helps all the trees maintain balance and stability.

As you walk among sequoias, watch for Douglas squirrels, also called chickarees. They climb into sequoias and chew through the stems of cones. If you come across a tree that seems to drop a cone every few seconds, you know that a Douglas squirrel is cutting cones for dinner. They then eat the green, fleshy covering of the cones; look for chewed-up cones on the ground. They also store cones and dried mushrooms high in pines or sequoias.

The Congress Trail starts near the Sherman Tree, and provides a tour of some of the most spectacular sequoias of Giant Forest. This easy three-mile loop also connects to other trails that can take you throughout Giant Forest (be sure to take a map).

The Sherman Tree was once named the Karl Marx Tree by the Kaweah Colony, a utopian group that lived in Three Rivers before Congress created this park. The Kaweah Colony supported itself in part through logging. When the national park was established, their efforts were deemed illegal. One of their original structures, Squatter's Cabin, still stands near Crescent Meadow and is on the National Register of Historic Places.

In 1903, the Buffalo Soldiers protected these parks. Their leader, then-Captain Charles Young, was one of the first superintendents of these parks and the first African-American superintendent of any national park. He developed plans to protect the legacy of the giant sequoia groves, oversaw the building of the first roads into the parks, and protected both parks from illegal logging, grazing, and poaching.

Services and Parking

The main parking area and trailhead for the General Sherman Tree is located just off Wolverton Road. The parking area is one of the main shuttle stops in the parks. Shuttles stop here every 15 to 20 minutes.

Parking for people with disabilities is located on the Generals Highway 2 miles from the Giant Forest Museum and 3 miles from the Lodgepole Visitor Center.
The parking area provides restrooms, trash cans, water, and food-storage lockers.

Make sure that you store all food is stored in these lockers-bears can be active in this parking lot.

The General Sherman Tree is about a half mile from the parking lot. Be prepared for an uphill climb when return from your hike. In summer, you can avoid the uphill hike by walking from the Sherman Tree down to the accessible parking lot and shuttle stop along the Generals Highway. From there, take the Orange Route back to the main General Sherman Tree parking area.

Accessibility

Accessible parking is located on the Generals Highway 2 miles from the Giant Forest Museum and 3 miles from the Lodgepole Visitor Center. The parking area provides restrooms, trash cans, and water. An easy path leads to the General Sherman Tree from the trailhead. This wheelchair-accessible paved path is accessible by wheelchairs, strollers, and walkers. The trail is about 500 feet in length and is gently sloped.

In summer, the free park shuttle leads to the General Sherman Tree accessible parking area.
data.audioDescription: The enormous General Sherman tree stands before you, about 40 feet away. Its bark is a bumpy reddish brown, with some lighter streaks. Grooves in the bark run vertically up the trunk. The trunk remains thick as it rises up toward the crown, tapering only gradually. More than halfway up, branches and green foliage finally appear. The massive branches are short and stubby. To see the top of the tree, one must look almost straight up. A split rail fence surrounds the tree, keeping people away for the tree's protection. Visit nearby wayside exhibits to learn more about the scale of the tree. A wide wooden sign mounted on the ground in the walkway to the tree. The wood is worn and rounded. Engraved white lettering reads, "General Sherman"

data.title: General Sherman Tree Accessible Trailhead Shuttle Stop
data.listingDescription: This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at the accessible parking area for the General Sherman tree, the largest tree in the world! From here is the shortest walking distance to General Sherman, 500ft (150m). This parking lot is for vehicles with accessibility placards only. All other vehicles can park at the main General Sherman Parking Area, and walk 0.5 miles (0.8km) to the tree from there, or ride the shuttle back to this lot for a shorter hike.

images.altText: A park ranger directs traffic at a shuttle stop with bathrooms and a white shuttle bus.
images.title: Lowe Sherman Shuttle Stop
images.caption: The shuttle stop at the General Sherman Tree Accessible Trailhead, also known as "Lower Sherman".

data.bodyText:
This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at the accessible parking area for the General Sherman tree, the largest tree in the world!

From here is the shortest walking distance to General Sherman, 500 ft (150 m).

This parking lot is for vehicles with accessibility placards only. All other vehicles can park at the main General Sherman Parking Area, and walk 0.5 miles (0.8km) to the tree from there, or ride the shuttle back to this lot for a shorter hike.

Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks.

Shuttles within the park are free; round-trip shuttles from Visalia are $20, which includes the park entrance fee.

All buses are wheelchair accessible, and either kneel or have lifts.

Visit the park shuttles page for more information, including a route map.

data.title: General Sherman Tree Main Trailhead
data.listingDescription: You are getting close to the famous General Sherman Tree. The volume of wood in its trunk alone makes it the largest tree in the world. As you walk the 0.8 miles to it, you'll pass many other spectacular giants as well. At the bottom of the trail, you can stand by a cross section of a sequoia trunk that was cut years ago. Because this trail goes downhill to where the giant grows, your walk offers the unique experience of seeing the Sherman Tree from top to bottom.

images.altText: Two benches sit on opposite sides of a cement path. A wooden roof and pillars sits over the path
images.title: General Sherman Tree Trailhead
images.caption: The upper trailhead structure for General Sherman Tree area

data.bodyText:
You are getting close to the famous General Sherman Tree. The volume of wood in its trunk alone makes it the largest tree in the world. As you walk the 0.5 miles (0.8 km) to it, you'll pass many other spectacular giants as well. At the bottom of the trail, you can stand by a cross section of a sequoia trunk that was cut years ago.

Because this trail goes downhill to where the giant grows, your walk offers the unique experience of seeing the Sherman Tree from top to bottom. You also get a view into the canopy of the sequoia grove, a habitat that few people ever witness. Watch for Douglas squirrels (aka chickarees) and other inhabitants of these high places.

After seeing General Sherman, explore the other trails near the tree before heading back uphill to your car. From late May to early September, you have the option to ride a free shuttle back up to the parking lot. The shuttle stop is near the restrooms on the Generals Highway, further downslope from the Sherman Tree.

You can also connect from the Sherman Tree to most of the trails in the Giant Forest. If you have a map, energy, and plenty of daylight, head for Crescent Meadow, Tharp's Log, the Giant Forest Museum, or even the High Sierra Trail.

Accessibility

People with disabilities may park in the small lot along the Generals Highway near the restroom.
data.audioDescription: Forest Description: You are at the beginning of a trail through a conifer forest that leads to the General Sherman Tree. The forest is canopied with pine, incense-cedar, fir, and, of course, sequoia trees. The branches of young sequoias give them the cone shape of most other conifer trees, like a Christmas tree. In mature sequoias, however, the trunk becomes much bigger than the branches. In fact, the top of the tree might only be about twice the width of the base, so it is shaped more like a pointed bottle brush than a regular tree. Branches only start about halfway up the trunk. The mature trees, called monarchs, are nature's skyscrapers. They can grow as tall as a 26-story building. Trying to glimpse their tippy tops could give you a sore neck. Their trunks are reddish brown, with thick layers of deeply furrowed bark that is soft and fibrous on the surface, like shredded wheat cereal. Some trunks have dark, indented triangular scars, caused by fire. These are widest at the bottom, and point upward. The forest floor is covered with a thick, soft carpet of pine needles. Around large sequoias, the ground is also covered with thin strips of bark that have shredded away from the tree trunks. The forest creates a rich habitat for a large variety of wildlife, including black bears, coyotes, mule deer, beavers, chickarees, and gray squirrels. Depending upon the season, you may also hear the sounds of forest birds: ravens, (insert birdsong?), nuthatches, (insert birdsong?), and Steller's jays. As the seasons change, so does the look of the forest. Spring brings warming temperatures and small colorful wildflowers on the forest floor. Winter brings a blanket of snow. This trailhead orientation panel provides information notices, photos, popular hikes around the Sherman Tree area. The View: You are standing in a sequoia forest near the top of the trail. Trees are relatively small and far apart, with plenty of open clearings. As you start to walk the trail, listen for the call of chickadees which sound like "cheeseburger"; and the call of the chickaree rodent, which sounds like a high pitched, "pew, pew". Along the trail, you can touch tree trunks and smell changing scents in the air, leaves, and bark. By the end, you will be in a dense, tall forest of sequoias, where you can strut along a giant trunk or run your fingers over a tall twisted ball of roots. The text reads, The Sherman Tree trailhead There are three photos with information about three popular hikes. A photo of an immense monarch sequoia tree, The General Sherman Tree, with a giant sequoia forest around it. People appear tiny standing before it. The General Sherman Tree is a half-mile (or 0.8 km) down the path. A photo of three giant sequoia trunks grouped together, The Senate Group. It is part of The Congress Trail, a two-mile (or 3.2 km) loop that starts at the Sherman Tree and continues through the Giant Forest Sequoia Grove. A photo taken from the base of a giant sequoia, looking straight up. The deeply grooved reddish brown trunk gives way to a densely leaved top, with blue sky above. The text explains that the Trail of the Sequoias is a moderate six-mile (or 9.7 km) loop that splits from the Congress Trail at the Senate Group and rejoins it at the Chief Sequoyah Tree. It says to bring a trail map. Junctions along this trail can be confusing. A black and white photo portrait of man. His dark wavy hair is combed to the side and hangs down just below his ears. His eyes are light and deep-set, and he has a rounded nose. He has long mustache and full, bushy beard. He is wearing a wool overcoat with a buttoned shirt and scarf. The text reads, John Muir in Giant Forest In 1875 pioneer naturalist John Muir visited here and gave this grove its enduring name: "...this part of the Sequoia belt seemed to me the finest, and I then named it "The Giant Forest." ... a magnificent growth of giants grouped in pure temple groves, ranged in colonnades along the sides of meadows, or scattered among the other trees. ... when I entered the sublime wilderness the day was nearly done, the trees with rosy, glowing countenance seem to be hushed and thoughtful, as if waiting in conscious religious dependence on the sun, and one naturally walked softly awe-stricken among them. I wandered on, meeting nobler trees where all were noble."

data.title: General Sherman Tree Main Trailhead Shuttle Stop
data.listingDescription: This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at the main parking area for the General Sherman tree, the largest tree in the world! From here it is a 0.5 mile (0.8 km) walk down a paved path with stairs to General Sherman. For a shorter walk, take the shuttle to the General Sherman Accessible Trailhead, which is a 500ft (150 m) distance. Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited.

images.altText: A shuttle bus arrives at a bus stop with a wooden kiosk. A man is opening a brown trashcan.
images.title: Upper Sherman Shuttle Stop
images.caption: The shuttle stop at the General Sherman Tree Main Trailhead, also known as "Upper Sherman".

data.bodyText:
This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at the main parking area for the General Sherman tree, the largest tree in the world!

From here it is a 0.5 mile (0.8 km) walk down a paved path with stairs to General Sherman.

For a shorter walk, take the shuttle to the General Sherman Accessible Trailhead, which is a 500 ft (150 m) distance.

Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks.

Shuttles within the park are free; round-trip shuttles from Visalia are $20, which includes the park entrance fee.

All buses are wheelchair accessible, and either kneel or have lifts.

Visit the park shuttles page for more information, including a route map.

data.title: Giant Forest Museum Shuttle Stop
data.listingDescription: This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at the Giant Forest Museum, which is an excellent entry point to learning about the giant sequoias and surrounding ecosystem. The museum is surrounded by a series of easy trails by which to explore the sequoias. Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited.

images.altText: A crowd steps off a white shuttle bus. There is a shuttle stop with a wooden kiosk in the background
images.title: Giant Forest Museum Shuttle Stop
images.caption: The shuttle stop at Giant Forest Museum.

data.bodyText:
This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at the Giant Forest Museum, which is an excellent entry point to learning about the giant sequoias and surrounding ecosystem. The museum is surrounded by a series of easy trails by which to explore the sequoias.

Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks.

Shuttles within the park are free.

All buses are wheelchair accessible and either kneel or have lifts.

Visit the park shuttles page for more information, including a route map.


Visalia Shuttles

We've partnered with the City of Visalia to offer shuttles that bring riders from Visalia and Three Rivers to Giant Forest Museum. Reservations are required and can be made by visiting sequoiashuttle.com or calling 877-287-4453. Round-trip shuttles from Visalia are $20, which includes the park entrance fee.

Once you reach Giant Forest Museum, transfer to other shuttles to visit features along Moro Rock - Crescent Meadow Road, the Lodgepole area, and Wuksachi Lodge for an elegant lunch. Be sure to make it back to Giant Forest museum in time for your return trip.

data.audioDescription: This park orientation board shows a map and photos of the Giant Forest Museum area. The text reads, Getting to know sequoias takes two things: learning about them and experiencing them firsthand. Explore the museum's indoor exhibits, but then leave the walls behind. Take a walk through the sequoia's world. If you plan to explore, be sure to purchase a map in the museum or any other visitor center. A map shows our location in the Giant Forest Museum area. A key names the main trails and shows round trip distances. Big Trees Trail. 1.25 miles (or 2 km). 1.5 hrs. To Beetle Rock. 0.5 miles (or 800 m). 15 min Hazelwood Trail. 1.5 miles (or 2.4 km). 1.0 hrs. Accessibility. Beetle Rock Trail This paved trail has a moderate grade. Only vehicles with accessibility permits may use the small parking area near the beginning of the trail. Big Trees Trail The Big Trees Trail is paved. From the museum down to the Generals Highway, it has a moderate grade. Around Round Meadow the trail is flat. Only vehicles with accessibility permits may use the small parking area at Round Meadow. Hazelwood Trail The Hazelwood Trail is unpaved with uneven surfaces. It is relatively flat, but has a short incline at the beginning of the trail. Other trails There is great variability among the trails in Giant Forest. Some other trails might be accessible depending on your ability. Some Things to Do Here A photo of an exhibit panel depicting a forest scene, including the shallow roots of a fallen sequoia tree. The caption reads, Enjoy exhibits at the Giant Forest Museum and get answers to your questions about sequoia trees. A photo of a large flat rock. Beyond it is an expansive view. The caption reads, At Beetle Rock look west toward the Coast Range and learn about local air quality. A photo of a green meadow, lined with giant sequoias. The caption reads, Examine why sequoias grow along the Big Trees Trail. See giant trees towering over a forest meadow.

data.bodyText:
The Grant Grove Cabins are in the Grant Grove Village area of Kings Canyon National Park. Giant sequoias and a variety of services are nearby, including a visitor center, market, restaurant, gift shop, and post office. Guests can choose from six types of cabins, some of which are available year-round. At an elevation of 6,500 feet (1,980 m), this area is snowy in winter and tire chains may be needed during winter storms.

For more information and lodging availability visit Grant Grove Cabin's webpage.

data.title: Grizzly Falls
data.listingDescription: Grizzly Falls and its picnic area are located in the Sequoia National Forest, 4.6 miles (7.4 km) from the Cedar Grove Visitor Center. No grills or water are available at this site. From the picnic area, follow a short walk to Grizzly Falls, an 80 foot waterfall that swells in early spring.

images.altText: A waterfall and trees
images.caption: The falls in spring. Photo by Alison Taggart-Barone.

data.bodyText: Grizzly Falls and its picnic area are located in the Sequoia National Forest, 4.6 miles (7.4 km) from the Cedar Grove Visitor Center. No grills or water are available at this site. From the picnic area, follow a short walk to Grizzly Falls, an 80 foot waterfall that swells in early spring.
data.audioDescription:
Visible from the road the waterfall is impossible to miss. Walk up to the base and watch the waterfall plunge eighty feet down a granite wall. Step closer through the large rocks to Grizzly Falls and you'll be greeted by a refreshing mist. But be careful, it can be slippery and muddy.
Depending on the season, the waterfall varies in size. After a snowy winter, Grizzly Creek swells and the waterfall widens to a frothy wall of thundering white water. When there is less snow, Grizzly Falls retreats to the right side of the exposed granite, forming a channel of freefalling water that fans out as it spreads over rocks toward the base of the falls.

data.title: Halstead Meadow Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: Next to a restored meadow, Halstead Meadow Picnic Area is four miles from the Lodgepole Visitor Center.

images.altText: a green meadow stretches into the distance a mountain covered with trees is behind the meadow
images.title: Halstead Meadow Picnic Area
images.caption: View of Halstead Meadow as seen from the picnic area

data.bodyText: Next to a restored meadow, Halstead Meadow Picnic Area is four miles from the Lodgepole Visitor Center.
data.audioDescription: Here, the road crosses a bridge over lush green Halstead Meadow. The meadow is roughly the length of a football field on one side and the size of two or three football fields on the other. There are varied wildflowers in early summer after the snow has melted. One can often see bears grazing on the meadow's grasses and other plants. Besides bears, other animals found in the meadow include mule deer, weasels, and many varieties of songbirds.

data.title: Hazelwood Nature Trail Trailhead
data.listingDescription: The Hazelwood Nature Trail features a 0.5-mile (0.8-km) loop trail. Along the Hazelwood Nature Trail you will walk through a mixed-fir forest with towering giant sequoias, and encounter a meadow. Along the trail, several exhibit signs provide information about the plants and and how they survive the seasons.

images.altText: A green trailhead sign displays a map, trees photo, and measurements for trail slope, width, etc and
images.title: Hazelwood Nature Trail Trailhead
images.caption: Hazelwood Nature Trail trailhead sign

data.bodyText:
The Hazelwood Nature Trail features a 0.5-mile (0.8-km) loop trail. This firm-packed trail has an elevation gain of approximately 50 feet (15 m). The average trail grade is 6.5% (maximum 10%) and the maximum cross slope is less than 2%. The trail is 6 feet wide.  

Along the Hazelwood Nature Trail you will walk through a mixed-fir forest with towering giant sequoias, and even encounter a meadow. Along the trail, several exhibit signs provide information about the plants and animals in the area and how they survive the seasons. 

Limited parallel parking is available here. The Alta Trail and Rimrock Trail connect to this loop, so this loop can also be accessed from other parking areas and trailheads.
data.audioDescription: This trailhead sign includes a photograph of the trail shrouded in trees, a map, and text with safety information. On the left of the panel is a map. It shows your location on the map, next to a parallel parking lot along the Generals Highway. The map extent is the Hazelwood Loop Trail, as well as intersections with the Rimrock Trail, the Alta Trail (two intersections), and portions of the Bear Hill Trail and Big Trees trails. The text accompanying the map reads, “Trail Information,” “This gently sloping loop trail leads through a portion of the Giant Forest sequoia grove. The path circles the upper end of Hazelwood Meadow and a footbridge crosses a small creek. Look for water-loving plants and wildflowers that thrive in wet conditions along the creek and in the meadow. After a short walk from this point, you’ll reach the loop portion of the Hazelwood Nature Trail. The loop is 0.6 miles (1 km) long and is relatively flat. The path is firmly packed and has benches and pullouts. The trail is suitable for people in wheelchairs or families with small children or strollers. From this point, you can also walk to the General Sherman Tree, Giant Forest Museum, or connect with other Giant Forest trails. If you choose a longer hike, a trail map is recommended. Maps are sold at Giant Forest Museum and other visitor centers.” The following trail accessibility statistics are also included on the sign: “Length of loop: 0.5 miles (0.8 km) from this point. Elevation gain: 50 feet (15 m). Trail surface: Firm-packed. Trail grade: Average 6.5%, Maximum 10%. Maximum cross slope: Less than 2%. Clear tread width: 6 feet” Below the map, additional text reads as follows: “Protect Sequoia National Park” “Stay on trails. Shortcutting damages the natural landscape. Carry out all trash. Do not feed or approach wildlife. All pets are prohibited on park trails. Most trails in Giant Forest are closed to stock. Leave all natural objects and artifacts in the park undisturbed. Please do not take any cones or other items. Do not disturb wildlife, plants, or historic objects.” “Protect Yourself All natural areas pose risks. You are responsible for your own safety. Carry a map and know how to use it. Watch for uneven or slippery footing. Be cautious around steep drop-offs and wet or icy areas. Don't walk on cones or other forest litter that may roll or slide underfoot. Be aware of what’s around you and overhead. Trees and limbs can fall without warning. Be careful when crossing roads. Use trails unless you need to cross the highway, then use crosswalks.”

data.title: High Sierra Trailhead
data.listingDescription: The historic High Sierra Trail is a marvel of engineering that stays relatively level for its first portion, offering views of wilderness without the steep climbs of other park trails. Hike 11 miles one-way (22 miles round-trip) to Bearpaw Meadow, where you can camp in designated sites or, with reservations, enjoy the luxury of Bearpaw High SIerra Camp. The trail travels through forests and oaks, along canyons, and reaches subalpine meadows.

images.altText: The sign for the High Sierra Trailhead
images.title: High Sierra Trailhead
images.caption: High Sierra Trailhead Sign

data.bodyText:
The historic High Sierra Trail is a marvel of engineering that stays relatively level for its first portion, offering views of wilderness without the steep climbs of other park trails. Hike 11 miles one-way (22 miles round-trip) to Bearpaw Meadow, where you can camp in designated sites or, with reservations, enjoy the luxury of Bearpaw High SIerra Camp. The trail travels through forests and oaks, along canyons, and reaches subalpine meadows. The first available campsite is at Mehrten Creek after 5.5 miles.

Adventurous travelers can embark on extended trips along this trail to cross the Sierra Nevada range to Mt. Whitney, the highest peak in the contiguous United States. Most hikers, however, will look for easier destinations, such as Eagle View (one mile from the trailhead), Mehrten Creek, and Bearpaw Meadow.
data.audioDescription: The text reads, This famous trail crosses the Sierra Nevada, ending atop Mount Whitney. Built in 1928 to 1932, it joins the Pacific Crest and John Muir trails on the way to its destination. Like most park trails, the High Sierra Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Possible destinations include: The top photo shows a green meadow nestled between steep granite peaks and canyons. The caption reads, Bearpaw Meadow 11.3 miles (or 18.2 km) one way Elevation: 7,800 feet (or 2,377 m) This trail remains relatively level in most places as it skirts steep canyons and sheer cliffs on the 11 miles to Bearpaw Meadow. From the Bearpaw area, look deep into a wilderness of granite peaks and canyons. The next photo is of the historic Whitney Hut at the end of the trail on Mount Whitney. The caption reads, Mount Whitney 60 miles (or 97 km) one way Elevation: 14,494 feet (or 4,417 m) The High Sierra Trail tops the Great Western Divide at Kaweah Gap. It descends into the Kern Canyon, then climbs again to reach Mount Whitney, the tallest peak in the lower 48 states. The historic Whitney Hut marks the end of the trail. A map of the Giant Forest shows our location at the beginning of the High Sierra trail. The bottom photo is of a rocky valley and cliffs are sprinkled with patches of snow. The caption reads, View east from Kaweah Gap. A quote by Colonel John R. White, Park Superintendent and originator of the High Sierra Trail: "I know of no better [scenery] than that which...will be opened by this trail."

data.title: Hospital Rock Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: Picnic in an oak woodland near the Middle Fork of the Kaweah River. Numerous picnic areas offer both sunny and shady spots to eat and relax. While you're here, browse outdoor exhibits that tell the story of Native Americans who lived and traveled in this area, and continue to visit this area today.

images.altText: Two wooden picnic tables under the shade of a large tree.
images.title: Hospital Rock Picnic Area
images.caption: Hospital Rock is usually warm and dry throughout the year.

data.bodyText:
Picnic in an oak woodland near the Middle Fork of the Kaweah River. Numerous picnic areas offer both sunny and shady spots to eat and relax. While you're here, browse outdoor exhibits that tell the story of Native Americans who lived and traveled in this area, and continue to visit this area today.

The KNP Complex Fire: Topography and prescribed burning affect how future wildfires burn

During the 2021 KNP Complex Fire, this area burned at much lower severity than areas just a few miles to the south. Why?   

The terrain here played a role. The steep, north-facing cliffs across the river and the narrow canyon that has rocky outcrops created a fire break, or an area without trees and plants to burn. These cliffs also shelter the area from intense sun that dries vegetation. 

The history of prescribed burning by park firefighters also reduced fire severity here. Periodic burning of grasses and shrubs means there is less plant material for a wildfire to consume.
data.audioDescription: You are surrounded by groves of Canyon Live Oaks and Buckeyes. Uphill are ridgelines with fractured metamorphic rocks, sticking up out of the brush. You may be able to hear the river nearby. Near the parking area are trash cans, recycling bins, and bear storage containers. There is also a payphone. In the picnic area, some tables have barbeque pits adjacent. A bulletin board and six area orientation panel describing local American Indian cultural history. The panels are mounted in a frame made of thick wooden posts, with a shallow wood-shingled roof. The pictographs are located across the road, just opposite the upper entrance to this picnic area.

data.title: Hospital Rock Picnic Area Exhibits
data.listingDescription: This place was once a vibrant village inhabited by Native Americans. Learn more about their relationship with this area. Experience these exhibits, along with accompanying tactile and audio components, in person, or learn more below.

images.altText: Three free-standing, wood exhibit panels and a bulletin board are found on the picnic area sidewalk.
images.title: Hospital Rock Picnic Area exhibits
images.caption: Hospital Rock Picnic Area exhibits

data.bodyText:
Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks worked cooperatively with associated tribes to update exhibits at this picnic area. This place was once a vibrant village inhabited by Native Americans. Learn more about their relationship with this area. Experience these exhibits, along with accompanying tactile and audio components, in person, or learn more below.

A Shared Space Exhibit

The past, present, and future are alive here. Nature, people, and spirit share this space. Native Americans call this place Pah-din, which means place to go through. It is also known as Hospital Rock.

This spot along the Kaweah River supports a diverse mix of animals, plants, and trees. The richness of this landscape made it an ideal location for Pah-din, a village that was home to hundreds of California Native Americans. Today, it is still an important place for the descendants of the village, and a site where people of many backgrounds come to rest, play, and explore the natural world.The Hospital Rock area features hot, dry summers and cool, wet winters. Snow, ice, and water carved the surrounding hillsides and valley floor. In this place, several large granite boulders provided temporary shelter or space for tribal gatherings. The area namesake rock, Pah-din or Hospital Rock, is a massive 60 feet long and 20 feet wide. Like the landscape, the river is a life force. It is home to fish and insects, and sustains nearby plant life.

Keeping Traditions Alive-The Civilian Conservation Corps

In the 1930s, the Hospital Rock landscape changed dramatically. Assigned to Hospital Rock, the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) completed several landscaping and improvement projects. They also cut a new stone staircase leading to the pictograph, built the Big Pool Trail and tunnel, and built a historic vehicle water station. Many local Native Americans joined the Corps and contributed to its projects nationwide.

Connections between Land and People Exhibit

Native American groups lived, interacted, and traded goods in this village for generations. They continue to gather here as land stewards to practice their culture, educate, restore native plants, and for spiritual and special events.

Native Americans have a deep connection with the land. When Hospital Rock was an active village, the people cared for the plants and woodland ecosystem in ways that promoted health and abundance. From this practice, they were able to harvest materials necessary to live and thrive. Even today, these tribal cultural practices remain a way of life.Life here included fishing and gathering foods, cultivating the land, trading, playing games, visiting, andconnecting to one’s spiritual beliefs. The land provided everything needed to survive. People of the village harvested plants to build shelters, weave baskets, and create snares.Fire has always been part of this landscape. People living here depended on it for warmth and cooking. They also used it to clear vegetation to improve visibility and productivity in forests and grasslands.In this area, Native Americans hunted game, such as deer, squirrels, birds, and fished for food. Theyalso gathered plants, acorns, seeds, berries, and roots.

Keeping Traditions Alive-Homeland

“This is an ancient site, a sensitive site.... People took care of each other here. There’s a welcome feeling here...the medicine is strong.”A connection with the land is critical to North Fork Mono Tribal Chairman Ron Goode. “Everything out here is our relations.” Traditional Ecological Knowledge has been passed down for generations by his people, and children today have strong relationships with the land. This traditional knowledge guides their restoration of damaged meadows and waterways in the Sierra Nevada mountain range. This work benefits not only tribal lands, but also national forests and parks.

A Village Exhibit

In this area, the Mono (Monache), the Yokuts, and the Tubatulabal connected with their neighboring tribes to form a vibrant community. These connections continue today.

Many groups lived, visited, gathered, and practiced traditions here. Historical accounts document more than 500 people occupying this village. Travelers stopped at the village to visit, rest, or trade. Runners and messengers used the extensive trails to deliver news about events such as fires. Tribal leaders are responsible for the safety and welfare of their people, including welcoming outsiders, negotiating with neighboring groups, and maintaining peace.By the 1860s, Native Americans left the Hospital Rock area. New settlers forced many out of the area, while others died from newly introduced diseases.Today, Mono (Monache), Yokuts, and the Tubatulabal live all over the world. Some live on rancherias,  reservations, or other Indian lands. Their descendants maintain a strong connection to Pah-din (Hospital Rock) and often participate in park management decisions.

Keeping Traditions Alive-A True Leader

The descendants of Chief Chappo remember him as a strong leader who was compassionate, honest, and decisive—a peacemaker and a healer. Responsible for the welfare of his people, Chappo lived peacefully at Hospital Rock for generations. In the 1860’s, when new settlers arrived, they brought disease and conflict to the area. Chappo made the difficult decision to leave his homeland to save his people. Today, his descendants share stories about his gifts, and work to follow in his footsteps.

Activity, Past and Present Exhibit

Signs that Pah-din (Hospital Rock) was once a vibrant village are all around us. Pictographs, bedrock mortars, historic fire pits, and obsidian artifacts all tell a story of a way of life.

Imagine a time when a community of hundreds of people lived here. Picture a village with dwellings (called nobi by the Mono people), children playing, women preparing food, and men getting ready for a hunt. This location inspired a way of life and created traditions and practices that continue today.Village women processed acorns into a flour that was a staple food. They made depressions in flat bedrock to create grinding holes, or mortars, and used cylindrical stones as pestles.Redbud shrubs provide strong, flexible shoots that were split or kept whole to weave into baskets. Elderberry shrubs were used for food, cultural uses, medicine, or ceremonial use.Items such as beads and obsidian (volcanic glass) may be found here. If you find an artifact, help us by leaving it where it is. Take a photo, note the location, and report your finding to park staff.

Keeping Traditions Alive-The Weavers

“The materials that make up a Native basket serve to ground it to an area. The weaver’s culture governed the techniques used to make it and the designs that adorn it. And the voices of tribal elders whisper through it.”               - BRYN BARABAS POTTER

Weaving serves a practical purpose but is also an art. Nature not only provides materials but also inspires patterns. An active basket-making community continues to teach skills to the next generation of weavers.

Community Traditions Exhibit

What memorable traditions occur here, past and present? The Hospital Rock area has a rich history of people, events, and activities that shape it and create a sense of  community.

The granite rocks near the pictographs of Hospital Rock served many purposes such as a shelter, a place of healing, and a location for ceremonies. Native Americans call this place Pah-din, which means place to go through.Every Native American society has healers, who practice traditional medicine to aid ailing community members. On occasions, healers cared for injured travelers here. The English name “Hospital Rock” was first used in 1873 after a pioneer recovered here from a trapping injury.Spirituality was prominent in the form of reverence for the natural world. The land and its animals were respected. Creation stories were passed down within families.­Like the beat of drums, sounds from clapper sticks are an important part of cultural, spiritual, and ceremonial traditions. Clapper sticks are made from elderberry stalks.Today, families picnic together, share memories, swim in the Kaweah River, and hike in this spot.

Shared Voices Exhibit

What is your native language? From past to present, many languages have been spoken here, connecting people to this space and to one another.

In the past, California Native American groups lived, met, and gathered here. They spoke a number of languages and dialects to trade goods, share news, and cooperate with others. Today, these languages are still heard throughout the Sierra range and foothills. People can tell a lot about their neighbors based on the way they say “hello.” A person’s language communicates to others who they are, where they come from, and how they live.Historically, California Native Americans each had their own language. However, each group spoke many languages to connect with their neighbors and fellow travelers.Today, travelers from all over the world rest, picnic, and enjoy nature here, whether they call this place Hospital Rock or Pah-din. While you’re here, listen for people speaking a variety of languages.Nature also has a language. The rustling of oaks, chirping of birds, calls of squirrels, and the roaring river flowing over granite boulders form the essential sounds of this landscape.

Keeping Traditions Alive-Our Language Lives

Language is Marie Wilcox’s life. According to Marie, “words matter and learning the language is important to our culture.” Marie is one of the last living speakers of the Wukchumni language. With the help of her family, Marie created a Wukchumni dictionary. Containing thousands of words and examples of their uses, the dictionary documents the living language of her people. As part of a movement to preserve our nation’s Native American languages, Marie’s work documents the art and heritage of the Wukchumni voice.
data.audioDescription: After you exit the Hospital Rock Picnic Area parking lot, these exhibits are positioned at an angle along a sidewalk. Beyond the exhibits are restrooms, and the main picnic area. Before you are three, double-sided, wood-framed exhibit panels with shake shingle A-frame roofs. Each panel (two per exhibit) contains photographs and text related to the history and modern use of this area by Native Americans. Some panels have a watercolor illustration, painted by a local Native American artist, depicting historic Native American activity in this area. The exhibit also features quotations from local, living descendants of this area. One exhibit features an audio recording of two prominent Native American languages. Two tactile panels are also found on the exhibits; one features basket patterns and the other is an artist’s rendering of the pictographs at Hospital Rock. Full text of the panels is included in place description.

data.title: Hospital Rock Pictographs
data.listingDescription: Note, this is a sacred area, please be respectful. Hundreds of years ago, people who came here drew these pictographs. Their meaning is unknown, but local tribe members explain that they serve as a history for the people who once lived here and area a reminder of how important this place is to them today.

images.altText: A rock with pictographs called Hospital Rock is found on an oak-covered path.
images.title: Hospital Rock
images.caption: Hospital Rock

data.bodyText:
Note, this is a sacred area, please be respectful.

By working with local Native Americans, we've learned the pictographs at Hospital Rock are sacred to their communities. They are part of their traditional belief systems, and as important as any place of worship. Do not touch or mark on the pictographs or rocks here. If you see someone vandalizing this area, please let a park ranger know right away.

Hundreds of years ago, people who came here drew these pictographs. Their meaning is unknown, but local tribal members explain that they serve as a history for the people who once lived here, and are a reminder of how important this place is to them today.

This area once hosted a village of hundreds of people from the Mono (Monache), Yokuts, and the Tubatulabal tribes. The tribes who once lived here are no longer in the park, but they live in nearby communities and actively continue to honor past traditions. 

Safety and Accessibility

The area around the pictographs, while flat, is bound by two roads—beware of traffic approaching with limited visibility. Access to the pictographs viewing platform is via a set of short, steep stairs. For those with limited mobility, the pictograph can be seen from the parking lot across the street with binoculars. The Hospital Rock Picnic Area across the street from this features offers many services, including parking, restrooms, and trash/recycling bins.
data.audioDescription:
About 20 yards from the road is a large gray granite boulder, about 25 feet high by as much as 100 feet wide. An upright, naturally flat surface on the rock, like a wall, starts about 6 feet above the ground and rises up to 15 feet. It is about 20 feet wide. On the top are vibrant red paintings of figures and shapes, with paint streaks running down the rock that obscure other painted figures and shapes below them.

Known as pictographs, these images include what appear to be:

Human stick figures, including one with about twenty small lines radiating out from its head.
Several parallel lines, some wavy and some curving.
A couple of starburst images with 10 lines radiating out from a central point.
Bird shapes with curved wings and tails.
A snake.
A tree-shaped outline, with five branches on either side of the trunk.
And several other geometric shapes, often with parallel lines radiating out at an angle from a straight line, like multiple arrows.

People can approach, but not touch, the pictographs. The uneven path that climbs slightly from the road up to the pictographs is made of paving stones, dirt, and a few stairs. Immediately in front of the pictographs is a set of about 10 rough-carved stone stairs, allowing people to get a closer look at the images. Caution is advised, as the stairs are narrow and uneven.

A carved wood sign with embossed white letters reads,

Hospital rock

Safety information text is shown in English and Spanish, but for this audio description we will only read the English.

It reads,

Please Be Aware

Welcome to Hospital Rock, a sacred site for local California Indian tribes whose ancestors lived and died here. Please be considerate of the sensitive area by staying on the trail, not touching the pictographs, and behaving respectfully.

Archaeological and historic sites like these are unique and irreplaceable. Please cooperate with the laws that protect them. Thank you.

Walk in a good way on Mother Earth.

data.title: Hospital Rock River Trailhead
data.listingDescription: A short steep downhill climb will lead you to the Kaweah River, which is one of the most scenic spots in all of the foothill region of the park.

images.altText: partially paved trail heading into the woods
images.title: Hospital Rock River Trailhead
images.caption: Be careful near the river, even dry rocks can be slippery.

data.bodyText:
A short steep downhill climb will lead you to the Kaweah River, which is one of the most scenic spots in all of the foothill region of the park. The water can be dramatic especially during spring and early summer when the snow is melting.

Safety 

Be careful if you head to the river. Even when the water seems calm the current beneath the surface can be flowing swiftly. Drowning is the most common cause of death in Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks. People sometimes slip and fall in, then find it impossible to get back out.

Near the parking area are trash cans, recycling bins, and bear storage containers. There is also a payphone.
In the picnic area, some tables have barbeque pits adjacent.


A bulletin board and six area orientation panel describing local American Indian cultural history. The panels are mounted in a frame made of thick wooden posts, with a shallow wood-shingled roof.

The pictographs are located across the road, just opposite the upper entrance to this picnic area.

data.title: Hot Spots
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Hot Spots," shows how fire helps trees grow.

images.altText: Outdoor exhibit in front of the base of a sequoia tree.
images.title: Hot Spots
images.caption: Sequoia trees need fire to reproduce.

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Hot Spots," shows how fire helps giant sequoias grow.
data.audioDescription:
The View: To your left are the grasses of Round Meadow and to your right are the sequoias of Giant Forest. There is a giant sequoia a few feet ahead of you along this trail, on the right side. The bark of the trunk is deeply furrowed. A few boulders lie nearby. The ground around it is covered with dried leaves, but no plants.

On the top corners of the frame of this wayside exhibit are tactile brass sequoia cones, about the size of an egg, with a small twig attached to each.

A photo of four large sequoias with a low fire burning around their base. Smoke billows through the forest around them.

The caption reads,

As fire moves through the forest, it creates ideal conditions for sequoia seeds to sprout-bare ground fertilized by ash. It also kills soil fungus that may harm seedlings.

The text reads,

Hot Spots

The four large sequoias that you see here are probably the same age. Such clusters may be found where fire once burned very hot. Most fires in this area are low ground fires, not hot enough to kill many big trees.

Where fire does flare up enough to kill a patch of trees, seedlings get a good start. No trees block their sunlight or compete for water and nutrients. A thousand years later, a group of giants may stand in what was once a hot spot.

A photo of two hands. One is open with a bunch of tiny seeds, about the size of oat flakes, in the palm. The other hand holds two sequoia cones, each the size of a small egg.

The caption reads,

Sequoia cones open when fire's heat rises. Soon tiny seeds drop to the ground. If they fall onto a layer of dry leaves, they will not survive. On soil left bare by fire, they can take root.

quickFacts.value: Along Big Trees Trail, Giant Forest
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Hotel Creek Trailhead
data.listingDescription: The 6.9 mile (11.1 KM) loop Hotel Creek Trail has a steep incline. The trail was iburned over during the 2015 Rough Fire but is recovering. It climbs through a ponderosa pine forest to views of Monarch Divide and other peaks. Parking is limited at the trailhead. Alternative parking is available at Cedar Grove Lodge, which adds 0.5 miles (0.8 km) to the trip.

images.altText: Trail through trees with burnt trunks with a trailhead sign in front
images.title: Hotel Creek Trailhead
images.caption: Recent fires are evident at the start of Hotel Creek

data.bodyText: The 6.9-mile (11.1 km) loop Hotel Creek Trail has a steep incline. The trail was burned over during the 2015 Rough Fire but is recovering. It climbs through a ponderosa pine forest to views of Monarch Divide and other peaks. Parking is limited at the trailhead. Alternative parking is available at Cedar Grove Lodge, which adds 0.5 miles (0.8 km) to the trip.
data.audioDescription: The text reads, Hotel Creek trailhead Switchbacks along this steep route leave from the canyon floor and up toward the Monarch Divide. After 1.9 miles, turn left at the trail junction to go to Cedar Grove Overlook, or stay to the right to join the Lewis Creek Trail and continue climbing. Like most park trails, Hotel Creek Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. A photo of steep tree covered mountain sides with a canyon below. The caption reads, Cedar Grove Overlook. 2.3 miles (or 3.7 km) one way. Elevation: 6086 feet (or 1855 m). Once the overlook trail splits from the steep Hotel Creek Trail, it levels out. The overlook offers wide views of the glacially carved Kings Canyon. A photo shows a sunlit meadow among conifer trees. The caption reads, Frypan Meadow. 7.6 miles (or 12.3 km) one way. Elevation: 7,840 feet (or 2390 m). A network of trails meets at this meadow. To the west lies Sequoia National Forest and, to the north, Kennedy Pass leads to the Middle Fork of the Kings River. A map shows the location of the Hotel Creek Trailhead. The bottom photo shows a stretch of rounded rocky mountain peaks with conifer trees on the lower slopes. The caption reads, A view of Monarch Divide from Lookout Peak. A quote by Helen Cathey, "All immensities, whether mountain or crises, are overcome by merely taking one step at a time."

data.title: How's the View?
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "How's the View?," shows the weather patterns that cause pollution in the valley.

images.altText: Outdoor exhibit with hazy mountains in the distance.
images.title: How's the View
images.caption: Air pollution is a prominent and pressing issue in these parks.

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "How's the View?," shows the weather patterns that cause pollution in the valley.
data.audioDescription:
The View: In front of you is a series of broad, domed rock surfaces with a forested area on either side. Beyond the rocks is an open view of forested hills. Layer after layer of hills descend into the distance, only visible on clear days.

The text on the panel reads,

How's the View?

You are looking west toward the San Joaquin Valley, a fertile basin that stretches to the Coast Ranges, 100 miles away. Can you see the mountains of the Coast Ranges today?

Wind and weather patterns cause pollutants to pool in the southern San Joaquin Valley. The problem occurs all year, but is especially bad in summer. A dark haze often blocks the view for days or even weeks.

In national parks people expect grand vistas, but in too many parks air pollution increasingly mars the view. You can help prevent smog darkened scenery. Conserve electricity, recycle, reduce your use of cars and gas-powered engines, and support clean air policies.

A photo of the view before you, the sky has a yellowish tint that hangs above the mountain range.

The caption reads,

Even on the"clear day" when this photo was taken, a haze obscures distant features. The best visibility typically occurs in winter. The worst, in summer.

Arrows point to the position of the Coast Range that is not visible in this photo, due to smog.

Two photos of the same view. The first, haze blocks all but one ridgeline. In the second, we see more layers of ridgelines in the distance.

The caption reads,

To See or Not to See?

A polluted summer day and a clear spring day, photographed a short distance from here.

A black and white illustration showing a topographic map of part of the state of California. The air flow pattern enters the San Francisco Bay area and then splits and curves north and south. The northern flow continues over the Sacramento Valley with two small branches flowing right and left. A longer flow pattern curves southward into the San Joaquin Valley, with branches to the Sierra Nevada mountains and the Coast Range. The flow dead ends at the southern end of the valley, and loops back to the north, like a hook. The illustration shows our location, in the Sierra Nevada mountains, near this dead-end loop.

The text reads,

Pollution's Path

As air flows through the San Joaquin Valley, it picks up urban and agricultural pollutants, including ozone. The southern end has the second worst ozone pollution in the country.

Polluted air is trapped in the valley. It collects in the southern end near Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks. During summer days, as the air warms, pollution rises into the parks.

images.altText: A forested campsite
