data.bodyText:
Hume Lake Campground is within the Sequoia National Forest, and within minutes walking distance from Hume Lake. Hume Lake is a popular destination year-round, with a full range of recreational activity.

The campground is typically open mid-May to mid-September. It has 74 sites open to tents, trailers, and RVs. Reservations are recommended. There are services available nearby at Hume Lake Village.

Please consult the USFS on facility availability- https://www.fs.usda.gov/activity/sequoia/recreation/camping-cabins/?recid=79563&actid=29

quickFacts.value: West side of Hume Lake, off Hume Lake Road

data.title: Hume Lake Village
data.listingDescription: Hume Lake Village and Camp is on national forest land on the shore of a small, man-made lake open to hiking, boating, and fishing. While some services are only available to Hume Lake Camp guests, a gas station, general store with gifts, cafe, and picnic area are available to the public.

images.altText: A rustic building with a Snack Shop sign
images.caption: The Snack Shop at Hume Lake offers casual dining and ice cream. Photo by Kiel Maddox.

data.bodyText:
Hume Lake Village and Camp is on national forest land on the shore of a small, man-made lake open to hiking, boating, and fishing. While some services are only available to Hume Lake Camp guests, a gas station, general store with gifts, cafe, and picnic area are available to the public. Created in 1908, this lake stored logs for the timber industry and provided water for a flume that floated timber down to the San Joaquin Valley. A 2.6-mile, easy trail loops around the lake, offering interpretive signs and benches along the way.

Services Nearby

A store, restaurants, restrooms, water, gasoline, picnicking, camping, and pay telephones are available.

data.title: Inheritance
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Inheritance," shows why fallen trees create good conditions for sequoias to thrive.

images.altText: Outdoor Exhibit with a fallen sequoia tree behind it.
images.title: Inheritance
images.caption: When sequoia trees fall they create good conditions for new sequoia trees to sprout.

data.bodyText: This outdoor exhibit, titled "Inheritance," shows why fallen trees create good conditions for sequoias to thrive.
data.audioDescription:
The View: To your left are the grasses of Round Meadow and to your right are the sequoias of Giant Forest. About twenty feet ahead of you, on the left side of the trail, is a giant sequoia that has fallen into the meadow on the left. Its exposed root ball is twenty feet tall, facing the path. Large branches lay near the trunk.

On the panel, a background photo, taken from the meadow, shows a dense line of giant sequoia trees against a dark sky.

The text reads,

Inheritance

This fallen giant grew too heavy for the soft, wet soil at the meadow's edge. When it fell, however, its broken roots exposed bare soil in a sunny spot with plenty of moisture. Those were the perfect conditions for the sequoia directly across the trail to get started.

Natural disturbances, such as falling trees and fire, contribute to good sequoia habitat.

A photo of a giant sequoia that has fallen. The root ball is exposed and broken branches are still attached to the trunk. Tall sequoias surround it.

The caption reads,

The fallen sequoia in this photo tore a hole in the canopy, letting in needed sunlight. But until a fire burns away the broken tree and exposes the ground, sequoia seeds could never sprout.

Sometimes it takes two forms of disturbance before sequoias can regenerate.

data.title: Into the Giant Forest
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Into the Giant Forest," shows a photo of the Giant Forest and a map of the Giant Forest Trail system.

images.altText: a metal sign is just off the side of the trail with trees in the background.
images.title: Into the Giant Forest
images.caption: Welcome to the Giant Forest

data.bodyText: This outdoor exhibit, titled "Into the Giant Forest," shows a photo of the Giant Forest and a map of the Giant Forest Trail system.
data.audioDescription: The View: You are descending into a thick forest of sequoias. Through the upper canopy of leaves, you can see glimpses of more distant trees and some bare branches, called "snags", that stick up from the tops of some sequoias. These gnarled tree tops create a twisted sculpture amongst the thick green curtain above. The text reads, You are standing on the edge of the Giant Forest sequoia grove. Sequoia trees grow in front of you but not behind you. Based on the huge size of so many sequoias here, the Giant Forest appears to provide the best habitat anywhere for sequoias to grow. John Muir, famous Scottish- American naturalist, described entering this grove in 1873: "A magnificent growth of giants... one naturally walked softly and awe - stricken among them. I wandered on, meeting nobler trees where all are noble... this part of the Sequoia belt seemed to me the finest, and then I then named it," the Giant Forest."" A photo of the top of a giant sequoia tree. The highest part of the trunk and two or three branches are bare, stubby, and worn down. The caption reads, Look closely and you might see this bare snag top. It is the tip of the 275 - foot - tall General Sherman Tree (84 m), just visible through the smaller trees. A map of the Giant Forest Trail system. The text reads, Within the Giant Forest stands scores of huge sequoia trees. This map- which illustrates the Giant Forest's trail system-highlights several of the large sequoias, including the General Sherman Tree, the biggest tree on Earth. The Giant Forest covers three square miles. It is the second largest sequoia grove in both area and number of sequoia trees. You can visit the Giant Forest via 40 miles of trail. Many of these paths are relatively flat and easy to walk. The map includes location the following trees, top to bottom: Adams tree. Lincoln tree. Chief Sequoyah. The President. Pershing Tree. Column Tree. General Sherman Tree, the largest tree by volume 52,000 cubic feet. The map also says that, The General Grant Tree, one of the largest sequoias, is in Grant Grove, a one-hour drive from here.

data.title: John Muir Lodge
data.listingDescription: Open year-round, this lodge offers hotel rooms and cabins. Nearby, food is available at the Grant Grove Restaurant and Grant Grove Market. Other services in the village include a post office, gift shop, and Kings Canyon Visitor Center.

images.altText: A large brown building sits nestled between tall trees. In front of it are green bushes.
images.title: John Muir Lodge
images.caption: John Muir Lodge

data.bodyText:
This lodge offers hotel rooms and cabins. Nearby, food is available at the Grant Grove Restaurant and Grant Grove Market. Other services in the village include a post office, gift shop, and Kings Canyon Visitor Center.

John Muir Lodge is an excellent starting point for exploring the Grant Grove sequoia grove, including the General Grant Tree. Panoramic Point Trail is also nearby, and offers views deep into the wilderness of Kings Canyon National Park.

Information about availability of overnight accomodations can be found at John Muir Lodge's webpage.

data.title: Junction View
data.listingDescription: The Junction View Scenic Overlook is located along Highway 180, the Kings Canyon Scenic Byway. This wayside exhibit, titled "The Kings Canyon: A Wonderland of Unique Geology," shows photos and text about the geology of the canyon in view.

images.altText: Metal sign labeling the mountain peaks in the background
images.title: Junction View
images.caption: Junction View Overlook

data.bodyText: The Junction View Scenic Overlook is located along Highway 180, the Kings Canyon Scenic Byway. This wayside exhibit, titled "The Kings Canyon: A Wonderland of Unique Geology," shows photos and text about the geology of the canyon in view.
data.audioDescription:
The View: This overlook has views down to the junction of the Middle and the South Fork of the Kings River far below us, with mountain peaks in the distance, sometimes covered with snow. Looking down from the overlook, the Middle Fork of the Kings River is on the left, and the South Fork is on the right. Because we are looking up the canyon toward the headwaters, both rivers flow toward us. Scrubby plants and deciduous bushes grow nearby, and below. The mountaintops are covered with conifers.

The exhibit shows an illustration of the same view, with snowcapped peaks in the distance. The Middle Fork of the Kings River carves through a V-shaped canyon. Most of the south fork canyon is obscured by hills.

The distant peaks and other features on the illustration are labeled. In the foreground, to the left of the Middle Fork of the river are:

Deer Ridge.

Deer Canyon.

Brush Canyon.

Tombstone Ridge.

Little Tehipite Valley.

In between the middle and south fork are:

Junction Ridge.

And Eagle Peaks.

The distant ridges and peaks, going from left to right, are:

Rodger's Ridge.

Spanish Mountain.
10,051 feet.

Crown Rock.
9,342 feet.

Obelisk.
9,700 feet.

Silver Spur.

Mt. Harrington.
11,008 feet.

Grand Dike (7 sisters).

And University Peak.
13,632 feet.

The text reads,

It took many years for geologic processes to shape the canyon before you. A photo of very steep jagged cliffs with a rounded ridge below, covered with low shrubs.

The caption reads,

Water and Sediment

The middle and south forks of the Kings River steadily scour and reshape this canyon, one of the deepest in North America. However, this was a shallow sea in the early Jurassic period where plants and animals were buried in the sand.

A photo shows a steep cliff side with zigzagging layers of white, brown and gray rock.

The caption reads,

Heat and Lifting

A volcanic wave at the edge of the continental plate lifted this prehistoric sea floor. Squeezed, melted, and twisted, the layers of marine sediment became marble and other metamorphic rock. Magma pushed upward, solidifying into granite domes.

A photo shows a cave with a wall made of many layers of stalactites suspended from the roof of the cave, like icicles.

The text reads,

Erosion

Glaciers scraped away sedimentary and metamorphic rock, and polished the granite domes over 15,000 years ago. As the glaciers retreated, water and wind erode the canyon walls forming caves.

Additional text reads,

In partnership with Fresno County Resource Advisory Committee, the National Park Service, and Miramonte Conservation Camp Crew 2.

Logos for Giant Sequoia National Monument and Sequoia National Forest are at the bottom right.

data.title: Just Enough Soil
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Just Enough Soil," shows why sequoias have shallow roots.

images.altText: Outdoor exhibit with young sequoia trees behind it.
images.title: Just Enough Soil
images.caption: Sequoias have shallow roots

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Just Enough Soil," shows why sequoias have shallow roots.
data.audioDescription:
The View: To your left are the grasses of Round Meadow and to your right are the sequoias of Giant Forest. The exhibit faces some sequoia trees, and some fallen branches.

On the panel, a background photo, taken from the meadow, shows a dense line of giant sequoias against a dark sky. An illustration, layered on top of the photo shows a giant sequoia on the right side, and a section cut away along the very bottom to reveal what lies under the ground. A thin layer of long, shallow roots extends from the base of the trunk all the way across the panel. They lie on top of a layer of bedrock at the very bottom of the illustration.

The caption reads,

The soil just needs to be deep enough to hold plenty of moisture for these thirsty trees.

The text reads,

Just Enough Soil

Bedrock is very close to the surface here. Just a thin layer of soil covers the granite. That can make it tough on some trees. Sequoias, however, do well in this environment. Their shallow roots can support a giant tree in less than three feet (or 1 m) of earth by spreading out far from the tree. Interlocking roots throughout the forest help to support the sequoias.

data.title: Kings Canyon Overlook
data.listingDescription: This overlook is located along the Generals Highway, south of Grant Grove. Thousands of acres of wilderness peaks and canyons lie before you. The forces of plate tectonics pushed these mountains up, then water and ice carved canyons deep into them. Thousands of species of plants and animals populate this wild landscape. For a different view out over this area, visit Panoramic Point in Grant Grove.

images.altText: A metal panel sits in a rock frame. Behind it are many trees
images.title: Kings Canyon Overlook
images.caption: Kings Canyon Overlook

data.bodyText:
This overlook is located along the Generals Highway, south of Grant Grove. Thousands of acres of wilderness peaks and canyons lie before you. The forces of plate tectonics pushed these mountains up, then water and ice carved canyons deep into them. Thousands of species of plants and animals populate this wild landscape. For a different view out over this area, visit Panoramic Point in Grant Grove.

Safety

Be very careful pulling into and out of this overlook; vehicles move quickly along this stretch of highway and visibility is limited.
data.audioDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Meeting the Wilderness Mission: Protecting Wilderness", with a photo and text, shows the importance of protecting Kings Canyon. A photo shows the view in front of you, looking out over miles of canyons, covered with conifer trees. A snowcapped mountain range is seen in the distance. The five mountain peaks that are identified along the horizon are: Spanish Mountain in the center of the ridge, and, to the right edge, Tombstone Ridge, Mount Reinstein, Mount Goddard, and Kettle Dome. The text reads, One of the largest areas of wilderness in the lower 48 states lies before you. This expanse of the Sierra Nevada spans both national forest and national park lands. Wilderness provides us increasingly rare, far reaching benefits: adventure, inspiration, scenery, wildlife habitat, clean water, scientific discovery...What might it hold in store for you or your children? A quote by Wallace Stegner in 1960 reads, We simply need that wild country available to us, even if we never do more than drive to its edge and look in. For it can be means of reassuring ourselves of our sanity as creatures, a part of the geography of hope. Additional text reads, Help the park fulfill its mission Protect scenery, natural and historic objects, and wildlife. Enjoy them in ways that leave the parks unimpaired for future generations. In the upper right corner, near the mission text are logos for the Forest Service and the National Park Service. The U.S. Forest Service Department of Agriculture logo is in the shape of a badge. The badge has a concave top with squared off top corners and oval base that comes to a point at the bottom center. It is outlined in yellow with a green center. Inside the badge are words in yellow lettering. "Forest Service" is on the top and "Department of Agriculture" is on the bottom. In the center, are the letters "U" and "S", with a yellow conifer tree in between them. The National Park Service logo is in the shape of an orange arrowhead, pointed downward. Inside the arrowhead are the words in white lettering, "National Park Service" with a green sequoia tree shape to its left. Near the bottom of the arrowhead is a white buffalo silhouette set against a green meadow, with a white lake and snow capped mountain behind it.

data.title: Knapp's Cabin
data.listingDescription: A wealthy businessman from Santa Barbara, George O. Knapp traveled here regularly with guests for fishing and camping expeditions. In 1925, he had this cabin built to store equipment for these lavish trips. In 1978, it was added to the National Register of Historic Places. Glacial ViewsIt's easy to see why Knapp built the cabin here.

images.altText: The inside of Knapp's Cabin with exposed wood beams and wood walls
images.title: Knapp's Cabin
images.caption: The inside of Knapp's Cabin

data.bodyText:
A wealthy businessman from Santa Barbara, George O. Knapp traveled here regularly with guests for fishing and camping expeditions. In 1925, he had this cabin built to store equipment for these lavish trips. In 1978, it was added to the National Register of Historic Places.
 

Glacial Views

It's easy to see why Knapp built the cabin here. It's situated on top of one of the many moraines along the canyon floor. These piles of glacial rubble are higher than the canyon floor, and views from the cabin are spectacular. Look closely to see horizontal scars along the canyon's granite walls; these were scratched by large rocks frozen fast in glacial ice as it slid slowly downslope thousands of years ago.
data.audioDescription: You are in an area of rocky boulders with low shrubs. Small pine and cedar trees are scattered sparsely across the landscape. A small, one room, wooden cabin is at the end of a short dirt trail. A steep granite mountain range is seen from the cabin. A horseshoe shaped river is nearby. A rectangular wooden sign carved with white embossed lettering reads, Knapp's Cabin A metal plaque attached to the sign reads, George O. Knapp, a wealthy California businessman, conducted several elaborate summer camping trips to this region of the Sierra. This cabin was built during the "Roaring Twenties" as a storage shed for those expeditions. It is the oldest building in Cedar Grove. Knapp's Cabin is about 10 feet by 20 feet. The outer walls and peaked roof are covered with overlapping layers of wooden shingles. On the north end of the building, the roof extends three feet to form an overhang: a porch with a dirt floor. The cabin has a wood door on each end. The doors are made of three vertical planks of wood, secured by three thinner planks mounted in a "Z" shape on the interior of the door. The doors are fastened in an open position and you may enter the cabin. Inside, the cabin frame is visible. It is built out of peeled log poles, with a few squared off in a roughhewn rectangular shape. The cabin has no windows and a dirt floor. There are several granite boulders near the cabin. One is just to the right of the south entrance, another midway along the east wall and several just beyond the porch area at the back of the cabin.

data.title: Ladybug Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This 4.2 mile (6.8 km) one-way trail, or 8.4 mile (13.5 km) out and back, is a moderate climb. After traveling through forests and passing over creeks, the path reaches Ladybug Camp, where ladybugs can be found during cooler months. The route then narrows and heads uphill to giant sequoias and Whiskey Log Camp.

images.altText: A misty mountain view with trees in the foreground
images.caption: A view from the Ladybug Trail. Photo by Lisa Silva.

data.bodyText:
The trailhead for this trail is currently inaccessible by vehicle (see Road Conditions below). The trailhead sign was damaged during heavy winter storms of 2022-2023. Anyone wishing to travel the trail should be self-reliant and expect significant flood and landslide damage, including sections of trail that are completely gone near all drainages.

This 4.2 mile (6.8 km) one-way trail, or 8.4 mile (13.5 km) out and back, is a moderate climb. After traveling through forests and passing over creeks, the path reaches Ladybug Camp, where ladybugs can be found during cooler months. The route then narrows and heads uphill to giant sequoias and Whiskey Log Camp.

This area is known for excellent fishing, secluded camping, and lower elevations where snow melts earlier in spring than in other areas of the park. Beware of the rough road that leads here from Three Rivers. If you encounter ladybugs, please take care to not hurt them as you explore.

Road Conditions

The South Fork Road is currently impassable within the national park due to extensive, heavy damage from flooding and landslides during winter storms in 2022-2023. No trailhead parking is available. When the road was open, it was a very rugged, backcountry road. Many sections of the road are one-lane with limited visibility. There are also stretches with steep drop-offs and no shoulder. High clearance vehicles are recommended.
data.audioDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the South Fork area. The text reads, "Two trails from this secluded area lead to low-elevation sequoia groves. One of these, Garfield Grove, formed the heart of the original 1890 Sequoia National Park. Only later was the park enlarged to include other groves and, later still, the high peaks. Like most park trails, these lead into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience." A map shows the location of the South Fork Trail. A photo shows a creek cascading through a bank of large rocks, surrounded by trees. The caption reads, "Ladybug Trail. 4.2 miles (or 6.8 km) one way. This relatively easy trail begins at the end of the parking area and ends at Whiskey Log Camp in the South Fork sequoia grove. As you hike, look along the ridge to the north for views of Homer's Nose, a prominent granite dome. The first permitted camping spot on this trail is Ladybug Camp (1.7 miles, or 2.7 km). A photo shows a row of large reddish-brown sequoia trunks in a lush grove. The caption reads, Garfield Grove Trail. 2.9 miles (or 4.7 km) one way to first sequoias. This trail begins along the road, just before the parking area. It climbs across north facing slopes into Garfield Grove, one of the largest sequoia groves in this park. The first permitted camping is at Snowslide Creek (3.6 miles or 5.8 km). Beyond Garfield Grove, the trail levels out as it approaches Hockett Meadow, 11.1 miles (or 17.9 km) from here. A quote by Joseph Wood Krutch, "The idea of wilderness is one of the permanent homes of the human spirit." A bottom photo shows tree covered mountains with a granite peak with traces of snow in the distance. The caption reads, "A view from Ladybug Trail."

data.title: Lakes Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Lakes Trail area. The 6 mile one-way Lakes Trail is a moderately strenuous climb up through meadows and forests, along granite cliff overlooks, and to several lakes. Heather and Aster lakes are closed to overnight use. Camping is available five miles from the trailhead at Emerald Lake and at the end of the trail, six miles from the trailhead, at Pear Lake.

images.altText: Dirt steps lead up to a metal sign beyond it are large trees
images.title: Lakes Trailhead
images.caption: The trailhead sign for the Lakes Trail

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Lakes Trail area.

The 6 mile one-way Lakes Trail is a moderately strenuous climb up through meadows and forests, along granite cliff overlooks, and to several lakes. Heather and Aster lakes are closed to overnight use. Camping is available five miles from the trailhead at Emerald Lake and at the end of the trail, six miles from the trailhead, at Pear Lake.
data.audioDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Wolverton Trailhead area. The text reads, The Lakes Trail leads to the Watchtower, a rocky outcrop 3.2 miles (or 5.1 km) from here. It offers spectacular views down into Tokopah Valley and up into the Tablelands. If you continue onward, icy lakes and granite peaks await. Like most park trails, these lead into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Possible destinations include: A photo of a reflective lake surrounded by rock covered granite slopes and scattered conifer trees. The caption reads, Heather, Emerald, and Pear Lakes Heather Lake lies closest, 4.1 miles (or 6.6 km) from here. For a longer dayhike or overnight trip, continue to Emerald, shown in the photo above, (5.3 miles or 8.5 km one way) or Pear Lake (6.2 miles or 10.0 km one way). When the Watchtower route closes (late fall through early summer), take the Hump route. Never use the Watchtower route when it is icy. A photo shows a dramatic view of rocky granite peaks with a jagged mountain range dappled with snow. The caption reads, Alta Peak. 7.0 miles (or 10.8 km) one way. Elevation: 11,204 feet (or 3,415 m). It is one of the easier High Sierra peaks to climb, but Alta's elevation can still slow you down. Consider visiting Alta Meadow, where wildflowers and trees provide a gentle contrast to the granite crags above. A map shows the location of the Wolverton Trailhead. A photo of a reflective lake nestled in a valley of granite slopes dusted with snow, with a few conifer trees. The caption reads, Emerald Lake in spring A quote by Dr. Seuss, "Today is your day! Your mountain is waiting."

data.title: Landslide Campground
data.listingDescription:
Please consult the USFS on facility availability- https://www.fs.usda.gov/activity/sequoia/recreation/camping-cabins/?recid=79563&actid=29

Landslide Campground is within the Sequoia National Forest, 12 miles from the Grant Grove Visitor Center. At 5800-foot elevation, the campground is within the designated Giant Sequoia National Monument, with hiking in two nearby groves of giant sequoias. Sites are available on a first-come, first-served basis.

images.altText: The US Forest Service campground sign
images.caption: The entrance of this national forest campground. Photo by Kiel Maddox.

At 5800-foot elevation, the campground is within the designated Giant Sequoia National Monument, with hiking in two nearby groves of giant sequoias. When open, sites are available on a first-come, first-served basis.

data.title: Lewis Creek Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Lewis Creek Trail area.

images.altText: The map and trail info is on a blue trail sign.
images.title: Lewis Creek Trailhead
images.caption: Watch for signs of previous fire and regrowth.

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Lewis Creek Trail area.

Lewis Creek Trail is a 9.8 miles one-way trail at a difficult incline. This can be a hot and dusty climb, and the trail becomes difficult to follow north of Kennedy Pass. The trail offers a wide variety of terrain, with forests, lakes, and meadows. The first campsite along the trail is 5.5 miles from the trailhead, at Frypan Meadow.
data.audioDescription:
The text reads,

This trail climbs steeply along a long series of switchbacks, then gradually becomes less steep. Trails to the west of Frypan Meadow lead out of the park and into the US Forest Service's Monarch Wilderness.

Like most park trails, Lewis Creek Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience.

A photo shows a sunlit meadow among conifer trees.

The caption reads,

Frypan Meadow.
6.2 miles (or 10.0 km) one way.
Elevation: 7840 feet (or 2,390 m).

A network of trails meets at the meadow. To the west lies Sequoia National Forest and, to the north, Kennedy Pass leads to the Middle Fork of the Kings River.

A photo shows a rocky mountain ridge dotted with conifer trees and patches of snow. A reflective lake is seen in a shallow valley.

The caption reads,

Kennedy Pass.
10.5 miles (or 16.9 km) one way.
Elevation: 10,820 feet (or 3,298 m.)

The hike to this pass, which lies on the divide between the Middle and South forks of the Kings River, gains more elevation than a hike out of the Grand Canyon. Forests dominate this side of the pass, while the vast expanse of granite, dotted with alpine lakes, lies on the opposite side.

A map shows the location of the Lewis Creek Trailhead.

The bottom photo shows a stretch of rounded mountain peaks with conifer trees on the lower slopes.


The caption reads,

A view of Monarch Divide from Lookout Peak.

A quote by Gaston RebuffÃ t,

"What a strange encounter then is that between man and the high places of his planet!"

quickFacts.value: Along Highway 180 (Kings Canyon Scenic Byway), near Sheep Creek Campground
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Life After Death
data.listingDescription: Tannin, a chemical in the wood and bark of sequoias, slows down the decay process. A surprising benefit: Trees long dead still preserve their growth rings, which scientists can study for insight into past climate and weather patterns. This wayside exhibit, titled "Life After Death", shows a black and white photo with text about the fallen sequoia tree in front of you.

images.altText: Exhibit with an old photo of a large log. The same log is in the background, and looks very similar.
images.title: Life After Death
images.caption: This outdoor exhibit shows the same scene over a century ago.

data.bodyText:
Tannin, a chemical in the wood and bark of sequoias, slows down the decay process. A surprising benefit: Trees long dead still preserve their growth rings, which scientists can study for insight into past climate and weather patterns.

This wayside exhibit, titled "Life After Death", shows a black and white photo with text about the fallen sequoia tree in front of you.
data.audioDescription: The View: About 10 feet to the left of this wayside is the root end of a fallen sequoia tree. It is hollow. You can walk down uneven, dirt steps into the hollow center, and then continue down the hollowed-out trunk. The opening is about 5 feet high, so watch your head! The roots of the tree stretch up around the opening about 15 feet. As you reach the trunk portion, the hollow tunnel is about 6 feet across, and you can feel the trunk above your head and on either side. There are trip hazards along the way. Columns have been installed along the way to reinforce the trunk for safety. You can go about 50 feet through the trunk before it connects to the other side of the loop trail. On the wayside exhibit, a photo shows seventeen men posing by the fallen tree before you. There are wooden bedframes in the hollowed-out area. Deer heads with antlers are mounted to the trunk above the opening. In the background is a crudely made wooden table that seems to be set with plates and food. Two taller tables are covered with bottles and boxes. The men wear trousers and shirts, and most also wear a hat and either a vest or a jacket. Other details, from left to right include: a man with dark hair and a moustache holds the barrel of a rifle propped up on the ground at his left. A man holding a violin on his shoulder stroking it with its bow. A man next to him is holding a guitar. A group of men are in two rows. Seven, in front, are seated on various objects, a rough wooden bench, an upright wooden crate, a barrel, a tree stump and a fallen tree trunk. One man holds a cane. The back row shows six men standing. A man in uniform is mounted on horseback to the right. The caption reads, Like the Gamlin Cabin on this trail, the Fallen Monarch sheltered some of the park's early visitors. Construction crews such as this one camped here, sleeping in beds inside the hollow log. The cavalry kept their horses in it (note the mounted cavalryman in this photograph). The text reads, Even after they fall, sequoias endure. These trees resist decay, sometimes lasting for hundreds or even thousands of years on the forest floor. Compare the Fallen Monarch in front of you with this photograph from 1900. It looks nearly the same today as it did over a century ago.

data.title: Life in the Zones
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, Life in the Zones," describes the different elevation zones you can see from this location.

images.altText: An exhibit sign is mounted to a white metal rail lining the steep trail on Moro Rock's peak.
images.title: Life in the Zones
images.caption: Life in the Zones exhibit sign, located at the summit of Moro Rock

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, Life in the Zones," describes the different elevation zones you can see from this location.
data.audioDescription:
In front of you is a breathtaking view of the varied mountain peaks. Many are grey and rocky, some have thick, dark green conifer forests. Depending on the time of year, there may be snow visible. The lower foothills are a lighter olive green with short vegetation.

The text reads,

Notice the varied colors and textures on these slopes. They indicate elevational bands called life zones. Temperature and precipitation, which are affected mostly by elevation, create these zones. Plants and animals adapted to certain conditions inhabit each one. Sequoias live in the montane zone.

Is our climate shifts due to increased heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere, life will adjust. Biologist can already measure the uphill movement of Sierran animals compared to 100 years ago. In years to come, your children will see a different mosaic of life in these mountains.

A photo of the view from where you are standing. The mountain peaks are identified from left to right. It reads,

Mount Stewart. 12205'
Lawson Peak. 13140'
Kaweah Queen. 13382'
Black Kaweah. 13765'
Lippincott Mountain. 12260'

On the right side of the photo the zones that are visible in the photo are identified. From the top to bottom. It reads,

Subalpine and alpine zones above 9000'
Small, cold tolerant plants grow in patches surrounded by bare rock.

Montane zone: 5000 to 9000'
Conifer Forest must survive the heaviest snow loads in these parks.

Foothill zone: 1000 to 5000'
Oaks and shrubby chaparral have adapted to heat and drought.

A photo of a furry Pika, a tiny rabbit like mammal. It has short body, with reddish gray fur. The face and ears are rounded, its beady eye is dark brown. Its muzzle is a lighter gray, with a pointed nose and white whiskers. Sitting on granite rock, it chews on a short branch with green leaves. The caption reads,

Pikas live high in the alpine zone. This cousin of the rabbit survives only where is cool. Increasing heat drives animals to seek higher ground. Life already on the highest peak has just one option- to move north, if it can. We still have time to make choices that limit risks of loss from climate change.

quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Little Baldy
data.listingDescription: Little Baldy is a wide granite dome that rises to just over 8,000 feet in Sequoia National Park. At the top of the dome there is a wide, fairly flat, area with patches of low shrubs and a few stunted conifer trees. There are long curved layers of rock, a few inches thick, on the dome's surface, like the layers of an onion. The surface is uneven and there are no safety rails. From this summit, you have a view to the east of tree-covered hills and the Great Western Divide.

images.altText: Two people in red sit on the summit of Little Baldy with mountains in the distance.
images.title: Little Baldy
images.caption: The view from the summit.

data.bodyText:
Little Baldy is a wide granite dome that rises to just over 8,000 feet in Sequoia National Park. At the top of the dome there is a wide, fairly flat, area with patches of low shrubs and a few stunted conifer trees. There are long curved layers of rock, a few inches thick, on the dome's surface, like the layers of an onion. The surface is uneven and there are no safety rails.

From this summit, you have a commanding view to the east of tree-covered hills and the Great Western Divide mountain ranges. To the west (depending on the air quality) you may either see a layer of haze over low, tree and shrub-covered foothills in the foreground, or the San Joaquin Valley. When it is very clear, you may even see California's coastal mountains.

data.title: Little Baldy Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Little Baldy Trail area. Little Baldy Trail travels 1.7 miles (2.7 km) at an easy incline to the granite dome of Little Baldy, which features views of the lower portion of the Great Western Divide, Kaweah Peaks, and Sillman Crest.

images.altText: A blue trailhead sign with the trail to the right.
images.title: Little Baldy Trailhead
images.caption: Little Baldy Trailhead sign next to trail

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Little Baldy Trail area.

Little Baldy Trail travels 1.7 miles (2.7 km) at an easy incline to the granite dome of Little Baldy, which features views of the lower portion of the Great Western Divide, Kaweah Peaks, and Sillman Crest.
data.audioDescription: The text reads, A series of long switchbacks climbs to the top of this granite dome. Panoramic views from the top include the Great Western Divide to the east and Big Baldy, another granite dome, to the north. Allow two to three hours round trip for this hike. Like almost all park trails, Little Baldy Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of legal protection, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to enjoy. A photo shows a clearing on a steep ridge with a view of the thick forest close by and mountainsides in the distance. The caption reads, A view from the top of Little Baldy. 1.7 miles (or 2.7 km) each way. Elevation gain: 709 feet (or 216 m). Other nearby trails: A photo shows a group of three reddish brown giant sequoia trunks. The caption reads, Dorst Campground to Muir Grove. 2.3 miles (or 3.7 km) one way to end of trail. This gentle hike leads to a secluded sequoia grove. Begin at Dorst Campground, near the group sites. Along the way, enjoy panoramic views that included Big Baldy and Chimney Rocks. One mile after entering the grove, the trail ends at Valley View, an overlook with sweeping views into the foothills. A map shows the location of the Little Baldy Trailhead. A bottom photo shows the flat top of a granite dome with a snow drift. Beyond it is a thick conifer forest and a tree covered mountain range. Snow covered peaks are seen in the far distance. The caption reads, A view from the top of Little Baldy A quote by Mary Austin, Author, "Man is not himself only...He is all that he sees."

data.title: Living Proof
data.listingDescription: Should we kill unusual trees like this in order to put them on display? That was a common practice in the past, with both trees and animals. Perhaps the display moved some people to visit these parks and fight to protect them. The wayside exhibit, titled "Living Proof", shows the felling of sequoia trees.

images.altText: A metal panel with text and images stands in front of a wooden fence. Behind the fence are trees.
images.title: Living Proof Wayside
images.caption: This wayside is found in Kings Canyon

data.bodyText:
Should we kill unusual trees like this in order to put them on display? That was a common practice in the past, with both trees and animals. Perhaps the display moved some people to visit these parks and fight to protect them.

The wayside exhibit, titled "Living Proof", shows the felling of sequoia trees.
data.audioDescription: The View: You are standing before the "Centennial Stump". It has a diameter of 24 feet. A sign explains that the tree was cut in 1875. The top of the stump is slightly concave, surrounded by worn ragged edges sticking up about 5 feet from the base. A photo shows a historic black and white image of the felling of a sequoia tree. The tree is captured during its dramatic fall, at about a 45-degree angle. There are people standing safely near the base. The text reads, Living Proof Early explorers told of giant trees, but the public remained skeptical. At least three nearby sequoias died to prove that they lived. Cut into pieces, they were shipped across the country to exhibit as freaks. All that remains of the tree that once stood here is the Centennial Stump. Cut in 1875 for America's Centennial Exhibition, sixteen feet of the trunk were hollowed out and then reassembled in Philadelphia. People laughed it off as the "California Hoax." There is a quote from an eyewitness to the felling of a sequoia in 1893. "The immense tree quivered like one in agony, and with a crushing, raging, deafening sound it fell, ... breaking into a million pieces." Inset is an historic black and white photo of a fallen tree trunk. The cut base that faces us is about 15 feet high. Standing at the bottom are a woman, in a long white dress with puffy shoulders, and a man, in shirt and pants holding a hat. To their right is a ladder that reaches almost to the top of the cut. Near the top rung is a man, holding up a two-man saw that is taller than the giant section of the trunk. The caption reads, Mark Twain Tree Over 300 feet tall, the Mark Twain Tree was cut in 1891. Slabs of its trunk still hang in museums in New York and London. You can see its stump along the Big Stump Trail near the park entrance.

data.title: Lodgepole Amphitheater
data.listingDescription: Meet here for ranger-led campfires and talks, usually given in the evening.

images.altText: Lodgepole Amphitheater with seats and a stage.
images.title: Lodgepole Amphitheater
images.caption: Lodgepole Amphitheater

data.bodyText: Meet here for ranger-led campfires and talks, usually given in the evening.
data.audioDescription:
A smooth paved path leads you to the edge of a paved, lighted, outdoor amphitheater, surrounded by tall pines, including the Jeffrey pine which has a butterscotch smell, and incense cedar trees. There are several large, weathered branches on the ground in the wooded area around the amphitheater.
To your right, and slightly downslope, is a platform with a stone base. It has six stairs, on both the right and left sides. The stairs lead to a curved stage. Behind the stage is tall wooden structure, painted tan, with a white screen in the center. The sides of the structure angle slightly inward, each with a tall narrow window.

To the left of the projection wall is a campfire ring made of stones that stick up about one foot above the ground.

Starting 15 feet from the edge of the stage area, there are twenty, 20-foot-long wood benches for seating. They are lined up in two sets of ten, with a five-foot-wide aisle running down the center. The benches angle slightly inward toward the stage, creating a V shape.

About ten feet behind the bench seating is a small, tan, wood planked projection building. It has a locked wood framed window on the side that faces the screen.

If you are facing the stage and go to the trees to the right of the middle of the seating area, there is one Jeffrey pine near the path. If you scratch its trunk, you will find that it smells like butterscotch.

On the right side of the wall, about halfway up, is the National Park Service logo, in the shape of a brown arrowhead, pointed downward. Inside the arrowhead are the words in white lettering, "National Park Service" with a green sequoia tree shape to its left. Near the bottom of the arrowhead is a white buffalo silhouette set against a green meadow, with a white lake and snowcapped mountain behind it.

data.title: Lodgepole Campground
data.listingDescription: This large, popular campground is on the Marble Fork of the Kaweah River within easy walking distance of Lodgepole Village. Many campsites are surrounded by lodgepole pine forest. In summer, this campground has 214 sites for tents, RVs, and trailers. In fall and spring, there are 16 walk-in tent sites and a limited number of RV sites, and

images.altText: Camper near a fire
images.caption: A riverside site at Lodgepole Campground. Photo by Chagrin Falls Photo.

data.bodyText:
This large, popular campground is on the Marble Fork of the Kaweah River within easy walking distance of Lodgepole Village. Many campsites are surrounded by lodgepole pine forest. In summer, this campground has 214 sites for tents, RVs, and trailers. In fall and spring, there are 16 walk-in tent sites and a limited number of RV sites, and at an elevation of 6,700 ft (2,042 m), the campground can be snowy in spring and fall. Each campsite has a picnic table, fire ring, tent pad, and metal food storage boxes to protect food and scented items from bears. The campground also has flush toilets, a pay phone, and potable water. Nearby, Lodgepole Village offers a visitor center, market, and shower and laundry facilities. In summer, ride the free Sequoia Shuttle from the campground to Giant Forest to avoid waiting for parking.

Campground Information
- Some Lodgepole sites are available in late April, and the campground is fully open from late May to late September. Some sites remain open until mid-October, depending on weather conditions.
- In summer, this campground has 214 sites for tents, RVs, and trailers. In fall and spring, there are 16 walk-in tent sites and a limited number of RV sites.
- Sites are available by reservation at recreation.gov or by phone at 877-444-6777
- Lodgepole Campground has sites for RVs up to 42 feet (12.8 m) long. The campground has a dump station and a water station, but these are closed from mid-October to mid-May, depending on the weather. The campground has no hookups. Generators are allowed between 8 - 11 a.m. and 5 - 8 p.m.
- Pets are permitted within the campground, but must be leashed at all times.

Wildlife Information

You are required to store food properly to protect bears. Each campsite has a large food storage locker (47"W x 33"D x 28"H) that is resistant to bears when properly latched. Store food and all scented items, including toiletries, unopened cans and bottles, baby wipes, and lip balm. Store trash or dispose of it in bear-resistant trash cans or dumpsters. Remove baby car seats from your vehicle and store them near your food-storage box.

data.title: Lodgepole Campground Shuttle Stop

Shuttles within the park are free.

data.bodyText:
This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at the Lodgepole Campground, which is conveniently located about two miles from the Giant Forest Museum and grove of sequoias.

Sequoia Shuttles typically run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks.

Shuttles within the park are free; round-trip shuttles beween Visalia and Giant Forest Museum are $20, which includes the cost of park admission.

All buses are wheelchair accessible.

Visit the park shuttles page for more information, including a route map.

Lodgepole Visitor Center reopened with new exhibits in 2023, providing an opportunity to learn more about the parks, plan your trip, activate or pickup a wilderness permit, and purchase souvenirs. When it is open, the Lodgepole Market offers groceries, camping and hiking supplies, and gift items. It also has a deli and snack bar with prepared food.

Sequoia Shuttle runs from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks.

Shuttles within the park are free; round-trip shuttles between Visalia and Giant Forest Museum are $20, which includes the cost of park admission.

All buses are wheelchair accessible.

Visit the park shuttles page for more information, including a route map.

data.title: Lodgepole Picnic Area
data.listingDescription: The Lodgepole Picnic Area is adjacent to Lodgepole facilities, including the Village Market, visitor center, campground, restrooms, laundry, and showers.

images.altText: A picnic table in the woods with a boulder to the left.
images.title: Lodgepole Picnic Area
images.caption: A picnic table and boulder at the Lodgepole Picnic Area.

data.bodyText: The Lodgepole Picnic Area is adjacent to Lodgepole facilities, including the Village Market, visitor center, campground, restrooms, laundry, and showers.
data.audioDescription:
You are standing on a paved walkway with low stone edging and wood benches that can be used for seating. Beyond the benches are grasses and conifer trees that surround Lodgepole Village. The village includes Lodgepole Visitor Center and the Lodgepole Market Center. There is an American flag at the entrance to the walkway, from the parking area. The walkway has a left branch that takes you to the Visitor Center. Continuing straight ahead takes you to the Lodgepole Market Center, which will be on your right. As you approach the building, you will pass a dining area on the right, with outdoor tables covered by market umbrellas.

The Lodgepole Market Center is a two-story building planked in dark wood. It has several dormer windows poking out through the roof. A peaked roof extends out over the main entrance, supported by large beams and posts rising from a low stone wall. This creates a seating area and shade outside the glass double doors at the market entrance. A second entrance of double doors is next to the outdoor dining area

Opposite from the Lodgepole Market Center entrance is the end of the Lodgepole Visitor Center, where the restrooms are located.

data.title: Lodgepole-to-Sherman-Tree Trailhead
data.listingDescription: The trail from the Lodgepole Campground to the General Sherman Tree is 2.8 miles one way (9 kilometers) with a mild incline.

images.altText: A trail orientation sign is on the side of a broad dirt path in front of fir trees

data.bodyText:
The trail from the Lodgepole Campground to the General Sherman Tree is 2.8 miles one way (9 kilometers) with a mild incline.

This trailhead orientation panel here includes a map and photos of the trail, as well as safety information.
data.audioDescription:
The text reads,

This trail begins with a gentle climb through a white fir forest, then descends into a spectacular sequoia grove, ending at the largest tree in the world. Remnants of pavement show evidence of this trail's previous life as a road.

Like almost all park trails, Lodgepole to Sherman Tree Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of legal protection, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to enjoy.

A photo of a paved path with a bench and some stone stairs, crossing through a bushy clearing that is strewn with boulders and surrounded by young sequoia trees.

The caption reads,

Main Sherman tree Trail Junction.
2.5 miles (or 4.1 km) one way.

A photo of the base of a gigantic sequoia, with people observing it from behind protective fencing. Smaller sequoia trees grow nearby.

The caption reads,

General Sherman Tree.
2.8 miles (or 4.6 km) one way.

A map shows the Lodgepole to Sherman Tree Trail.

The bottom photo shows the tops of giant sequoia trees. A mountain range with snow dappled ridges is seen in the distance.

The caption reads,

A view of the Giant Forest from Moro Rock.

A quote by Edward Abbey,

"Walking makes the world much bigger and therefore more interesting."

images.altText: A metal box collects money to distribute passes
images.title: Lookout Point
images.caption: The fee box located at lookout point

data.bodyText:
Welcome to the Mineral King area in the canyon of the East Fork of the Kaweah River. This marks one of only three road entrances into Sequoia National Park. Take a moment to look down into the river valley below. As you continue on this historic road, views will become more spectacular.

Entering the Park

Please use the self-serve station to pay your park entrance fee.
data.audioDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Silence & Clean Air", shows an illustration, photos and text about the energy systems used in the park. The View: In front of you is a tree filled valley that stretches into the distance. Mountain peaks that surround it have exposed rock above a thick tree line. An illustration of a distant view of this location, including the road, a ranch style house and mechanical equipment. On the roof of the house is the symbol of a yellow lightbulb inside a black jagged multipoint star shape. A spiral black line connects that to a smaller wood shed with two tilted shiny panels on the roof. An inset illustration shows a close up of what is inside that shed: three rows of generator batteries in a metal rack. Wires connect the batteries. The text reads, Silence and Clean Air Silence and clean air two of the priceless qualities we seek in national parks. Yet until recently, an obsolete diesel generator ran noisily 18 hours a day at this remote spot. In 1933, park employees installed a solar energy system here. Now for days on end electrical power is produced only by silent, clean sunshine. Sunlight strikes solar panels, energizing electrons. The resulting electrical current charges a bank of batteries. The batteries store enough power for three sunless days. For backup, a propane generator stands ready, but it is seldom used. Fossil fuels produce most of the electricity in Central California. Burning these fuels contributes to acid deposition, high ozone levels, and particles in the air. in Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks, ozone is damaging black oaks, yellow pines, and sequoia seedlings. Acid deposition is changing the chemistry of alpine lakes. A haze of airborne particles obscures once beautiful vistas. By switching to cleaner, more efficient energy sources we not only protect our parks, but give our hometowns more of the qualities we seek here. Ask for information on air quality at any park visitor center. A photo of a bunch of thin, yellow spikes. The caption reads, Yellow pine needles exhibit ozone damage. A photo of two people sitting on a rock at the edge of a stream, holding up a cylinder of water. The caption reads, Scientists monitor the effects of air pollution on park waters. Attached to the stone base, on the front of this wayside panel, is a metal framed plaque with raised letters. It reads, The Mineral King Road Cultural Landscape District Has been placed on the National Register of Historic Places, under the provisions of the National Preservation Act of 1966. The District represents a cultural landscape that reflects the growth of recreational activity in California from 1915 to 1942. United States Department of the Interior National Park Service October 24, 2003

data.audioDescription: You are standing beside the road. Both sides of the road are edged with mature sequoia trees. If you're driving south bound, there is a cluster of two giant sequoias on the right side of the road, and a cluster of six on the left, protected by a split rail fence. data.title: Marble Falls Trailhead
data.listingDescription:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Marble Falls Trail area.

This trail climbs 3.1 miles one-way at a moderate incline through the chaparral scrubland, ending at a waterfall cascade.

Park near site #14 at Potwisha Campground and follow the dirt road across the concrete ditch. The trail starts along the steep bank to the right. Additional parking available across the Generals Highway in the Potwisha Overflow Parking Lot.

images.altText: A blue metal panel sits in a metal frame next to a trail behind it are yellow grass and oak tree
images.title: Marble Falls Wayside
images.caption: The start of Marble Falls Trail

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Marble Falls Trail area.

This trail climbs 3.1 miles one-way at a moderate incline through the chaparral scrubland, ending at a waterfall cascade.

Park near site #14 at Potwisha Campground and follow the dirt road across the concrete ditch. The trail starts along the steep bank to the right. Additional parking available across the Generals Highway in the Potwisha Overflow Parking Lot.

Community Science

Water is essential for life to thrive in the hot, dry foothills, but can sometimes be challenging to find. In the springtime, streams and creeks swell to high levels as snowmelt makes its way down towards the Central Valley. Once the snow has melted, however, water levels drop significantly. By late summer, many water sources dry up completely. Inconsistent snowpack from year to year makes it difficult to predict what resources will be available for the parks' flora and fauna. By tracking water levels over time, park scientists can better understand this unique landscape.

Are you interested in exploring watersheds in the Foothills? Join a park ranger at any point in the year to collect data as a community scientist. In order to be sensitive to the plants and animals that call these streams home, group sizes are limited to a maximum of 6 participants. Individuals with an interest in a longer-term volunteer commitment are encouraged to reach out.

Call Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks' Education Office at 559-565-4211 or email seki_ritc@nps.gov for more information.
data.audioDescription: This trail ends at a cascading waterfall. It crosses some of the most rugged, least visited terrain in this park. If you go beyond the base of Marble Falls, use caution. Water and slippery rocks are beautiful but dangerous. Like almost all park trails, Marble Falls Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of legal protection, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to enjoy. A photo of a creek, cascading over large rocks, surrounded by trees. The caption reads, Marble Falls during spring high water. 3.7 miles (or 6.0 km) one way to end of trail Elevation gain: 1470 feet (or 448 m) The text reads, Other nearby trails: A photo of a creek with water flowing through large rocks, surrounded by green shrubs and trees. The caption reads, Paradise Creek Trail This gentle trail begins in Buckeye Flat Campground near site #28. If you are not camping there, park at Hospital Rock Picnic Area and walk the 0.7 miles to the campground. A map shows our location at the beginning of the Marble Falls trail. There is a safety warning on the map indicating that rattlesnakes and ticks are common in the foothills. The bottom photo shows a view of rolling hills with a valley cutting through the middle. Hills on the left are darker green with more trees. Hills on the right are rockier and lighter green, with more shrubs. The caption reads, Marble Fork Canyon A quote by Charles Dickens: "Walk and be happy, walk and be healthy."

data.title: McGee Overlook
data.listingDescription: This overlook on US Forest Service land has excellent sunset views. It's also a great spot to see the effects of a very hot portion of the 2015 Rough Fire that reburned an area of the 1955 McGee Fire.

images.altText: Sunset over hazy mountain ridges
images.caption: Views extending into the foothills make this an excellent spot at sunset. Photo by Kiel Maddox.

data.bodyText:
This overlook on US Forest Service land has excellent sunset views. It's also a great spot to see the effects of a very hot portion of the 2015 Rough Fire that reburned an area of the 1955 McGee Fire. The 60-year gap between these fires is longer than normal. After the McGee Fire in 1955, naturalists began to realize the dangers of long-term fire suppression and the benefits of prescribed burns.

Safety

Be very careful pulling into and out of this overlook; vehicles move quickly along this stretch of highway and visibility is limited.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit, titled "A Fiery Hand Shapes the Land", shows the importance of fire in the parks.

The View: In front of you is a view through charred tree trunks over a canyon. The rounded mountain sides are covered with conifer forest.

Three images, from left to right, show:

A photo of an intense blaze engulfing a forest.

An illustration of this valley consumed by fire with large plumes of smoke filling the sky.

A black and white photo of the burned valley, charred and desolate, with spiky broken tree trunks covering the mountainside. The sky is hazy.

The text reads,

In fall 1955 McGee Fire burned over 17,500 acres between Miramonte and the Kings River. Sparked by an escaped burn, McGee was a dramatic example of extreme fire behavior in the Sierra Nevada ecosystem.

Natural fires were common and not very intense so they burned ground vegetation and debris, but left the trees. McGee left ashes and charred sticks where the trees once stood.

Sierran plant species play an important role in fire ecology. Bushes have oily leaves and shaggy bark to fuel fires so they burn in any fire, large or small. Trees here are adapted to fire in a different way. Giant sequoia bark can be two feet thick and pine bark several inches thick, so fire rarely harms the living wood.

A quote by E.V. Kormarek,

"The earth, born in fire, baptized by lightning, since before life's beginning has been and is, a fire planet."

Additional text reads,

What Happened:

After this area was logged in the late 1800s, few trees remained in this altered ecosystem where poor quality wood and branches were left to rot. Years of suppressing all fire here had disrupted the fire cycle. Dense brush grew under the trees forming fuel ladders.

Fifty years later the dry September wind carried embers from a prescribed burn into a tinderbox of old brush and scraggly trees. Fuel ladders allowed the McGee Fire to climb from the ground through the brush and branches into the treetops.

The text reads,

What's Next:

The land seems barren after a fire like McGee, but looks are deceiving. Within two years the hills are covered with grass, brush and new seedlings. Increased food and light helps trees like sequoia and pine grow quickly. To speed up the process, foresters plant more seedlings.

Today the Forest Service burns small areas under carefully controlled conditions to reduce risk of a large fire like McGee harming people and property in the forest. This also protects timber resources and wildlife in the area, while continuing the natural fire cycles.

A badge-shaped U.S. Forest Service Department of Agriculture logo.

data.title: Meadows
data.listingDescription: This outdoor exhibit, titled “Meadows,“ discusses the seasonal lifecycle of a meadow.

images.altText: A brown, metal sign has a picture of bright yellow flowers and text about meadows.
images.title: Meadows outdoor exhibit
images.caption: Meadows outdoor exhibit

data.bodyText: This outdoor exhibit, titled “Meadows,“ discusses the seasonal lifecycle of a meadow.
data.audioDescription: This outdoor exhibit panel is titled, "Meadows" and features a photo with a caption and text about the seasonal lifecycle of a meadow. The photograph caption reads, “California coneflower (Rudbeckia californica) blooms prominently in summer.” The text on the panel reads, “The meadow before you changes dramatically with the seasons. Do you see a snow-covered clearing? A wet and soggy brown field? Or a meadow knee-deep in flowers and tall grasses? In winter, deep snow blankets this landscape. As spring nears, snowmelt nourishes newly-emerging plants. By summer, grasses and flowers overtake the meadow, towering over the boggy ground. As the plants die back in fall, they decompose and provide nutrients for the next generation of vegetation. Meadows provide critical habitat for amphibians and birds. They offer a cool, shady resting place for mammals, including deer and black bears. Their flowers sustain native bee species and other insects.”

data.title: Middle Fork Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Middle Fork trailhead.

images.altText: A trailhead sign and bench are located at the beginning of a dirt trail with a hill in background.
images.title: Middle Fork Trailhead
images.caption: Middle Fork Trailhead

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Middle Fork area.

In fall 2021, the KNP Complex Wildfire burned much of the surrounding area. While wilderness permits are available for this area, if you enter here, nearby exit points may be closed due to extensive damage during 2023 winter storms, including but not limited to trailheads exiting in the Mineral King and Cedar Grove area. Please be sure you exit the wilderness in an open area. Consult the closed area map for more details. If you start a wilderness trip here, please obtain a wilderness permit at the Foothills Visitor Center. 

Directions

To access this trailhead, follow the Generals Highway. Directly across from the Hospital Rock Picnic Area, turn onto the Buckeye Flat Campground Road. From here, you will encounter a dirt road on the left—turn here to follow the narrow, often-times single lane Middle Fork Access Road to the trailhead. Parking is extermely limited here (~8 vehicles).

This road is closed during rainy weather, and during the winter season (late September to early April). During this time of year, park at the Hospital Rock Picnic Area and walk in.
data.audioDescription: The text reads, This trail begins within the diversity and richness of the foothills, and climbs steadily into higher country. It is a good choice in winter for both day hikes and overnight trips, when temperatures are cooler and other trails are snow covered. Like most park trails, Middle Fork Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Panther Creek and Mehrten Creek are popular destinations for day hikers. Possible overnight destinations include: A photo of a lush meadow lined with sequoia trees. The caption reads, Redwood Meadow 16.8 miles (or 27.0 km) one way. Elevation: 6,040 feet (or 1,841 m) Chaparral hillsides and oaks give way to lush meadows, streams, and sequoia groves as you approach the upper reaches of the Middle Fork of the Kaweah River. A photo of a canyon surrounded by granite peaks. The caption reads, Bearpaw Meadow 17.0 miles (or 27.4 km) one way. Elevation: 7,820 feet (or 2,384 m) From the Bearpaw area, look deep into a wilderness of granite peaks and canyons. The High Sierra Trail passes through here. The map shows the Foothills area and our location at the Middle Fork Trailhead. The bottom photo shows a sunlit tree filled valley, with a line of dark tree tops running across it. A snow-covered mountain peak is seen in the distance. The caption reads, Middle Fork Canyon. A quote by Gerard Manley Hopkins, Inversnaid: "Long live the weeds and the wilderness yet."

data.title: Mist Falls
data.listingDescription: The 8-mile round-trip walk to this spectacular cascade makes a great all-day walk. The first miles are relatively flat and open; in the last mile the wooded trail gains 600' in elevation. Be careful once there: Mist and spray make the surrounding rocks slippery and treacherous. Too often people have slipped and fallen in here.

images.altText: a large waterfall over a steep granite slope
images.title: Mist Falls
images.caption: The view from the base of the falls.

data.bodyText: The 8-mile round-trip walk to this spectacular cascade makes a great all-day walk. The first miles are relatively flat and open; in the last mile the wooded trail gains 600' in elevation. Be careful once there: Mist and spray make the surrounding rocks slippery and treacherous. Too often people have slipped and fallen in here.
data.audioDescription: The first section of the Mist Falls trail stays close to the river and is shaded in some parts, but is often hot and dry in summer. Closer to Mist Falls it crosses ground that is sometimes steep and rocky. Parts of the river have cascades and rapids. Other parts have deep, clear pools that look inviting, but swimming is not advised due to the fast current and cold water. Mist Falls is indeed misty, and the rock it travels over is smooth and wide. Conifer trees and brush grow along its rocky banks.

data.bodyText:
Montecito Sequoia Lodge is located in the Giant Sequoia National Monument on National Forest Service land. Please contact them directly for hours of operation.

Most accommodations were built as a Girls' Camp in the 1970s and have since been remodeled.

Lodging here is all-inclusive. During the snowy season, the resort offers cross-country skiing and other winter activities for guests.

In fall, winter, and spring, meals may be available for the public, even if you're not staying at the lodge.

data.title: Moro Rock
data.listingDescription: Climb to the top of this immense granite dome for views of the park that extend deep into wilderness. Along the way, stop to catch your breath at exhibits that offer details about the surrounding landscape. At the top, a railing encloses a flat portion of the rock to protect viewers from steep dropoffs.

images.altText: Protective rails sit atop a granite rock. In the distance are many mountains
images.title: Moro Rock
images.caption: The top of Moro Rock

data.bodyText:
Climb to the top of this immense granite dome for views of the park that extend deep into wilderness. Along the way, stop to catch your breath at exhibits that offer details about the surrounding landscape. At the top, a railing encloses a flat portion of the rock to protect viewers from steep dropoffs.

Safety

The stairway, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, is safe as long as you stay on it. Avoid climbing if snow or ice are present. Stay away from Moro Rock during thunderstorms or if there's static in the air.

Winter Access

To access this area in winter, you will need to hike, snowshoe, or ski into the area.

data.bodyText: These wayside exhibits show a timeline of historic events related to Moro Rock, and describe the forces that created the granite dome, and provide an introduction to hiking the stairway to the top.
data.audioDescription: Exhibit One: This trailhead orientation panel shows photos of the Moro Rock trail area. A photo of a mountain range, with snow speckled peaks and tree filled valleys. An inset photo shows people at an overlook, standing behind metal handrails. The text reads,Changing ViewsMorro Rock TrailA climb up Moro rock always offers a dramatic experience, with views that constantly change. Natural processes transform the landscape you see. People shape the view as they make changes in the park and surrounding areas.An atmosphere altered by pollution affects both how far you can see, and in the long term, life itself in these parks. What will you- or your children- see from here in the future?A photo at the top of the granite rock; handrails create a safe walkway across the gray glossy rock. Visitors take in the eagle eye view of the mountain range beyond. The caption reads,The Top of the Trail TodayThe text reads,Climbing a Granite DomeThis trail climbs over 350 steps to the top, and an elevation of 6,725 feet (2050 m). Just a few steps up, the vista of the High Sierra peaks (above) first reveal itself. A black and white photo of Moro Rock near the top, with wooden stairs and long handrails running up the dome. Another black and white photo shows concrete steps with metal handrails circling a large rock on the way to the top. The caption reads, Yesterday's trail The first stairs were built in 1917 of wood. Concrete steps replace them in 1931, making them safer and blending them in with the granite rock.Please note, about 60 stair steps up the trail is a broad landing with strongly scented plants on either side called mountain misery.Exhibit Two: This orientation panel shows photos and a timeline of events. A black and white photo from September 7, 1936, of a hiker, gazing east from the top of Moro Rock. He leans on two walking poles and is wearing a stiff, wide brimmed hat, long pants and a jacket with shirt and tie. Near him is a stone stairway cut into the granite rock, a flagpole with two flags, and a metal handrail.The text reads,A High PointThe text explains that early travelers used ropes to scale this dome. Today's staircases make the trip easier, but it is still an effort to gain the top. From the 6,725 feet summit, on a clear day, you can see more than 150 miles. A timeline provides key dates, text and some related photos (starting as black and white and ending in color):1858. A bearded man, Hale Tharp, who was led by two young Native Americans to explore Moro Rock. 1860s. A dark horse with a spotted rump. This rock may have been named for a horse that grazed nearby. It may also come from "moro", the Spanish word for spotted animals or dark rocks.1890. Just two weeks after the creation of Sequoia National Park, Moro Rock gains protection when Congress enlarges park boundaries. 1903. A uniformed man, Buffalo Soldier Capt. Charles Young, and his regiment complete Moro Rock Road. 1913. Old model T style cars parked on dirt, under trees. Automobiles become more common at Moro Rock. 1915. The Mather Mountain Party begins its historic trip across the Sierra with a climb up Moro Rock. During the trip, the idea of a national park service is born.1917. A woman poses at the bottom of a new wooden staircase that leads up the dome's northern ridge. 1921. About twenty male Park rangers pose on top of Moro Rock, along with some other hikers, including several women and children. A large U.S. flag rises from the peak.1926. Congress enlarges Sequoia National Park to include the Great Western Divide, whose peaks are visible to the east. 1931. Workers remove the deteriorating wooden staircase and build a stone stairway that fits neatly into existing crevices in the rock.1933. New steps at the bottom of the stairway now complete the trail from the parking area to the dome's top. 1940s. About 50 male WW II soldiers pose for a photo while resting on top of Moro rock 1959. Encircled by a chain railing, a few men and women look out over Giant Forest.1960s. A new metal handrail along the entire stairway provides more protection from falls. 1975. Zigzagging white lightning cuts through a blue sky. The first recorded lightning fatality occurs at Moro Rock. 1978. Due to the way it blends almost invisibly into the granite contours, Moro Rock Stairway is added to the National Register of Historic Places. 1995 to 2005. Three people fall from the rock to their deaths in separate incidents. Always stay on the trail and within the railings.2005. A graph shows a cross section of earth and sky, with the Moro rock in the center at the bottom. A graph key represents the darkness in a spectrum of colors: purple represents the darkest; green is medium bright; and red is the brightest. Above Moro rock, the sky is dark blue and purple. On either side of the rock, the sky is dark high above the ground, but moves down through the rainbow, as it nears the ground, reaching red at a few points. data.title: Moro Rock Shuttle Stop
data.listingDescription: This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at Moro Rock, a spectacular hike up an immense granite dome. From the top, take in 360 degree views of the Sierra Nevada. Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks. Shuttles within the park are free; round-trip shuttles from Visalia are $20, which includes the park entrance fee.

images.title: Moro Rock Shuttle Stop
images.caption: The shuttle stop at Moro Rock.

data.bodyText:
This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at Moro Rock, a spectacular hike up an immense granite dome. From the top, take in 360 degree views of the Sierra Nevada.

Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks.

Shuttles within the park are free; round-trip shuttles from Visalia are $20, which includes the park entrance fee.

All buses are wheelchair accessible, and either kneel or have lifts.

Visit the park shuttles page for more information, including a route map.

images.altText: A trailhead sign is situated in the foreground. Stone stairs that summit Moro Rock in background.
images.title: Moro Rock Trailhead
images.caption: Moro Rock Trailhead

data.bodyText:
Welcome to one of the most popular and spectacular hikes in these parks. To reach the top of this granite dome, take the stairway that climbs up 300 feet (.09 km) to the 6,275 ft (2,050 km) summit.

At the top is a spectacular 360° view from the Great Western Divide to the east around to the western half of Sequoia National Park. Consider summiting Moro Rock at dawn or before dusk. It offers a huge expanse of night sky, a rare view in forested parts of the parks. One of the best places in the parks to see sunset and moonrise.

Moro Rock is one of several granite domes in these parks. These domes formed millions of years ago when magma beneath the surface cooled into granite. Since erosion removed the layers of softer rock that were above them, they have been rebounding and lifting a tiny bit each year.

In summer, free park shuttles at the Giant Forest Museum will drop you off at this parking area. This parking area is two miles (3.2 km) from the Generals Highway.

Safety

Take your time; unless you are used to this elevation this walk can be challenging. Moro Rock is also prone to lightning strikes. If there is any evidence of an approaching storm, get off the rock quickly but safely.

Winter Access

To access the base of this trail in winter, you will need to hike, snowshoe, or ski into the area. In winter, the staircase is typically not safe to ascend. Don't climb the stairs if any ice or snow is present; it is very dangerous.
data.audioDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows photos of the Moro Rock trail area. A photo of a mountain range, with snow speckled peaks and tree filled valleys. An inset photo shows people at an overlook, standing behind metal handrails. The text reads, "Changing Views, Moro Rock Trail. A climb up Moro rock always offers a dramatic experience, with views that constantly change. Natural processes transform the landscape you see. People shape the view as they make changes in the park and surrounding areas. An atmosphere altered by pollution affects both how far you can see, and in the long term, life itself in these parks. What will you- or your children- see from here in the future?" A photo at the top of the granite rock; handrails create a safe walkway across the gray glossy rock. Visitors take in the eagle eye view of the mountain range beyond. The caption reads, "The Top of the Trail Today." The text reads, "Climbing a Granite Dome. This trail climbs over 350 steps to the top, and an elevation of 6,725 feet (2050 m). Just a few steps up, the vista of the High Sierra peaks (above) first reveal itself." A black and white photo of Moro Rock near the top, with wooden stairs and long handrails running up the dome. Another black and white photo shows concrete steps with metal handrails circling a large rock on the way to the top. The caption reads, "Yesterday's trail. The first stairs were built in 1917 of wood. Concrete steps replaced them in 1931, making them safer and blending them in with the granite rock." Please note, about 60 stair steps up the trail is a broad landing with strongly scented plants on either side called mountain misery.
