data.title: Muir Grove Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Muir Grove offers an opportunity to hike into a sequoia grove that's off the beaten path. The gently sloping trail follows a ridgeline that offers distant views of the sequoias as you hike. Once you reach them, enjoy the quiet and calm of the area.

images.altText: The Muir Grove Trailhead sign sits in the foreground of a dirt path with trees on each side.
images.title: Muir Grove Trailhead
images.caption: Muir Grove Trailhead

data.bodyText: Muir Grove offers an opportunity to hike into a sequoia grove that's off the beaten path. The gently sloping trail follows a ridgeline that offers distant views of the sequoias as you hike. Once you reach them, enjoy the quiet and calm of the area.
data.audioDescription:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Muir Grove Trail area.

The text reads,

This gentle hike leads to a secluded sequoia grove. Along the way, enjoy panoramic views of Big Baldy, Chimney Rocks, and the forest. Halfway to the grove, sequoia treetops become visible. Look for the characteristic rounded tops of mature sequoias.

Like almost all park trails, Muir Grove Trail leads to designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of legal protection, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to enjoy.

A photo shows a group of three reddish brown giant sequoia trunks.

The caption reads,

Giant Sequoias in Muir Grove.
2.3 miles (or 3.7 km) one way to end of trail.

Other nearby trails:

A photo of a granite ridge, with a forest of conifers below. Tree covered mountains and steep peaks with snow are seen in the distance.

The caption reads,

Little Baldy Trail.
1.7 miles (or 2.7 km) each way.
Elevation gain: 709 feet (or 216 m).

A series of long switchbacks climbs to the top of this granite dome. Begin at Little Baldy Saddle, one mile south of the campground on the Generals Highway. The view from the top includes the Great Western Divide to the east and Big Baldy, another granite dome, to the north. Allow two to three hours round-trip for this hike.

A map with the location of the Muir Trails area.

A bottom photo shows the view from a rocky ridge looking out over tree covered valleys and hills in the distance.

The caption reads,

A view from the Muir Grove Trail

A quote by John Muir,

"The clearest way into the Universe is through a forest wilderness."

data.title: Muir Rock
data.listingDescription: Over a hundred years ago, Scottish-American naturalist John Muir explored the Kings Canyon, calling it "a yet grander valley" and "a rival of the Yosemite." From this rock overlooking a relatively quiet bend of the Kings River, he would address anyone who would listen. He shared his love of the wild and his theories on how these canyons formed (carved by large rivers of ice called glaciers, which later proved to be correct).

images.altText: An oval rock sits above a shallow blue river. Tall trees line the opposite bank.
images.title: Muir Rock
images.caption: Visitors enjoying Muir Rock and the Kings River.

data.bodyText:
Over a hundred years ago, Scottish-American naturalist John Muir explored the Kings Canyon, calling it "a yet grander valley" and "a rival of the Yosemite." From this rock overlooking a relatively quiet bend of the Kings River, he would address anyone who would listen. He shared his love of the wild and his theories on how these canyons formed (carved by large rivers of ice called glaciers, which later proved to be correct). These talks and the articles he wrote celebrating the area helped lead to its becoming a national park. Be sure to watch the movie at Kings Canyon Visitor Center, Gem of the Sierra, for a taste of the history of this rock.

In late summer, the pool below the rock may be swimmable, but be careful: the river can be treacherous. Cold water and swift currents lie beneath a placid surface in some areas.
data.audioDescription: You are standing on a large, fairly flat rock, next to a river, edged with large conifer trees. The river sometimes flows slowly and gently. At other times, it may be a fast and raging torrent. The top surface of the rock is uneven and there is no safety rail or barrier between the rock and the river. The texture of the rock is grainy. Its surface has curved ridges next to slight dimples as if patches of the top layer of the rock have flaked off. The rock looks like long thin plates that have stacked together to form its flat oval shape. From this flat rock, you have a view of a giant rocky mountain, with craggy peaks and large sequoias dotted along the ridges. The mountain is light gray with streaks of a pale yellow that seem to drip down the side of the mountain. This is the Grand Sentinel.

data.title: North Fork Trailhead
data.listingDescription: The trails that start here are lightly maintained. Be prepared for more rugged conditions than you would see on trails that get heavier use. Maps can be useful in this area. Poison oak is common here, especially on the Colony Mill Trail.

images.altText: Trailhead placard, closed to a no hunting sign and bear box in front of oak trees
images.caption: North Fork Trailhead

data.bodyText: The trails that start here are lightly maintained. Be prepared for more rugged conditions than you would see on trails that get heavier use. Maps can be useful in this area. Poison oak is common here, especially on the Colony Mill Trail.
data.audioDescription:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the North Fork area.

The text reads,

Welcome to Sequoia National Park. Only one maintained trail begins here, the Colony Mill Trail. Once part of the original road from the foothills to Giant Forest, this trail ends at Crystal Cave Road, 11.2 miles (or 18.0 km) from here.

Other unmaintained routes offer a challenge for experienced hikers and riders. Finding your way can be difficult in this remote area. Carry a map and be prepared.

Like almost all park trails, these lead into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of legal protection, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to enjoy.

A map shows the location of the North Fork park entrance.

Two photos of poison oak: One labeled, "Spring", shows a thin branch with red and yellow oval leaves with pointed tips and wavy edges, in clusters of three. "Summer" shows a close up of a cluster of three similar leaves, now colored green.

The caption reads,

Poison oak is abundant along this trail.
This plant causes itchy rashes a few days after it touches your skin. Look for shrubs or vines with leaves of three. If you come in contact, wash the area with cool, soapy water.

A quote from J.R.R. Tolkien,

"Not all those who wander are lost."

A photo shows a view through the tops of green deciduous trees toward tree covered mountains in the distance.

The caption reads,

A view from the North Fork area.

quickFacts.name: Location

data.listingDescription: The North Grove Trail is an initial loop through sequoias and meadows. After the North Grove Trail, you can continue to the Dead Giant Trail loop. These trails offers views of Sequoia Lake and the Dead Giant, a huge sequoia that stayed standing even after it died.

images.altText: A grassy green meadow surrounded by trees

data.bodyText:
The North Grove Trail is an initial loop through sequoias and meadows. After the North Grove Trail, you can continue to the Dead Giant Trail loop. This trail offers views of Sequoia Lake and the Dead Giant, a huge sequoia that stayed standing even after it died. Combined, these two loops are 2.5 miles (4.0 kilometers) and a mild incline.

This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the North Grove and Dead Giant Trails area.

Services Nearby

Parking, restrooms and water are available in the General Grant Tree parking lot.

The North Grove Loop offers sequoia groves, conifer forests, waterfalls, and meadows. Choose from one of the loops shown below, or create your own route along the trails that wind through this forest.

The top photo shows a tree-lined trail, with rays of sunlight streaming through the trees and highlighting large stones speckled with moss. The caption reads,

data.title: On Native Soil
data.listingDescription: This exhibit, titled "On Native Soil," shows the plants that flourish in the foothills.

images.altText: A sign titled On Native Soil talks about native plant species.
images.title: On Native Soil
images.caption: On Native Soil exhibit in garden at the Foothills Visitor Center.

data.bodyText:
This exhibit, titled "On Native Soil," shows the plants that flourish in the foothills.

This exhibit is located next to the Foothills VIsitor Center, where restrooms, drinking water, a payphone, and other amenities are found.
data.audioDescription:
The View: is a garden of native plants. They vary in shape and size, from clusters of small leaved bushes to long spikey grasses. Many plants have a small metal signs identifying their common and scientific names. A 50-foot dirt pathway loops through the garden, reaching from the street to the Visitor Center entrance. Along the path is a wooden bench to relax on.

A photo of gentle rolling hills, densely covered with dark green trees and shrubs.

The text reads,

All life in the Sierran foothills around you depends on communities of native plants. Adapted to the local climate, these tough plants form the basis of this entire ecosystem.

They survive due to fascinating adaptations that help them to live through the hot, dry summers here. As a result, they can provide year-round food and shelter to the animals of the foothills.

Additional text reads,

Growing native plants

Wherever you live, a community of native plants evolved to fit your climate. These plants require little irrigation, pest control, or overall care. What plants are truly native to your soil?

A photo shows thin green branches with clusters of hand-shaped leaves. The caption reads,

California buckeyes drop their large leaves each summer to save water.

A photo shows a mound of long, spiky, needle thin green grass. The caption reads,

Deergrass gathers water effectively with its far-reaching root system.

A photo shows a bush with small clustered leaves, and tall upright spikes of flower clusters made up of tiny light blue flowers that circle up the flower stems. The caption reads,

Silver bush lupine's pale leaves deflect some of the sun's strong rays.

A photo of a branch with flat paddle shaped leaves, with bunches of small pink bell-shaped flowers dangling below. The caption reads,

Manzanita leaves stand up, rather than lay flat, to limit exposure to sun.

A photo shows a branch covered with clusters of tiny short, needle like leaves. The caption reads,

Tiny chamise leaves lose less water through evaporation to the dry air.

A photo shows several plants, each with a rounded cluster of green spiky leaves at its base and a single 8 to 10-foot-tall flower spike. Many small white flowers cluster around the top of this spike, combining into the shape of a giant, thin football. The caption reads,

Chaparral yucca's tough, waxy leaves and thick roots store scarce water.

data.title: Panoramic Point Overlook
data.listingDescription: This overlook is located a short driving distance from the Kings Canyon Visitor Center. Look outward from Panoramic Point across hundreds of miles of Kings Canyon National Park and neighboring national forest lands. Below lies Hume Lake, a small historic lake in Sequoia National Forest that was created in 1908 using a rare multiple-arch dam.

images.altText: black metal panels stand in front of an asphalt path. Behind it are bushes and mountains
images.title: Panoramic Point overlook
images.caption: Panoramic Point Overlook

data.bodyText:
This overlook is located a short driving distance from the Kings Canyon Visitor Center. Look outward from Panoramic Point across hundreds of miles of Kings Canyon National Park and neighboring national forest lands. Below lies Hume Lake, a small historic lake in Sequoia National Forest that was created in 1908 using a rare multiple-arch dam. The lake water fed a flume that floated timber down to the valley. Beyond, lies the deep glacial gorge of the Kings Canyon itself and a wealth of the High Sierra's peaks.

The area before you has a rich history. In the 1890s, artist Bolton Brown climbed many peaks to learn about and paint the area more accurately. Beginning In the late 1920s, poet Kenneth Rexroth often hiked here and wrote about this area. James Hutchings also spent time here, developing his Illustrated California magazine in the 1850s to bring attention and protection to the High Sierra. The likes of John Muir, Stephen Mather, George Moskey, and Horace Albright spent time here discussing how to develop a national park system.

This is also home to countless species of plants and animals, from the alpine zone, where cold-tolerant species like pika and foxtail pines live, to the foothill zone, where heat-tolerant life thrives year round. You can also see the effects of fires that have passed through, leaving the forest healthier and stronger.

You can also continue past the overlook on a more difficult 2.6-mile unpaved hike to the Park Ridge Fire Lookout. If the lookout volunteers are in, they may give you access and a tour of the view.

Accessibility

The half-mile trail to the viewing area is accessible, leading visitors to a stunning view overlooking the Sierra Nevada. The trail leads up a moderately-sloped path with cross slopes that may be difficult for some individuals to navigate.

The area also has an accessible parking stall, restrooms, and picnic tables.

Winter Access

To access this area in winter, you will need to hike, snowshoe, or ski into the area.
data.audioDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "A Remarkable Range", shows photos and text about the landscape in front of you. A background photo shows the sweeping view of the mountain ranges and canyons below. A large lake is seen in the valley. The following peaks are identified from left to right: Spanish Mountain at 10,051 feet. Obelisk at 9,700 feet. Mt. Goddard at 13,568 feet. Kettle Dome at 9,446 feet and, below it, Tombstone Ridge. North Palisade at 14,242 feet and, below it, Monarch Divide. Near the bottom of the photo, labels identify Hume Lake at 5,200 feet and two canyons just above the lake: the South Fork of the Kings River, in the canyon closest to the lake, and the Middle Fork of the Kings River, in the next canyon back. A topographic map shows a large dot where the Obelisk is located, at the top of a mountain. Two lines connect to this dot. The caption reads, The Obelisk. Park boundaries stretch to include this granite dome along the far western edge of Kings Canyon National Park. A black and white photo shows a line of mules, harnessed with large sacks on their backs, walking up a steep snow covered slope. Two men on horses lead them. The caption reads, Mapping Mt. Goddard. In the early 1900s, cartographers and their mules scaled these rugged snow covered peaks to map the area. A photo shows a group of people sitting on rocks at the shore of a large lake. Conifers line the edges of the lake. In the distance is a gently sloping rocky mountain with a few scattered trees. The caption reads, Hume Lake This reservoir in Sequoia National Forest hosts a public campground, a private camp, and a community of cabins. (266 words) A photo of rocky, jagged mountain peaks, that look orange in the later afternoon light. The caption reads, North Palisade at sunset At 14,242 feet (or 4341 m), this peak is the third highest in the Sierra Nevada and the tallest in Kings Canyon National Park.

data.title: Panoramic Point Picnic Area and Trailhead
data.listingDescription: Take this fairly easy half-mile hike to Panoramic Point and a great view of the Kings Canyon, Hume Lake, and the mountains beyond. It offers one of the best places to get a view of the effects that millions of years of erosion, and especially the Ice Age, have had on Kings Canyon. The trail to Panoramic Point is paved, with gentle slopes. You can continue past there to the Park Ridge Fire Lookout, another 2.5 miles of unpaved trail.

images.altText: A metal sign stands next to a partially shade covered asphalt trail.
images.title: Panoramic Point Trailhead
images.caption: A trail sign located on Panoramic Point

data.bodyText:
Take this fairly easy half-mile hike to Panoramic Point and a great view of the Kings Canyon, Hume Lake, and the mountains beyond. It offers one of the best places to get a view of the effects that millions of years of erosion, and especially the Ice Age, have had on Kings Canyon. The trail to Panoramic Point is paved, with gentle slopes. You can continue past there to the Park Ridge Fire Lookout, another 2.5 miles of unpaved trail.

Area Information

At the parking area are vault toilets, picnic tables, and food-storage boxes. Be aware that the road to the trailhead is narrow; drive it slowly and carefully. Motor homes and trailers are not permitted.

Accessibility

This quarter-mile paved trail trail offers benches and pullouts along the route. At Panoramic Point, there are accessible wayside exhibits and ample space to turn around. For the easiest climb, begin near the restroom and stay to the left at each trail junction, then return the same way. Along that route, the average trail grade is 6.5%.

Winter Access

To access this area in winter, you will need to hike, snowshoe, or ski into the area.
data.audioDescription: This exhibit is titled, "Panoramic Point Trail". This panel shows a map and photos of the Trail. It also has safety information. The text explains that most a broad view out over of Kings Canyon National Park can be seen from Panoramic Point. There are two short trails to the overlook. One is accessible. Much of the landscape is wilderness, one of the highest forms of legal protection. The map shows the Grant Grove Area, with a Panoramic Point Trail map inset. One photo shows a tree-filled valley with mountains in the distance, described as the view from Panoramic Point, elevation 7,500 feet, about half a mile away on either trail. It explains that views reach to the crest of the Sierra Nevada mountain range. Another photo shows a small wood building on a wood pole structure with windows on all sides and a U.S. flag, described as Park Ridge Fire Lookout, 2.8 miles from here. When no staff is present, the lookout is closed to the public. A photo at the bottom shows another view from Panoramic Point, of a tree-lined ridge with snow-capped peaks in the distance. A quote by Edward Abbey: "We need wilderness whether or not we ever set foot in it..." Safety text says: Store food properly to keep bears wild. Do not store food or scented items in your vehicle. Store them in metal food-storage boxes or bring them with you. Travel Lightly: Trails here are for day-use only. Overnight trips are not permitted. Pets and wheeled vehicles are prohibited. Firearms are subject to state and local regulations. Discharge of a firearm is prohibited within Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks. Wood fires are prohibited on this trail. As you travel, choose to act in ways that preserve the wilderness experience. Blend in. Keep noise to a minimum. Leave Indian artifacts, historical objects, and natural items such as pine cones where you find them. Don't construct fire rings trenches, or other "improvements." Don't introduce invasive species. Before hiking, clean seeds and mud from boots, laces, and equipment. Wilderness Safety: People traveling in wilderness areas should be very self-reliant. Immediate rescue is rarely possible. The responsibility to understand natural hazards and to travel safely lies with you. Plan your trip carefully. Carry a map. Be prepared. Creek crossings may be hazardous at any time. Bring drinking water or treat it. Never drink untreated water from lakes or streams. Know what to do in an emergency. Cell phones rarely work in most of the park. Carry and know how to use basic first aid gear. Be alert to falling objects. Take notice of snapping branches overhead, pay extra attention to windy or snowy conditions. If you encounter illegal activity, leave the area immediately and notify a ranger.

data.title: Paradise Creek Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Paradise Creek trailhead.

images.altText: a trailhead sign a burned area warning sign are located at the beginning of a trail.
images.title: Paradise Creek Trailhead
images.caption: Paradise Creek Trailhead

data.bodyText:
Paradise Creek Trail

Along the gentle climb through the foothills, you'll hike alongside a quiet creek that's shaded by riparian trees and shrubs. You can hike to the end of the trail, or walk as far as you'd like and then turn around. In summer, watch carefully for poison oak and avoid touching its "leaves of three." Many hikers prefer to spend time here in fall, winter, and spring, when temperatures are cool. In spring, wildflowers are varied and lovely. In spring or after storms, take care with creek crossings and turn back if it doesn't seem safe.

The trailhead is in Buckeye Flat Campground. In winter, the road to the campground is closed to vehicles and you can begin your hike at Hospital Rock Picnic Area. Walk along the road to the campground and look for the trailhead as you enter.

Education Programs

The Sierra Newt, a native Californian amphibian, calls the foothills home. Newts descend from the hillsides throughout the winter and early spring to reach their breeding pools, which form as snowmelt cascades down the mountains.

Interested in learning more? Join a park ranger on a curriculum-based field trip to study the phenology, or timing, of newt migration. Tracking the timing of breeding cycles gives scientists critical insight into how the lives of plants and animals are impacted by the changing climate.

Call 559-565-4211 or email seki_ritc@nps.gov to learn more about the community-science field trip opportunities offered at Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks.
data.audioDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Paradise Creek trailhead. The text reads, Gentle Paradise Canyon contrasts sharply with tis surrounding terrain. The trail crosses Middle Fork Bridge then parallels and crosses Paradise Creek. Crossing the creek, however, may be difficult. The trail grows quite faint in some areas, and can be hard to find. Turn back unless you are prepared for route-finding and creek crossings. Like almost all park trails, Paradise Creek Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of legal protection, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to enjoy. A map of the foothills area shows our location at the beginning of the Paradise trail. A safety warning indicates that rattlesnakes and ticks are common in the foothills. The top photo shows a tree filled valley. A gentle creek with large rocks surges through it. The caption reads, Paradise Creek 3.0 miles (or 4.8 km) one way to end of trail Two photos of poison oak: "Spring" shows a branch with leaf clusters of three. The pointed leaves have yellow centers deepening to orange with red tips. "Summer" shows a close up of a cluster of three green, pointed, leaves. The caption reads, Poison oak is abundant along this trail. This plant causes itchy rashes a few days after it touches your skin. Look for shrubs or vines with leaves of three. If you come in contact, wash the area with cool, soapy water. The bottom photo shows a tree lined ridge, with a granite dome visible in the distance to the right. The caption reads, View from Paradise Creek, with Moro Rock on the ridge to the right. A quote by Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas: "Walking the wilderness is indeed like living."

Located between the Giant Forest Museum and Lodgepole Visitor Center, the Pinewood Picnic Area offers regular and long picnic tables for groups of all sizes. The picnic areas also has restrooms, a water faucet, and barbecue grills.

Accessibility

An accessible picnic area is available with designated parking and an extended picnic table on a level, paved surface with a path to an accessible restroom. A standard, barbeque grill has limited ground clearance, and may be difficult to navigate for picnickers with mobility devices. Some other picnic areas have extended tables, and may be reached by paved ramp or dirt trail.

Program information is also available at visitor centers.

images.title: Potwisha Amphitheater
images.caption: Potwisha Amphitheater

data.bodyText:
Up to 50 people can enjoy a ranger-led programs at the Potwisha Campground Amphitheater. Parking is located across the street from the campground. For evening programs, please watch your footing and remember to bring a flashlight. A sign at the front of the campground, posts current program times. Program information is also available at visitor centers.

Safety

Parking is located across the street from the Potwisha Amphitheater-use caution when crossing the road, especially after sunset. For evening programs, remember to bring a flashlight.
data.audioDescription: From the campground at Loop Road, a dirt path leads you to the Potwisha Amphitheater, about 150 feet away. At the start of the path, a large rectangular metal sign on wood posts reads, "Amphitheatre" with an arrow pointing to the right. A symbol icon shows a human figure, from the waist up, in the center, with three curved lines radiating out from its waist. A frame with program information is attached to the center of the sign. Along the bottom of the sign are two rectangular panels attached with metal hooks that can swing up to reveal program information. You are surrounded by Buckeye and Live Oak trees. When you reach the Amphitheater area, to the left there is an open dirt area for presentations and a campfire pit on the ground, enclosed by large rocks. On the right is the seating area. Two sets of long benches are angled inward to face the presentation area, creating a "V" with a five-foot-wide aisle running down the center. There are three benches on each side of that aisle. Wood posts with lights provide lighting on the path and at the Amphitheater. A metal bear-safe storage box is located at the back of the seating area.

data.title: Potwisha Day Use Area
data.listingDescription: This day use area features river access, as well as overflow parking for Potwisha Campground, Potwisha Amphitheater guests, and additional parking for Marble Falls hikers.

images.altText: A small building and dirt parking lot at Potwisha Day Use Area
images.title: Potwisha Day Use Area
images.caption: Potwisha Day Use Area

data.bodyText:
This day use area features river access, as well as overflow parking for Potwisha Campground, Potwisha Amphitheater guests, and additional parking for Marble Falls hikers. A recreational vehicle dump station is located adjacent to the overflow parking and day use area.

If you visit the river, be aware that drowning is the leading cause of deaths in our parks. Slips from polished marble boulders are common, currents are swift, and the water is especially cold in spring and early summer.

The KNP Complex Fire: What factors affect fire behavior? 

On the other side of the highway, you can see distant ridgelines. Some are blackened or ashen, others have browned trees. The 2021 KNP Complex Fire burned here at varying intensities based on numerous factors. 

Fire behavior, or how a fire burns, is affected by a number of things. 

  • Weather and climate: temperature, relative humidity, amount of precipitation prior to or during a fire, and periods of drought affect when, where, and how fires burn. 

  • Topography: the steepness slopes or the direction they face; fire tends to burn faster and often at higher intensity when moving up steep slopes, especially drier south-facing slopes.  

  • Time since last fire: more time means more buildup of sticks, leaves, and duff, and greater density of trees and shrubs. 

  • The type of vegetation that is burning: grasses, when dry, carry fast-moving fire. Chaparral shrubs support intense fires that typically kill most or all nearby vegetation, but later resprouts from below-ground roots or seeds in the soil. Oaks or California buckeye are more likely to survive fire and re-seed or re-sprout afterwards.

data.title: Prime Sequoia Habitat
data.listingDescription: This outdoor exhibit, titled "Prime Sequoia Habitat," shows an illustrated map and photos of Round Meadow and Big Trees Trail.

images.altText: A outdoor exhibit sign sits in front of a wooden fence line, with a meadow in the background.
images.title: Prime Sequoia Habitat Outdoor Exhibit
images.caption: Prime Sequoia Habitat Outdoor Exhibit

data.bodyText: This outdoor exhibit, titled "Prime Sequoia Habitat," shows an illustrated map and photos of Round Meadow and Big Trees Trail.
data.audioDescription:
The View: You are standing at the right-hand entrance to Big Trees Trail. Just beyond a roughhewn wood stacked fence is a large meadow. Sequoia trees line the path that stretches ahead along the right side of the meadow.

On the upper corners of this wayside exhibit frame are tactile sequoia cones made of brass. The cones have been flattened on the bottom to help secure them to the frames. Most wayside exhibits on this trail have similar cones.

A background photo, taken from the meadow, shows a dense line of sequoias against a dark sky.

The text reads,

Prime Sequoia Habitat

Welcome to one of the best places on earth for giant sequoias. In Giant Forest sequoias grow bigger than anywhere else, and Round Meadow is one of the best sequoia habitats within Giant Forest.

As you circle Round Meadow on the Big Trees Trail, notice where these magnificent trees thrive and where they do not. Where are they largest? Where are they absent? As you walk the trail you can learn what factors determine where sequoias grow.

The map shows a long, rough oval shape with the words "Round Meadow" in the center. Surrounding the shape is a series of dots that cross each other at the bottom edge of Round Meadow, indicating a loop trail. The words "You are Here" are above and to the right of where the dots cross. The text reads,

Big Trees Trail
Distance 0.6 miles (or 1.0 km)

Accessibility

The trail is very flat with no steps. It is paved except for small stretches of wooden boardwalk.

Additional text reads,

In memory of John Palmer.

The Big Trees Trail is dedicated to John Palmer, Chief Park Interpreter from 1969 to 1987. His vision, a Giant Forest preserved for the sequoias and the people who want to experience them, has finally come.

Additional wayside exhibits along this trail will be described as if you are continuing on this trail to the right and circling the meadow counterclockwise.

data.title: Protecting Scenery
data.listingDescription: This exhibit shows the effects air pollution has on the park.

images.altText: An exhibit sign mounted on a stone base discusses air pollution in the parks.
images.title: Protecting Scenery Exhibit
images.caption: Learn how regional air pollution affects Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks.

data.bodyText: This exhibit shows the effects air pollution has on the park.
data.audioDescription:
Text is shown in English and Spanish, but for this audio description we will only read English.

This wayside is titled "Meeting the National Park Mission: Protecting Scenery."

A photo of the view in front of you, layers of ridgelines of foothills, covered in trees and shrubs that stretch into the distance, quickly disappearing into hazy gray smog. A dashed line near what would be the horizon indicates the location of the Coast Range. Text superimposed on the photo shows that the Coast Range is about 100 miles away, and is visible only on clear days.

The text reads,

Named for the rows of rugged ridges visible on clear days, Eleven Range Overlook offers great views day and night. At times, however, two kinds of pollution from outside the park affect the view. Polluted air blurs scenery and harms trees. Unnatural light turns night skies gray and dims the stars. Your help in reducing these pollutants outside the park protects the scenery here.

Two photos show the same close-up of a ridgeline. In one photo, the scene behind the ridge is all gray. In the other photo, many ridges are visible in the distance.

The caption reads,

Limited Scenery

Summer smog rises into the park, obscuring vistas. Photographs (right) show the same view on a smoggy and a clear day from the western edge of the Giant Forest.

A photo shows long thin pine needles, green with yellow spots along the shaft.

The caption reads,

Ponderosa pine

A photo shows a close up of a wide leaf. It has large splotches of yellow and red.

The caption reads,

Black oak

The text reads,

Ozone damage weakens trees

Ozone damage causes yellow spots on leaves. As a result, trees cannot create as much energy through photosynthesis. Air pollution affects many of the trees you see here.

An aerial photo shows the United States as seen from space at night. White lights in urban areas clearly indicate the shape of the United States, as well as Mexico, Central America, the top of South America, and islands in the Caribbean Ocean.

The caption reads,

Dimmed Stars
Light pollution affects the night sky. If more lights were aimed only downward, light from millions of stars would shine more brightly.

Text reads,

Help the park fulfill its mission
Protect scenery, natural and historic objects, and wildlife. Enjoy them in ways that leave the parks unimpaired for future generations.
On the top right corner is the National Park Service logo.

data.title: Protection: Past and Future
data.listingDescription: Activities outside the parks affect life here. By working in our home towns to prevent air pollution and fight climate change, we contribute to preserving these awe-inspiring trees. These parks feel inputs from as close as the San Joaquin Valley and the San Francisco Bay Area to as far away as China. Where does the air in your town travel before it arrives?

images.altText: A metal panel sits in a metal frame. On the metal panel are text and images.
images.title: Protection Past and Future
images.caption: How will the park be protected in the future?

data.bodyText: Activities outside the parks affect life here. By working in our home towns to prevent air pollution and fight climate change, we contribute to preserving these awe-inspiring trees. These parks feel inputs from as close as the San Joaquin Valley and the San Francisco Bay Area to as far away as China. Where does the air in your town travel before it arrives?
data.audioDescription: A photo of a contemporary ranger in uniform and hat, looking toward a giant sequoia. As she stands in a sunlit patch, her figure is dwarfed by the trees surrounding her. The text reads, Protection: Past and Future Are sequoias safe? No longer can a national park guarantee absolute protection of the natural systems these trees rely on. Air pollution affects young sequoias trying to grow skyward. Climate change may heat or dry this area too much for these sensitive trees. By facing these challenges, we can work to protect this symbol of endurance and its forest community. On the right side of the exhibit, there is a recessed rectangular area with tactile graphics of a National Park Service logo and leather hat band. On top is the logo, in the shape of a brown arrowhead, point downward. Inside that arrowhead, a green sequoia tree shape is cut out and recessed. The rest of the illustration is not tactile. It includes the words, "National Park Service." Near the bottom of the arrowhead is a white buffalo silhouette, set against a green meadow, with a white lake and a snow-capped mountain behind it. Below this is a band, running on an angle across the lower right corner. It has a raised parallel ridge along each edge, and four raised sequoia cone shapes within those ridges. Thin needle-like ridges, representing sequoia leaves, can be felt between the cones. The text reads, Symbol of the Service Three of the first four national parks protected giant sequoias. As a result, the NPS arrowhead logo features a sequoia silhouette. Embossed sequoia cones decorate the belts and hatbands of park rangers nationwide.

data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Redwood Mountain Trail area.The Redwood Mountain Trail is 9.5 mile loop (15 km) at a moderate incline. It takes you along the ridge above Redwood Canyon for spectacular views as well as along the canyon floor among the trees. The trail is lightly used, so you may be able to experience solitude on this hike.

images.altText: Redwood Canyon Trailhead Sign
images.title: Redwood Canyon Trailhead
images.caption: Redwood Canyon Trailhead

data.bodyText:
Trail closed until further notice due to the KNP Complex Wildfire.

This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Redwood Mountain Trail area.

The Redwood Mountain Trail is 9.5 mile loop (15 km) at a moderate incline. It takes you along the ridge above Redwood Canyon for spectacular views as well as along the canyon floor among the trees. The trail is lightly used, so you may be able to experience solitude on this hike.

Relatively few people visit the Redwood Mountain sequoia grove. The trails take you along the ridge above Redwood Canyon for spectacular views as well as along the canyon floor among the trees. The trailhead is two miles from Highway 180 down a sometimes rough, unpaved road; take it slowly. Once you arrive, you can take a short walk or an overnight trip (for overnights a wilderness permit is required).

Redwood Mountain Grove, Post-Fire: What to Expect

This grove burned in the 2021 KNP Complex Fire. Forty percent of the grove burned at moderate to high fire severity, and many giant sequoias were killed. 

Redwood Mountain Grove is a very large grove noted for its old growth sequoias and diversity of other plants. In the spring, wildflowers are a highlight both along the ridge trail and along Redwood Creek. In the fall, the dogwood shrubs turn a deep red color, and the fall light provides good photo opportunities. Visitors to this grove will see evidence of wildfire in fire-killed trees, more open forests, and we hope, giant sequoia seedling regeneration as well as re-sprouting wildflowers and shrubs.

Visit the KNP Complex Fire web page, to learn more about this fire.

Services Nearby

Parking, vault toilets, and bear boxes are available.
data.audioDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Redwood Canyon Trail area. The text reads, These trails wind through Redwood Mountains Grove and the largest area of unlogged sequoia forest on Earth. It was here that scientists in the mid 1960s discovered the strong, fascinating connection between healthy sequoia groves and natural fire cycles. Watch for signs of fire and regrowth as you walk. Like most park trails, Redwood Canyon trails lead into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Several loops offer opportunities for short or long hikes. Possible destinations include: A photo shows a group of giant reddish-brown sequoia trunks. The caption reads, Sugar Bowl Loop. 6.5 miles (or 10.5 km) round trip. Elevation gain: 1,480 feet (or 450 m). The name comes from the Sugar Bowl Group, a dense stand of mature sequoias along the trail. This walk is slightly steeper than the Hart Tree Loop, with a short series of switchbacks near the creek. A photo of massive giant sequoia with a deeply furrowed trunk and a deep fire scar. The caption reads, Hart Tree and Fallen Goliath Loop 7.3 miles (or 11.8 km) round trip. Elevation gain: 1,100 feet (or 335 m). Named for a man who located it in the 1880s, the Hart Tree is one of the 25 largest sequoias. Watch along this trail for evidence of limited logging that took place in the 1870s. Combine this trail with the Sugar Bowl Loop for a longer hike of 9.8 miles (or 15.8 km). A map shows the location of the Redwood Mountain Trailhead. A bottom photo shows the view from a ridge, lined with sequoia trees. In the distance are tree covered mountains. The caption reads, Redwood Mountain A quote by Honoré de Balzac, "Who...can walk in a forest without the forest speaking to him?"

data.title: Redwood Mountain Overlook
data.listingDescription: This overlook is just west of the Redwood Mountain Road, along the Generals Highway. Before you lies one of the largest groves of giant sequoia trees in the world. From this overlook, you can see the tops of sequoias, the canopy of the Redwood Mountain grove. It was here that park scientists began to understand the importance of fire in the ecology of forests. The trunks of large giant sequoias trees are almost always marked by fire scars at ground level.

images.altText: Rounded and pointed treetops with lower hills in the distance
images.caption: Mature sequoias with rounded tops and younger "spire-top" sequoias

data.bodyText:
This overlook is just west of the Redwood Mountain Road, along the Generals Highway. Before you lies one of the largest groves of giant sequoia trees in the world. From this overlook, you can see the tops of sequoias, the canopy of the Redwood Mountain grove.

It was here that park scientists began to understand the importance of fire in the ecology of forests. The trunks of large giant sequoias trees are almost always marked by fire scars at ground level, and their lower branches have been burned away. Their living limbs and needles grow hundreds of feet above the forest floor, where they are safe from most flames. Fire is necessary in order for sequoia cones to open and release their seeds. It is also necessary to clear away underbrush and give trees the space and sunlight they need to grow. Scientists and park managers have developed ways to use fire to maintain healthy ecosystems within the parks, including natural (lightning) fires and prescribed burns.

Redwood Canyon also houses thousands of dogwood trees. In spring and early summer, white blossoms cover their branches. In autumn, their foliage turns red, brown, and yellow. Light filtering through the leaves or blossoms creates an ever-changing atmosphere, so the experience of the canyon shifts with the seasons.
data.audioDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Meeting the National Park Mission: Protecting Natural Objects," shows photos and text about protecting sequoia health. The text reads, In front of you stands one of the world's largest groves of the world's largest trees. Redwood Mountain Grove covers five square miles with more than 2,100 giant sequoias larger than 10 feet in diameter. The National Park Service mission requires us to protect these "natural objects." How? We protect the natural processes that create the conditions that those objects require. In the case of sequoias, a process that holds the key to survival is fire. Without it, these giant trees cannot regenerate. A photo of a tree covered mountain range. Sequoia trees in the foreground have differing shapes. A few with pointed cone shaped tops are identified as young "spiretop" sequoias. A sequoia tree with rounded full branches at the top is identified as a mature sequoia. A giant sequoia, with massive branches and abundant foliage, has a dead branch at its top. It is identified as a "snagtop". The caption reads, Shape reveals the life stage of a sequoia. Young sequoias grow into graceful spires as they race toward the sunlight. Mature sequoias show smooth clumps of foliage. The tops of the trunks eventually die, giving the oldest trees the nickname "snagtops." A photo shows a green forest with a low fire burning around the bases of giant sequoia trees. A firefighter walks near the base of a sequoia. The firefighter wears a yellow shirt, a yellow plastic helmet, and a backpack. The caption reads, The earliest efforts to use fire to benefit sequoias started here. In the 1960s, scientists first learned how much sequoias need fire: Sequoia seeds rain down after fires. These seeds survive best in burned forest clearings. Small, frequent fires create optimum conditions for large sequoias, too. They clear the forest of competing trees and remove fuel that would feed unnaturally hot wildfires. Two black and white photos of other sequoias, photographed from the same position at different times. A photo from 1890 shows several sequoias. Park workers stand next to the enormous trunks. A photo from 1970 shows the same sequoia trees with thick clusters of young fir trees growing around the trunks. The text reads, Compare these photos. In 1890, when fires burned naturally, the forest floor was clear. In 1970, after years of fire suppression, undergrowth chokes the same forest. Additional text reads, Help the park fulfill its mission. Protect scenery, natural and historic objects, and wildlife. Enjoy them in ways that leave the parks unimpaired for future generations.

data.title: Restoring Dark Skies
data.listingDescription: This exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, Restoring Dark Skies," shows an evening view from Moro Rock and a filtered image of light pollution to the west.

images.altText: A sign titled Restoring Dark Skies features text and images about light pollution in the parks.
images.title: Restoring Dark Skies Exhibit
images.caption: Restoring Dark Skies exhibit

data.bodyText: This exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, Restoring Dark Skies," shows an evening view from Moro Rock and a filtered image of light pollution to the west.
data.audioDescription:
The View: In front of you is a view of mountain peaks, with thick, dark green conifer forests at lower elevations. The lower foothills are a lighter olive green with short vegetation. Often there is a haze over the valley to the right. To your left, above the mountain peaks it's clearer.

The background image on the exhibit is a long-exposure photo from the walkway at the top of Moro Rock. The rock is silhouetted in black as the handrails reflect the last sunlight. The mountains beyond take on a textured gray against the last glow of sunset behind them, the upper sky is dark. The stars appear as hundreds of white curved lines streaking across the dark sky.

The text reads,

Daytime views from here reach miles into the wilderness. At night, you can see even farther. In the dark, our universe reveals itself in uncountable stars.

Why protect dark skies? For nocturnal animals, who need darkness to live. For diurnal wildlife, who seek safety in the night. For knowledge gained from telescopes that require darkness to probe the cosmos. And for you to enjoy the fascination, beauty, and inspiration of the heavens.

Dark skies grow rarer as artificial light spills across the landscape from afar, as shown by the late night long exposure above. Today's improved lighting, however, can help. Fixtures that focus light downward, rather than up and out, save energy and restore darkness, even miles away.

An image shows a rainbow spectrum of colors depicting a view toward the west. Five cities are identified across the bottom. Each city creates a warm color, that morphs into a cooler color in the higher atmosphere. The cities from left to right:

Los Angeles, 169 miles, 272 km. Red

Bakersfield, 83 miles, 133 km. Orange

Porterville, 36 miles, 58 km. Orange

Visalia, 34 miles, 55 km. Red

Fresno, 60 miles, 96 km. Purple

The caption reads,

This filtered image of the late-night view to the west from Moro Rock shows sources of artificial light. Cities in San Joaquin Valley and Los Angeles emit the most light (red).

Stop at Muir Rock, then choose a short walk around Zumwalt Meadow, or a longer hike to Roaring River Falls. A photo of a grassy meadow, lined with trees, with steep mountains surrounding it. The caption reads, Zumwalt Meadow. 2.2 miles (or 2.4 km) around meadow loop. This loop offers a close up look at a lush mountain meadow, and expansive views of the towering peaks that surround it. To reach the wheelchair accessible portions of the trail, drive back to the Zumwalt Meadow parking area and begin there. A photo of a white waterfall, surging through a rocky chute. The caption reads, Roaring River Falls. 2.8 miles (or 4.5 km) one way. The roar from this powerful waterfall is loudest in early summer. Mist makes rocks slippery and dangerous; be very cautious near the water. A map shows the location of the River Trail Trailhead. The bottom photo is of a tree filled valley, with steep rocky mountains surrounding it. The caption reads, A view from Zumwalt Meadow. A quote from an "unknown" source, "... From the mighty peaks to the smallest of the tiny flowers hidden in the meadow's grass."

data.title: Road's End Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Road's End Trail area.Road's End is the start of some great hiking adventures. Looking for relatively easy, flat hiking? Try the Zumwalt Meadows Loop, or make a longer day hike to Roaring River Falls. If you want to gain elevation, hike one of the trails that lead to Bubbs Creek, Mist Falls, Paradise Valley, and Copper Creek.

images.altText: A small brown building sits in the shade of tall trees. A dumpster stands in front of it
images.title: Roads End Trailhead
images.caption: Many backcountry trips start from this location.

data.bodyText:
Highway 180 closes for the winter in mid-November. Access to this area typically reopens the fourth Friday in April; reopening is conducted by CalTrans. 

This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Road's End Trail area.

Road's End is the start of some great hiking adventures. Looking for relatively easy, flat hiking? Try the Zumwalt Meadows Loop, or make a longer day hike to Roaring River Falls. If you want to gain elevation, hike one of the trails that lead to Bubbs Creek, Mist Falls, Paradise Valley, and Copper Creek. These tougher hikes climb out of the valley floor quickly, but offer spectacular views of the canyon and rivers. As you climb into the high country, you will pass through a number of different ecosystems and life zones on the way to subalpine forests. Be sure to stay hydrated as the canyon is hot and dry in summer.

Kings Canyon is also a very active bear area. Be sure to stow anything with a scent in the food storage lockers. Bears have a keen sense of smell and can cause significant damage to your vehicle.
data.audioDescription: Exhibit One: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Woods Creek and Bubbs Creek Trails area. The text reads, Welcome to where roads end and trails begin. Walk a few hours, or hike farther into a glorious wilderness ruled by elevation and climate. Like most park trails, these lead into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Possible destinations include: Via Woods Creek Trail. A photo of a cascading waterfall, surging through rocks. The caption reads, Mist falls. 3.9 miles (or 6.3 km) one way. Elevation: 5,840 feet (or 1780 m). As the name suggests, mist from this powerful cascade surrounds the area of the falls. The trail and nearby rocks can be slippery here, especially in early summer when the river is at its peak flow. Be extremely careful. Via Bubbs Creek Trail, A photo of a pass through a rocky ridge, with a rounded crag to the left, and a pointed steep crag to its right. Low shrubs and a few conifer trees dot the landscape. The caption reads, Sphinx Creek. 4.1 miles (or 6.6 km) one way. Elevation: 6,240 feet (or 1902 m). Towering over the canyon floor, the Sphinx evokes images of Egypt's giant statues. John Muir named the formation in the later 1800s. A map shows the location of the Woods Creek and Bubbs Creek Trailhead. The bottom photo shows a hillside of large foxtail pines, with a snow-covered mountain range in the distance. The caption reads, Above Vidette Meadow, A quote by Shel Silverstein, "There is a place where the sidewalk ends..." Exhibit Two: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Rae Lakes Loop area. The text reads, One of the most popular loops in the Sierra Nevada begins here. The Rae Lakes loop travels 41.2 miles (or 66.3 km) through rugged canyons and alpine wilderness. Part of the loop parallels the Sierra Crest, sharing the tread of the Pacific Crest and John Muir trails. Because of the large number of hikers on the Rae Lakes Loop, special restrictions apply. Extra care with storing food from bears is required. Keep the camping restrictions in mind as you plan your trip. Above all, choose to act in ways that preserve the wild character of this remarkable place. Six photographs with captions, from left to right, and top to bottom: A photo of a tree filled valley, with rocks and patches of snow, and mountains in the distance. Middle Paradise Valley is 6.8 miles (or 10.9 km) clockwise. A photo of two deep blue lakes, ringed by trees with a granite dome in the distance. Middle Rae Lake is 22.7 miles (or 36.5 km) clockwise. A photo of a sunlit meadow, dotted with large conifer trees. Vidette Meadow is 28.2 miles (or 45.5 km) clockwise. A photo of trees with bright yellow leaves, a conifer forest, and steep mountains with patches of snow beyond. Woods Creek Crossing is 15.7 miles (or 25.3 km) clockwise. A photo from a rocky ridge, looking down at three turquoise blue lakes. Glen Pass is 24.6 miles (or 39.6 km) clockwise. A photo of a lush green meadow, lined with conifers, with steep granite cliffs in the distance. Junction Meadow is 31.1 miles (or 50.1 km) clockwise. The text reads, Clockwise or counterclockwise? Choose the direction of your hike before getting a wilderness permit. Most people travel the Rae Lakes Loop in the clockwise direction. More time is spent climbing, but the ascents are more gradual, especially along the approach to Glen Pass. Hiking in a counterclockwise direction results in steeper climbs. Most of the elevation gain comes early in the trip. A map shows the location of the Rae Lakes Loop with trails marked. The bottom photo is a calm lake, with granite Fin Dome towering above the left horizon.

data.title: Roaring River Falls
data.listingDescription: Roaring River flows from Deadman and Cloud canyons deep in the parks' wilderness, then crashes down a narrow chute into a pool. The power and sound of the waterfall changes through the year, and is at its biggest and loudest in late spring and early summer. From here, you can also take a relaxing walk along the River Trail to Zumwalt Meadow. This walk is 3.9 miles round-trip in a lollipop shape at an easy, paved incline.

images.altText: A powerful chute of water flows into a dark blue pool. Surrounded by high rock walls
images.title: Roaring River Falls
images.caption: Roaring River Falls

data.bodyText:
Access to this area via Highway 180 closes for the winter in mid-November. Access typically reopens the fourth Friday in April; reopening is conducted by CalTrans. 

Roaring River flows from Deadman and Cloud canyons deep in the parks' wilderness, then crashes down a narrow chute into a pool. The power and sound of the waterfall changes through the year, and is at its biggest and loudest in late spring and early summer.

From here, you can also take a relaxing walk along the River Trail to Zumwalt Meadow. This walk is 3.9 miles round-trip in a lollipop shape at an easy, paved incline. The trail starts at the misty waterfall, then travels over creeks and through meadows and shady forests. Follow this short, shaded path to a powerful 40-foot waterfall. Look for the junction with the River Trail just a few feet away toward the parking area.

Safety


Don't be fooled if the pool appears calm and safe for swimming. The rocks are slippery and the currents below the surface of the water can easily drag you under. Drowning in rivers like this one is the most common cause of death in Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks.
data.audioDescription: A flat, paved viewing area is surrounded by a low, rocky wall. Listen for the sound of rushing water. In spring and early summer, you may feel the mist from the waterfall. Roaring River Falls is low, short, and powerful. White churning water rushes from a rocky chute. It falls into a wide, deep pool of dark water. The pool is almost completely surrounded by rock walls with a few small trees and shrubs growing from openings in the rock. More trees grow above the viewing area.

data.title: Sawtooth Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Sawtooth Trail area. Sawtooth Trail is a 10.2 mile (16.4 kilometer) loop trail at a steep incline. Beyond Monarch Lakes, the trail is rough and unmaintained. The first campsite is at Lower Monarch Lake at 4.2 miles (6.7 kilometer).

images.altText: A black and white photo of a rocky peak
images.caption: Sawtooth Peak. Photo by Kristian Calma.

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Sawtooth Trail area.

Sawtooth Trail is a 10.2 mile (16.4 kilometer) loop trail at a steep incline. Beyond Monarch Lakes, the trail is rough and unmaintained. The first campsite is at Lower Monarch Lake at 4.2 miles (6.7 kilometer).
data.audioDescription: The text reads, Mountain passes and vistas of remote High Sierra lie ahead. Monarch Lakes, lying on the boundary between granitic and metamorphic rock, create an inviting but chilly destination for hikers and backpackers. Like most park trails, the Sawtooth Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Possible destinations include: The top photo shows a brown rocky alpine, with pockets of snow. The caption reads, Monarch Lakes. 4.2 miles (or 6.8 km) one way. Elevation: 10,400 feet (or 3,170 m) to first lake. From valley floor to forest to rocky alpine, the trail brings you to Monarch Lakes at the foot of 12,343 foot Sawtooth Peak. Like several other small lakes in this area, Lower Monarch Lake has a small dam. The next photo of two ridges descending into a mountain pass covered with a grove of massive red firs in the shape of an inverted triangle. The caption reads, Timber Gap. 2.0 miles (or 3.2 km) one way. Elevation: 9,450 feet (or 2,880 m.) The views of Mineral King Valley are superb as you climb. At the gap itself, you stand in a grove of massive red firs. A map of the Mineral King area shows our location at Sawtooth trailhead. At the bottom is a photo of snow covered peaks and valleys. The caption reads, View toward Mineral King Valley from the Sawtooth Trail. A quote from The Wilderness Act of 1964: "...where the earth and its community of life are untrammeled by man..."

data.title: Sentinel Tree Interactive Ruler

images.altText: An outdoor walkway with a linear tile inset

data.bodyText: This interactive exhibit, titled "Sentinel Tree," is embedded in the rough surface of the pedestrian plaza in front of the Giant Forest Museum. Here, you can follow the path of the sidewalk ruler that marks the height of the Sentinel Tree found just above you.
data.audioDescription:
This interactive exhibit, titled "Sentinel Tree," is embedded in the rough surface of the pedestrian plaza in front of the Giant Forest Museum. It is like a smooth giant ruler that runs the length of the plaza, showing the height of the sequoia tree called The Sentinel, if it were lying on the ground. The height ruler is mostly made up of a long line of smooth, light grey cement paving stones that are each one foot square. So it is a ruler measuring feet, not inches!

The exhibit begins with a darker square representing the base of the tree. This square is located in the middle of the plaza, close to the museum entrance. This paving stone is etched with an illustration of the entire tree, and titled, "Ground Level on Sentinel Tree". There are arrows pointing at either side of the base of the tree. The text reads,

You are Here.
28 feet (or 8.5 meters) thick.

A shorter width ruler, perpendicular to the height ruler, crosses the plaza to show the tree's width of 28 feet (or 8.5 m). A dark stone paver at each side of this width ruler explains that the Sentinel tree measures 86 feet (or 26.2 m) around the circumference of the base.

After walking 20 feet (or 6 meters) further along the ruler on the plaza, another dark paver appears. It is again etched to show the full tree, but the arrows are now slightly higher up on the tree trunk. The text reads,

20 feet (or 6 m) up Sentinel Tree.
Imagine yourself here.
18 ft. (or 5.5 m) thick.

Every 20 feet, another dark paver appears, showing the tree, arrows, and text asking you to imagine yourself at that height along the trunk and saying how wide the tree is at that point.

The final dark paver reads,

257 ft. (or 78.5 m) up Sentinel Tree.
Imagine yourself at the top.

data.title: Sequoia Mather Plaque
data.listingDescription: A bronze plaque embedded in stone commemorates Stephen Tyng Mather, the first National Park Service Director. This spot is within walking distance from the Tunnel Log, where you will find limited parking and a trash can.

images.altText: A bronze plaque commemorating the contributions of Stephen Mather to the National Park Service.
images.title: Mather Plaque, Sequoia National Park
images.caption: Mather Plaque, Sequoia National Park

data.bodyText:
A bronze plaque embedded in stone commemorates Stephen Tyng Mather, the first National Park Service Director.

This spot is within walking distance from the Tunnel Log, where you will find limited parking and a trash can.
data.audioDescription: This plaque commemorates Stephen T. Mather. The relief plaque is made of weathered bronze and is mounted on a seven-foot-high, moss-covered boulder. The plaque height is roughly 4 feet and features a profile image of Stephen Mather. The surrounding forest contains a variety of firs, giant sequoias, dogwood trees, and currants. The plaque reads, Stephen Tyng Mather July 4, 1867-January 22, 1930 He laid the foundation of the National Park Service. Defining and establishing the policies under which its areas shall be developed and conserved unimpaired for future generations. There will never come an end to the good that he has done.

data.title: Sequoia National Park Entrance, North Boundary
data.listingDescription: This point marks the northern boundary of Sequoia National Park.

images.altText: large wooden sign reading "Sequoia National Park" in front of trees, next to a road

data.bodyText:
This point marks the northern boundary of Sequoia National Park. To the north, the Generals Highway passes through national forest lands. Just after Montecito Sequoia Lodge, the highway lies along the boundary between the national forest and Kings Canyon National Park, and then enters the park near Quail Flat.

If you're driving south, the highway enters Sequoia National Park here. You'll be in the national park until you pass the entrance station in the foothills and enter the town of Three Rivers.

Rules and regulations vary between the national parks and national forests. Check you park newspaper for details.

data.title: Sequoia National Park Historic Entrance Sign
data.listingDescription: This historic entrance sign was constructed in 1935 by Civilian Conservation Corps craftsmen based on a smaller design from a National Park Service architect.

images.altText: A large piece of wood is carved to resemble a Native American face
images.title: Sequoia National Park historic sign
images.caption: This historic sign is found by the Ash Mt. entrance station

data.bodyText:
Warning, this area burned in the recent KNP Complex Wildfire. Enter river trail here at your own risk. Stay on trail. Hazards include but not limited to falling trees or tree limbs, loose rocks, flash flooding, and debris flows. Portions of the trail may be blocked with debris. 

This historic entrance sign was constructed in 1935 by Civilian Conservation Corps craftsmen based on a smaller design from a National Park Service architect. Over time, the original sign has been updated and painted. A sequoia log four feet in diameter supports the sign, complete with sequoia bark.

History emanates from some objects. Sequoia National Park's entrance sign, with its powerful presence at the boundary, is one such antique. Its origins speak of varying aspects of our past. But is this sign, with its Indian head image, still appropriate for display today? Learn more about the story of the sign and the cultural history questions it raises today 

Accessibility

There is designated accessible parking at this scenic viewpoint. A paved sidewalk leads to the Historic Entrance Sign and views of the river.

Community Science

The foothills of the Sierra Nevada mountain range are home to the blue oak woodlands. Ongoing drought, inconsistent snowpack, wildfires, bark beetles, and other environmental factors place this sensitive ecosystem at risk. Park scientists closely monitor the blue oak trees to measure the growth, and death, of this important species.

Are you a middle school or high school student? Your class can join us in collecting data to learn more about blue oaks. Students work alongside park rangers to collect data in two oak plots here, serving as community scientists. They gain basic forestry skills and help the parks better understand this changing landscape.

Call 559-565-4211 or email seki_ritc@nps.gov to learn more about the community-science field trip opportunities offered at Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks.
data.audioDescription: The wooden Sequoia Historic Entrance Sign is painted brown. From the left you see a smoothly carved American Indian profile, facing the road, with a vividly painted headdress. A sloping forehead with a protruding black brow, prominent nose with flared nostril, chiseled cheek, closed firm lips, and a strong chin, shape the left edge of the sign. His eye is painted white with a black pupil. The headdress has a white band that curves around the forehead down to the ear area, decorated with six yellow triangles with white centers, outlined in black, in an alternating pattern. Above the white band are carved red "feathers" with black tips curving upward to merge into the top of the sign. His black hair braid has a wrap decorated with a triangle made up of three smaller white triangle shapes. To the right, the words "Sequoia National Park" are carved into the center of the sign, and the letters are painted white.

quickFacts.value: Generals Highway, just beyond Ash Mountain Entrance Station
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Sequoias Take Shape
data.listingDescription: This tactile outdoor exhibit, titled "Sequoias Take Shape," shows the growth stages of a sequoia tree.

images.altText: An exhibit sign discusses the shapes of various trees and includes tactile relief.
images.title: Sequoias Take Shape Tactile Sign
images.caption: The Sequoias Take Shape exhibit includes tactile relief.

data.bodyText:
Not every seed makes it to maturity. In fact, the vast majority never sprout. Those that do may start in a poor location and never get big. Each giant needs only to replace itself once, however, to maintain this grove.

This tactile outdoor exhibit, titled "Sequoias Take Shape," shows the growth stages of a sequoia tree.
data.audioDescription:
The View: In front of this exhibit are examples of sequoias in each stage of growth.

The exhibit has two indented rectangles with tactile images and text. Shapes in the left rectangle show early growth in life-sized scale. The text reads,

Sequoias Take Shape

You can't miss mature sequoias, given their immense size and cinnamon-colored bark. Like children, young sequoias represent the future of this forest community yet they often go unnoticed. Can you spot them?

On the left side of this rectangle, you can feel a raised oval, which is the outline of a sequoia cone, with about 20 tiny seeds below it.

The text reads,

Each cone holds about 200 seeds the size of oat flakes. They must land on bare soil to grow.

To the right of the cone is a seedling a few weeks old. If you feel the round top, it shows that the seed coat is still attached to the plant. The text reads,

The first leaves out of the seed are long and soft. Short, prickly needles grow the next year.

To the right of the seedling is a taller sapling, with short needles.

Moving right to the second indented rectangle, you will find the shape of more mature sequoias, shown at about one 200th of actual size.

On the left side is a spire-shaped young tree, filled with branches from top to bottom. The text reads,

Given plenty of water, these "teenagers" grow quickly upward. Pointy and cone-shaped, they have a grayish bark.

On the right side of this rectangle is an outline of a mature sequoia tree with a thick, bare, lower trunk, and short stubby branches near the top. The text reads,

As sequoias age, lower branches drop off and bark thickens. Their crowns of foliage grow rounded and irregular.

The Braille information provided on this exhibit has already been explained in this Audio Description.

data.title: Shedding Water
data.listingDescription: Listen carefully; you may hear the birds that nest here. Small swifts and swallows dart about in the air above this rock dome, especially near the top. They are hard to see so high in the air. Swifts are black with white bellies and long pointy wings. They make a high-pitched cheeping call that sounds like "swheey swheey." Swallows are brown with a red neck and short wings. Their calls are also high pitched and sound like, "twitter twitter".

images.altText: A metal panel sits on a metal railing high above the ground. In the distance mountains are visible
images.title: Shedding Water
images.caption: Quite the view from up here!

data.bodyText:
Listen carefully; you may hear the birds that nest here. Small swifts and swallows dart about in the air above this rock dome, especially near the top. They are hard to see so high in the air. Swifts are black with white bellies and long pointy wings. They make a high-pitched cheeping call that sounds like "swheey swheey." Swallows are brown with a red neck and short wings. Their calls are also high pitched and sound like, "twitter twitter". They also sometimes make squeaking or clicking sounds. You may also hear a peregrine falcon, calling "key, key, key, key."

This wayside exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, Shedding Water", shows photos about the importance of snow in the park.
data.audioDescription: The text reads, All seasons alter this view, but none as dramatically as winter. Snow smooths jagged rocks, pointy trees, and rough ground. Yet it means more than a change in scenery. Snow here equals water for the valley below. Farmers supported creation of Sequoia National Park in 1890. They knew that mountain snow sends water to thirsty people and crops downstream. They also knew that, without forests to hold the soil and slow the snowmelt, runoff would speed downward too early, too fast. Climate changes that may reduce snow pack concern farmers - and city planners- today. A photo of a tree and brush filled valley with a fast-moving blue green river. White caps encircle large rocks as it rushes along the rocky shore. The caption reads, A photo of this location on Moro Rock during winter, a glistening snow-covered peak has icicles hanging from a top perch. The white starburst sun shines over the snow dusted valley below, a sparkling river flowing through it. Mountain peaks layer the distant landscape. Almost all the land you can see from here lies in the Kaweah watershed. Watershed means an area where all water on or under it drains to the same place. The Kaweah River's water - billions of gallons - flows to the southern San Joaquin Valley.

quickFacts.value: Moro Rock in Giant Forest, Sequoia National Park
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Shifting Stone
data.listingDescription: This outdoor exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, Shifting Stone," shows photos and text about granite layers of Moro Rock.

images.altText: An outdoor exhibit on Moro Rock Trail
images.title: Shifting Stone exhibit
images.caption: An outdoor exhibit on Moro Rock Trail

data.bodyText: This outdoor exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, Shifting Stone," shows photos and text about granite layers of Moro Rock.
data.audioDescription:
The View: You are at the edge of a dizzyingly steep cliff hundreds of feet high!

A photo of a steep view upward to the top of Moro Rock from where you stand. Large layers of gray speckled granite, like large scales, are seen on the rock's face. A large v shaped surface has a tinge of light orange that darkens near the bottom. Stairs, with a handrail lead up the side of the dome. The caption reads,


Look at the rock above you for evidence of exfoliation. Numerous rock layers that have yet to break free loom overhead. Some have separated from the main rock but still lie on the surface. Exfoliation produces the round shape of Moro Rock.

The text reads,

Granite describes something hard and unchanging. Yet bit by bit, the mass of granite that forms Moro rock splits like the layers of an onion and huge slabs detach. When a layer peels off, it frees the granite below of its huge weight. The next layer may in turn expand and separate from the parent rock. This exfoliation shrinks Moro Rock gradually, making it smaller than it was in times past-and larger now than it may be the next time you visit.

A photo of an enormous granite rock slab covering a steep rocky hillside, surrounded by pines and firs. The caption reads,

Scan the view behind you for this rockslide. In the 1990s, a slab broke loose and crashed onto the Generals Highway. It blocked the road until the park staff blasted it into smaller pieces and removed it. Throughout the parks, rocks of various sizes are always on the move, changing our views in ways we may or may not notice.

data.title: Sun Worshipers
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Sun Worshipers," shows how sequoias use the sun.

images.altText: Small wayside sign explaining the meaning of Sun Worshipers
images.title: Sun Worshipers
images.caption: Sun Worshipers Sign

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Sun Worshipers," shows how sequoias use the sun.
data.audioDescription:
The View: To your left are the grasses of Round Meadow and to your right are the sequoias of Giant Forest. The exhibit faces the meadow. Tree trunks and branches in various stages of decay litter the forest floor around you.

On the wayside panel is a photo of the meadow and the sequoia grove that surrounds it. The taller sequoias have reddish trunks with no branches until halfway up. Smaller trees have branches all the way to the ground, like a Christmas tree.

A caption at the tree tops reads,

Mature Sequoia
Over 250 feet (or 76m) tall, the round tops of these monarchs tower over the forest. There are several mature trees in this view.

A caption next to the two prominent smaller sequoias reads,

Young Sequoia
These "spire tops," about 100 years old and 100 feet (or 30 m) or more tall, are difficult to distinguish because they blend in with other tree species.

The text reads,

Sun Worshipers

Look across the meadow for a view of sunbathing sequoias. Young sequoias have branches all the way down their trunks, gathering as much solar energy as they can. Their pointed tops grow quickly toward the sun.

As sequoias grow taller, they lose lower branches due to fire or lack of sun. Once the trees rise above the rest of the forest canopy, their pointed crowns round off. Dead tops mark the oldest sequoias. Once mature, they grow no taller, but continue to grow thicker.

data.title: Sunset Amphitheater
data.listingDescription: Cross Hwy 180 from the visitor center, get there via trail or drive into Sunset Campground and follow signs to the parking for the amphitheater. Meet here for ranger-led campfires and talks, usually given in the evening.

images.altText: Several people are seated on wooden benches at an outdoor amphitheater. Others gather at the stage.
images.title: Sunset Amphitheater
images.caption: Enjoy an evening program at Sunset Amphitheater.

data.bodyText:
Meet here for ranger-led campfires and talks, usually given in the evening. Cross Hwy 180 from the visitor center, get there via trail or drive into Sunset Campground and follow signs to the parking for the amphitheater. 

Getting There

From the Kings Canyon Visitor Center, take the trail across Highway 180, or drive into Sunset Campground and follow signs to the parking for the amphitheater.
data.audioDescription: Sunset Amphitheater is a few hundred feet from the parking area via a paved trail, in a conifer forest. There is bench seating for up to 300 people on an angled asphalt surface. The seating is arranged in three sections, each with about 20 rows of benches. The sections are arranged in an arc so that all benches face the stage. Two aisles run in between these sections, from the back toward to the area in front of the stage. They are about five feet wide. The presentation area has a stage where someone can stand and give a talk. A projection screen behind it is framed in wood. To the left of the stage is a campfire circle built up from the ground, encircled by large rocks.

quickFacts.value: Next to Sunset Campground, across from Kings Canyon Visitor Center
quickFacts.name: Location
