data.title: Surviving Change
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Surviving Change," shows how climate changes can affect sequoia growth.

images.altText: Wayside Panel explaining Surviving Change
images.title: Surviving Change
images.caption: Surviving Change

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Surviving Change," shows how climate changes can affect sequoia growth.
data.audioDescription:
The View: To your left are the grasses of Round Meadow and to your right are the sequoias of Giant Forest. You are standing before a fallen sequoia tree trunk. The trunk has been cut across its base, showing the tree's cross section.

On the panel, a background photo, taken from the meadow, shows a dense line of giant sequoias against a dark sky. An illustration, layered on top of the photo, shows two giant sequoias. The tree on the left has a wide "Flared Base", like an overturned fluted glass or trumpet bell. The tree on the right has a "Typical base", with just a slight widening at its base.

The caption reads,

Sequoias growing in moist areas often develop flared bases. This adaptation apparently provides greater support in the soft soil. It's similar to standing with your feet wider apart for stability.

Notice the bases of other sequoias. They may provide clues about local soil moisture.

The text reads,

Surviving Change

This spot is unusually wet for sequoias. It was probably drier here when the trees in front of you began growing. During prolonged droughts, wet meadows like this one often shrink. Sequoias can get started in the drier soil around the edge.

However, if the climate turns wet again and the meadow expands, roots get flooded. These giants may not make it. Their roots may drown. The moist soil may be too soft to support large trees, causing them to lean and finally fall. Time will tell.

data.title: Surviving In Snow
data.listingDescription: This outdoor exhibit, titled “Surviving in Snow,” explains how dogwoods and fir trees survive in the snowy winter months in the Sierras.

images.altText: A free-standing, brown-framed sign with mostly blue imagery and text is found in front of trees.
images.title: Surviving In Snow
images.caption: Surviving in Snow exhibit

data.bodyText: This outdoor exhibit, titled “Surviving in Snow,” explains how dogwoods and fir trees survive in the snowy winter months in the Sierras.
data.audioDescription: This outdoor exhibit panel is titled, "Surviving in Snow." There is a photograph of moon rising over far-away peaks and trees that are backlit by a two-toned, blue and purple sky. In the image foreground is a fir tree and snow-covered ground. The text on the panel reads, “Winter in the Sierra Nevada mountains usually means a deep snowpack. Each plant that grows here has a strategy to survive the winter. Conifers—pines and other needle-bearing trees—have a conical shape and densely packed, slippery needles that shed snow . Flexible branches bend easily to dump snow before too much accumulates. Thick bark insulates the trunk from cold. Broadleaf trees and bushes grow shorter and rounder. When they lose their delicate leaves each fall, only their bare branches are exposed to cold. Smaller plants spend the entire winter under the snowpack, sheltered from wind and temperature extremes.”

data.title: Tar Gap Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Tar Gap trail area.

images.altText: A trailhead sign and a boot brush installed nearby

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Tar Gap trail area.

Tar Gap Trail is a 4 mile one-way (8 miles round-trip) trail at a moderate incline. The trail visits lakes, travels through forests, and offers alpine vistas. This can be a popular trail for people with stock. The first campsite is at Deer Creek after 4 miles.
data.audioDescription:
The text reads,
This trail climbs gently through forest to the Hockett Plateau. The large meadows and rolling hills of this gentle piece of high country contrast with the peaks and crags of other Mineral King destinations,
Like most park trails, Tar Gap Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Possible destinations include:
The left photo shows a grassy meadow with a wood building in the center surrounded by tall trees. The caption reads,
Hockett Meadow.
10.9 miles (or 17.5 km) one way.
Elevation: 8,499 feet (or 2,591 m).
The trail breaks out of the trees and into this large meadow, where deer graze summer's rich grasses and wildflowers.
The right photo shows a deep blue reflective lake with a gentle forested slope leading to its banks. The caption reads,

Evelyn Lake.
13.8 miles (or 22.2 km) one way.
Elevation: 8,720 feet (or 2,658 m).

A gently sloping, forested trail leads beyond Hockett Meadow to Evelyn lake. If you camp there, consider a side trip to Cahoon Rock for broad views of neighboring peaks.

A map of the Mineral King area shows the location of Tar Gap Trailhead.
The bottom photo is of a large flat meadow circled by conifers. A rustic log cabin with a triangular shaped roof support by large wood beams stands in the meadow. Its chimney has a tall capped flue. There is smaller wood building to its left. The caption reads,

The historic Hockett Meadow Ranger Station

Quote from President Theodore Roosevelt,

"It is not what we have that will make us a great nation; it is the way in which we use it."

data.title: Ten Mile Campground
data.listingDescription: Tenmile Campground is within the Sequoia National Forest, 10 miles from the Grant Grove Visitor Center. The campground is adjacent to Ten Mile Creek, a creek popular with anglers and hunters and dwarfed by towering sequoia and Jeffrey pines at an elevation of 5,294 feet.

images.altText: A campsite in a primitive campground
images.caption: The US Forest Service campground is small and relatively primitive. Photo by Kiel Maddox.

data.bodyText:
Ten Mile Campground is within the Sequoia National Forest, 10 miles from the Grant Grove Visitor Center. The campground is adjacent to Ten Mile Creek, a creek popular with anglers and hunters and dwarfed by towering sequoia and Jeffrey pines at an elevation of 5,294 feet. Ten Mile Campground is only five miles from Hume Lake, a popular destination with a wide range of recreational opportunities.

Note, the Ten Mile Road is unmaintained during the winter, and only accessible to vehicles with four wheel drive. There are 5 tent-only sites and 6 sites open to RVs and trailers. Reservations are available at recreation.gov or by calling (877) 444-6777.

quickFacts.value: Ten Mile Road, Sequoia National Forest
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Tharp's Log
data.listingDescription: Back in 1861, Hale Tharp built this cabin in a tree, making him the first non-Native American to live in the Giant Forest.

images.altText: A cabin with a stone chimney is built into a downed, giant sequoia log.
images.title: Tharp's Log
images.caption: Tharp's Log is a cabin built by Hale Tharp out of a downed, giant sequoia log.

data.bodyText:
Back in 1861, Hale Tharp built this cabin in a tree, making him the first non-Native American to live in the Giant Forest. He grazed cattle in these meadows in summer and near Horse Creek, in the foothills, in the winter. John Muir stopped here in 1875, the same year he named this grove "The Giant Forest." Muir and his mule, Brownie, found Tharp quite hospitable.

What would it be like to live here, watching the forest change throughout the season? What might you learn? Could you do it without damaging the surroundings, or yourself?
data.audioDescription: You are standing in a sequoia forest near the trunk of a massive fallen sequoia. Attached to the root end of the trunk is a small cabin with wood siding and a stone fireplace. Most of the wood plank siding is grey in color, and weathered, warped, and carved with graffiti. A few planks that have been restored near the door are straighter and orange brown in color. Further up the trunk, a wooden shutter is attached to the log with two large metal hinges. The shutter is open, with its lower edge propped up on two posts, revealing a square opening cut into the trunk behind it, forming a window. The entrance to the cabin is missing a door. People can enter the front portion of the cabin. The back part is blocked by a wooden railing. Beyond it are Tharp's original old wooden bed, table, and bench. A sign on the back wall asks people to please respect the site.

data.title: The CCC Boys
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Shaping a Park, The CCC Boys," shows photos and text about Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC).

images.altText: Wayside Panel explaining The CCC Boys
images.title: The CCC Boys
images.caption: The CCC Boys

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Shaping a Park, The CCC Boys," shows photos and text about Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC).
data.audioDescription:
The View: You are at the edge of thick sequoia forest. In front of you, is a fallen giant sequoia, stretching across the road. In 1937, The CCC Boys tunneled through its trunk. Today cars can drive through this tunnel.

A black and white photo of 25 jovial young men posing for a group photo. Some have their hands on their hips or behind their backs. A couple are holding shovels. Many are dressed in brown button up long-sleeved shirts with two breast pockets. Their belted dark trousers are cuffed at the bottom. Most are wearing round canvas hats. Behind the men are a dozen white canvas tents, in two neat rows. A larger white tent is seen behind the lines of tents, with smoke billowing next to it. To the left, is a shrub covered hill with a road running beside it. An old-fashioned Model T style automobile is parked near the road. The caption reads,

CCC Boys pose at their camp at Potwisha.

The text reads,

Tunnel Log reminds us of the work of young men who struggled to survive The Great Depression in the 1930s. The drive through hole in the log was carved by the "boys" of the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC).

The Great Depression left millions unemployed. Congress created the CCC to put young men to work and get paychecks to their families. The CCC worked mostly on public lands, including Sequoia National Park.

Despite youth and inexperience, the CCC boys proved remarkable in developing many features of this park and at thousands of other places across the nation. They built roads, trails, buildings, campgrounds, water systems, and more much of which is still used today.

A black and white photo of a large fallen sequoia covered with snow laying across a road. An old-fashioned automobile with a hard top with rounded corners and close, rounded fenders. is parked facing the log. The caption reads,

When this sequoia fell across the road on December 4, 1937, CCC worker Roy DeVoe of Weldon, California, suggested cutting the tunnel. The tree extended 275 feet long, with a base of 21 feet.

A black and white photo of a large fallen sequoia with two old fashioned, Model T style cars parked on the top of the trunk. Several visitors are standing or sitting next to their cars. The caption reads,

Auto Log circa 1920s

The text explains that in the past it was common to alter natural features to create attractions that drew people to the parks. Today, national parks are valued more for preserving landscapes unchanged.

A photo of curved dirt road with boulders piled up along either side. A very large rock spans between those boulders, creating a bridge across the road. A man stands under the rock for scale. A photo of Tunnel Rock from the 1930s.

quickFacts.value: Along Moro Rock / Crescent Meadow Road, at Tunnel Log
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: The General Grant Tree
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "The General Grant Tree," has illustrations that show the size of the tree.

images.altText: A metal panel has images and text on it informing visitors about the General Grant tree
images.title: The General Grant Tree
images.caption: The wayside exhibit for the General Grant Tree

data.bodyText:
This wayside exhibit, titled "The General Grant Tree," has illustrations that show the size of the tree.

Tree Facts

Height: 268.1 feet (81.716 meters)
Ground circumference: 107.5 feet (32.8 meters)
Trunk volume: 46,608 cubic feet (1320 cubic meters)
data.audioDescription:
The View: In front of you is an enormous sequoia tree. The tree has deep crevices and curves outward at the base. The trunk is covered with shaggy reddish-brown bark that is thick and fibrous. Its thick stubby branches with clusters of oval green leaves, start high above the ground.

The text reads,

The General Grant Tree's massive trunk makes it the third largest tree in the world, by volume. And at 40 feet (or 12 m) in diameter at ground level, it is the world's widest known sequoia. But it is not nearly the oldest. In fact, it is 1,500 years younger than the oldest known sequoia.

Location, not age, is the key to a sequoia's size. In places with the best combination of moisture, sunlight, and nutrients, they outgrow older sequoias rooted in less prime locations. Apparently conditions here are ideal, considering how quickly the General Grant Tree has grown so large.

Additional text, with small illustrations, reads,

Fun Facts:

An illustration of a sequoia tree, the planet earth, and a red car lined up next to each other. A fuel hose connects the trunk of the tree to the gas tank of the car.

The caption reads,

If the trunk of the General Grant Tree was a gas tank on a car that got 25 miles per gallon, you could drive around the earth 350 times without refueling.

An illustration of people, holding hands, stretched out around a sequoia tree trunk.

The caption reads,

The General Grant Tree is so wide it would take about twenty people holding hands to make a complete circle around the base.

An illustration of a sequoia tree trunk, filled with large orange balls and tiny white balls.

The caption reads,

If the General Grant Tree's trunk could be filled with sports equipment, it could hold 159,000 basketballs, or more than 37 million ping pong balls.

An illustration of a sequoia tree with a yellow star at the top.

The caption reads,

President Calvin Coolidge proclaimed the General Grant Tree to be the Nation's Christmas Tree in 1926. In 1956, President Dwight D. Eisenhower designated it as a National Shrine, a living memorial to those who have given their lives for their country.

A large Illustration of the General Grant Tree:

The text inside the trunk reads,

Volume makes it the 3rd largest tree in the world.

The text at the base reads,

It is the widest known sequoia, at 40 feet across.

The statistics listed for the General Grant tree include:

Volume.
46,608 cubic feet (or 1,320 cubic meters).

Height.
268 feet (or 82 meters).

Estimated Age.
1,700 years old.

Estimated Weight.
1,254 tons (or 1,325 metric tons).

Circumference (at its base).
107 feet (or 33 meters).

Maximum Diameter.
40 feet (or 12 meters).

Diameter of Largest Branch.
4.5 feet (or 1.4 meters).

Height of First Branch.
129 feet (or 39 meters).

To see the world's largest tree (by volume), drive 27 miles (or 43 km) south on the Generals Highway to the General Sherman Tree in the Giant Forest.

Additional text reads,

How do we know its age?

Determining a living sequoia's age is hard. We can't count all of the growth rings inside a huge sequoia without injuring the tree. Instead, scientists have used tree ring measurements from old stumps to develop mathematical formulas for sequoia growth. On living trees, they only need to count the rings on the outer edge to apply the formula. This gives an estimated age, not a precise one, that is "give or take" within a couple hundred years.

data.title: The General Sherman Tree
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "The General Sherman Tree," shows measurements of the General Sherman Tree, the biggest tree on Earth, as well as other notable trees.

images.altText: a metal panel has images and text on it informing visitors about the General Sherman Tree
images.title: The General Sherman Tree
images.caption: The wayside exhibit for the General Sherman Tree

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "The General Sherman Tree," shows measurements of the General Sherman Tree, the biggest tree on Earth, as well as other notable trees.
data.audioDescription: Notice the tactile brass sequoia cone, the size of a small egg, on the upper left corner on the frame of this exhibit. The text reads, This tree is not the tallest or the widest, but the overall volume of its trunk makes it the biggest tree on Earth. Text and charts explain the Sequoia World Records by volume, weight, width, height and age. The General Sherman holds the records for volume: 52,500 cubic feet (or 1,487 cubic meters) and weight: 1,385 tons (or 1,256 metric tons). General Grant holds the record for width: 40 feet (or 12 m). Unnamed sequoias hold records for height: Three hundred and eleven feet (or 95 m) and age: 3,200 years. A diagram of the tall General Sherman tree along with three circular sections through the trunk show the volume at various heights. The sections are labeled A, B, and C. The same letters appear on the tree illustration. "A", at the base, is 36.5 feet (or 11 m) in diameter. "B", 180 feet up, by the first branches, is 13.7 feet (or 4.2 m) across. "C", for the largest branch, is 6.8 feet (or 2 m) wide. An illustration of three tiny people at the base of the tree, with an arrow pointing upward. The text reads, It's a Matter of Perspective Looking up at the General Sherman Tree for a six-foot-tall human is about the equivalent of a mouse looking up at the 6-foot-tall human. More labels on the illustration of the General Sherman Tree explain that: The height is 275 feet tall. The volume is 52,500 cubic feet (or 1,487 cubic meters). Just how much is that? If the Sherman tree's trunk could be filled with water, it would provide enough water for 9,844 baths. That's one bath every day for 27 years. The weight is 1,385 tons (or 1,256 metric tons) The circumference, the measurement around the base of the trunk, is 103 feet (or 31 m). The age is 2,200 years old. Additional text reads, Biggest Does Not Mean Oldest The General Sherman Tree is about 1,000 years younger than the oldest - known Sequoia. How can this be? Location, location, location! We're growing conditions are best, sequoias grow faster. They outgrow older trees rooted in less prime locations. A life sized photograph shows that the cross section of a stunted 100-year-old sequoia tree is actually smaller than a U.S. half dollar. On the bottom, illustrations with arrows show the life cycle of a sequoia, from a tiny seedling less than two years old, to a taller Spire Top tree, 25 to 100 years old, to the massive 2,200-year-old General Sherman Tree.

data.title: The Naturalists
data.listingDescription: This exhibit, titled "Shaping a Park: The Naturalists," shows photos and text about early park rangers.

images.altText: An exhibit titled The Naturalists talks about people who shaped the history of the parks.
images.title: The Naturalists
images.caption: The Naturalists exhibit

data.bodyText: This exhibit, titled "Shaping a Park: The Naturalists," shows photos and text about early park rangers.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit, titled "Shaping a Park: The Naturalists", shows photos and text about early park rangers.

A black and white photo of a group of tourists, of all ages, on a steep stone stairway. The women are wearing knee length dresses, jackets, and rounded hats. The men wear trousers and buttoned shirts. Some have ties and brimmed hats. A ranger stands above the group, wearing a hat with a stiff brim, a white shirt and tie under a five-pocket buttoned jacket, and jodhpurs. He is pointing forward and upward. Many tourists are looking in that same direction. The caption reads,

Park ranger Frank Been leads a group at Moro Rock in 1930. Been was hired a year earlier as the park's first fulltime paid ranger naturalist.

The text reads,

Moro Rock is one of the places in Sequoia National Park where, in 1922, naturalists began "translating" the landscape for early park visitors. Naturalists offered walks, talks, and campfire programs, which combined information with inspiration, and visitors loved it.

For many people, parks are beautiful but mysterious. What shaped the land? Why does something grow here and not there? The tradition of naturalists helping visitors to combine fascination with knowledge continues today, kindling a commitment to parks in untold numbers of people.

A quote by Colonel J. R. White, Park Superintendent, 1926:

"The expansion of museum, nature walks and campfire lectures is the surest protection against degeneracy into jazzy amusements"

A black and white photo of an older man. He is wearing a stiff, wide brimmed felt hat. The hat has a medium sized, cylindrical crown with a dimpled rounded peak. A wide band with an emblem encircles its crown and a leather strap is tucked under his chin. He wears a white shirt and tie under a jacket with curved lapels, covered buttons, and two large buttoned pockets across the chest. He gazes downward, peering at the ferns surrounding him. The caption reads,

Walter Fry

The text reads,

Sequoia's First Naturalist

As a young man, Walter Fry came to the Sierra Nevada to log. After counting more than 3,000 rings on a cut sequoia, he turned instead to protecting the trees. Fry eventually became the first civilian superintendent of Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks.

Later, in 1920, Stephen Mather, (first director of the National Park Service) concluded that every park needed naturalists. Two years later the Sequoia Nature Guide Service was born when Superintendent John White called on his predecessor, Walter Fry, to volunteer. Working part time, Fry thus became Sequoia National Park's first naturalist.

data.title: The Sentinel: Just Average?
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "The Sentinel: Just Average?," shows this tree's size compared to other sequoias.

images.altText: An outdoor exhibit near the Sentinel Tree

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "The Sentinel: Just Average?," shows this tree's size compared to other sequoias.
data.audioDescription:
The View: Next to this wayside exhibit stands the giant sequoia named "The Sentinel."

A background photo on the panel, taken from the meadow, shows a dense line of giant sequoias against a dark sky with an overlaid illustration of another sequoia. Behind the tree are the ghosted images of two large jet airplanes.

The caption reads,

At 700 tons (or 635 m tons) the Sentinel Tree weighs more than two fully loaded jumbo jet airplanes, yet it is still just an average sequoia tree.

The text reads,

If you think the giant tree in front of you is big, in one sense you are right. The Sentinel, a 2,200-year-old sequoia, is a monster, compared to most trees. But in this land of giants, the Sentinel is just average. In the grove of sequoias that surround you, some trees are nearly twice as large as the Sentinel.

An illustrated chart to the right compares The Sentinel Tree and the Maximum Known giant record holders for sequoia trees. It reads,

Compare for yourself.

Base width. (Showing round sections of the tree trunks for the Sentinel on the left, and the record holder on the right)

The Sentinel Tree: 28 feet (or 9 m).

Maximum Known: 40 feet (or 12 m).

Height.

The Sentinel Tree: 257 feet (or 78 m).

Maximum Known: 311 feet (or 95 m).


Volume. (Showing two sequoia trees.)

Sequoias are the world's largest trees, due to the volume of their trunks. Other trees grow taller or have greater width, but none has greater volume.

The Sentinel Tree: 27,900 cubic feet (or 790 cubic meters).

General Sherman: Tree 52,500 cubic feet (or 1487 cubic meters).


Weight. (Showing two sequoia trees on a slanted line. The tree on the right is lower, as if it is on the heavier side of a scale.)

The Sentinel Tree: 700 tons (or 635 m tons).

Maximum Known: 1,385 tons (or 1256 m tons).


Age. (Showing round sections of two tree trunks)

The Sentinel Tree: 2,200 years old.

Maximum Known: 3,200 years old.

To see the largest tree on Earth (the sequoia that has the greatest volume), visit the General Sherman Tree just two miles (or 3.2 km) north of here.

data.title: There it is!
data.listingDescription: As you stand on the path before this exhibit, notice the pavement has a textured feel. Under your feet, rows of paving stones radiate out in concentric circles from a central point. They represent a cross-section through the base of the General Sherman Tree. The outer edge of the landing has smooth tiles, which represent the bark. Walk along it to experience the "footprint" of the biggest tree on earth.

images.altText: Wayside exhibit mounted on level rest place in forested area

data.bodyText: As you stand on the path before this exhibit, notice the pavement has a textured feel. Under your feet, rows of paving stones radiate out in concentric circles from a central point. They represent a cross-section through the base of the General Sherman Tree. The outer edge of the landing has smooth tiles, which represent the bark. Walk along it to experience the "footprint" of the biggest tree on earth.
data.audioDescription: The View: In the distance is the lower trunk of the massive General Sherman Tree, with a triangular black scar that points upward from the base almost 30 feet high. Glimpses of the upper tree are seen through the branches of smaller giant sequoias that grow nearby. The text reads, “The Largest Tree on Earth.” In front of you stands the General Sherman Tree. It's claim to fame is the biggest tree in the world comes from the volume of its trunk. A few other trees trunks are bigger around. Some trees are taller. But no other tree has more wood in its trunk and the Sherman tree. The Sherman Tree's top is dead, so the tree's trunk no longer gets taller. However, its volume keeps increasing. Each year the trunk grows wider, adding enough wood to equal another good-sized tree. Check out the life-sized "footprint" of the Sherman Tree's trunk on the ground behind you. It gives an idea of the trees girth -109 feet (33 m) around at the ground- and its irregular shape. Natural growth patterns and fire scars caused the uneven shape. Compare the fire scar on the tree (the same black scar visible behind the cavalry in the historic photo below) with the indentation the scar makes in the trunk's outline. A photo of the view. An inset black and white photo of a row of nine men on horseback, in cavalry uniform, posing in front of the tree. The horses face us. The massive trunk is the width of seven horses. High on the tree trunk, inside the scar, is a white sign that reads "General Sherman". The caption reads, “U.S. Cavalry guarded Sequoia National Park from 1891 until 1916, when the National Park Service came into existence. In 1879, pioneer cattlemen and former soldier James Wolverton named the tree "General Sherman," after the leader he served under during the Civil War.

data.title: There it is! (General Sherman Tree Accessible Trail)
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "There it is!", shows photos about the General Sherman Tree. You can also find this exhibit southwest of the General Sherman Tree, near the General Highway Parking Access.

images.altText: Wayside exhibit in front of a wooden fence on paved trail

data.bodyText:
This wayside exhibit, titled "There it is!", shows photos about the General Sherman Tree.

You can also find this exhibit southwest of the General Sherman Tree, near the General Highway Parking Access.
data.audioDescription: Notice the tactile brass sequoia cone, the size of a small egg, on the upper left corner on the frame of this exhibit. The text reads, “There it is!” Across the open space before you stands the biggest tree on the planet, the General Sherman Tree. Some trees grow taller, and some are bigger around, but no tree has greater mass. The amount of space taken up by its trunk is greater than that of any other tree. From here you have an unusual view, because you can see the entire tree from bottom to top. Notice two characteristics of a monarch sequoia: The top is dead, so it's upward growth has stopped at 275 feet (84 m). It has a huge, cylindrical trunk, which makes it the world's largest tree by volume. As long as the sequoia tree lives its trunk thickens, gaining mass. Each year the General Sherman Tree's trunk gains enough new wood to equal a very large tree of most other species. A photo of the massive monarch in the winter, amongst smaller snow-covered trees, the reddish-brown trunk and branches above stand out. An icon of a camera. The caption reads, From this viewpoint you can photograph the Sherman tree from bottom to top. For similar views of other sequoia trees, visit one of Giant Forest's meadows. A photograph of a woman examining a piece of a large branch, about four feet in diameter, that is laying near the base of the General Sherman tree. Broken fencing and small branches are scattered in the snow on either side of the branch. If you walk around the General Sherman tree, you can touch this fallen branch. The text reads, The General Loses a Limb Look closely, the General Sherman Tree has changed since this photo (left) was taken. Can you spot the large limb in the photo that is now missing from the tree itself? This second largest branch on The Sherman Tree fell in January 2006. No one witnessed the crash. Thankfully, it crushed only some fencing and pavement (right).

data.title: Tokopah Falls Trailhead
data.listingDescription:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Tokopah Falls Trail area.

Tokopah Falls trail is a 1.7 mile (2.7 kilometer) hike at an easy incline. It travels along the Marble Fork of the Kaweah River to the impressive granite cliffs and cascading waterfall of Tokopah Canyon. Tokopah Falls is 1,200 feet (365.8 meters) high, and is most impressive in early summer. Please use caution around the water.

images.altText: A dirt trail runs alongside a river cutting between tall trees
images.title: Tokopah Falls Trailhead
images.caption: The Start of Tokopah Falls trail

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Tokopah Falls Trail area.

Tokopah Falls trail is a 1.7 mile (2.7 kilometer) hike at an easy incline. It travels along the Marble Fork of the Kaweah River to the impressive granite cliffs and cascading waterfall of Tokopah Canyon. Tokopah Falls is 1,200 feet (365.8 meters) high, and is most impressive in early summer. Please use caution around the water.
data.audioDescription:
The text reads,

This fairly easy trail follows the Marble Fork of the Kaweah River to the head of Tokopah Valley. Where the trail ends, cold water from the High Sierra cascades down granite slopes. Marmots are common near the falls. Don't encourage these large rodents to come closer; they may chew shoes and other gear.

Like almost all park trails, Tokopah Falls Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of legal protection, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to enjoy.

Photo of a rock and tree filled valley, with a river running through it.

The caption reads,

Tokopah Falls.
1.7 miles (or 2.7 km) one way to end of trail.

Other nearby trails:
A photo looking down at a green meadow, nestled in a conifer forest, with hazy mountains in the distance.

The caption reads,

Twin Lakes Trail.
2.6 miles (or 4.2 km) to Cahoon Meadow.
6.8 miles (or 10.9 km) to Twin Lakes.

Look for Twin Lakes Trailhead further along the campground road. Cahoon Meadow (shown here) and Twin Lakes, popular dayhiker destinations, are on the side of Silliman Pass.

A map shows the location of the Tokopah Falls Trailhead.

The bottom photo shows peaks of granite mountains. The closest peak is striped with orange and dark grey coloring.

The caption reads,

Looking across Tokopah Valley from the Watchtower

A quote by Roderick Nash,

"... wilderness is not so much a place, but a feeling..."

data.title: Too Wet
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Too Wet," shows why too much water is not healthy for sequoias.

images.altText: An metal exhibit sign is found along the edge of a meadow, to the right of three trees.
images.title: Too Wet Outdoor Exhibit
images.caption: Outdoor Exhibit titled, "Too Wet"

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Too Wet," shows why too much water is not healthy for sequoias.
data.audioDescription:
The View: To your left are the grasses of Round Meadow and to your right are the sequoias of Giant Forest. The meadow contains a few scattered conifer trees but no sequoias. Giant sequoias are visible on the right side of the path ahead.

On the top corners of the frame of this wayside exhibit are tactile brass sequoia cones, about the size of an egg, with a small twig attached to each.

The text on the panel reads,

Too Wet

This open meadow is too wet for trees. Sequoia roots can't live in this soggy soil. Rainwater and melting snow drain here from the surrounding hills. The water collects in a depression in the bedrock, creating this moist opening.

Yet giant sequoias need enormous amounts of water. By growing near the meadow but not in it, they can benefit. Their roots capture moisture as it drains toward the meadow.

A background photo, taken from the meadow, shows a dense line of giant sequoia trees against a dark sky. An illustration, layered on the top of the photo, shows sequoia trees on the right and left side of a meadow. A section cuts through the ground, revealing a pool of water collecting below the meadow on bedrock.

A line stretches across the meadow, between the two trees.

The text for this line reads,

Too Wet for Trees to Grow

The amount of water in the meadow varies with the season. In Spring, with winter's snowmelt, there may be standing water across the meadow.

data.title: Tough Twins
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Tough Twins", shows photos of two trees and explains the relationship between fire and a sequoia's growth cycle.

images.altText: A metal panel sits in a metal frame. On the panel are images and text
images.title: Tough Twins
images.caption: Tough Twins wayside exhibit

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Tough Twins", shows photos of two trees and explains the relationship between fire and a sequoia's growth cycle.
data.audioDescription:
The View: Two wide sequoia trees flank the path before you. Their trunks are only 10 feet apart. You can touch and compare the texture of the two. The tree on the left has a healed fire scar and the bark is soft. The right tree's trunk has a huge triangular dark fire scar about 20 feet tall and about 10 feet wide at the base. The scar is recessed about 4 feet deep into the trunk. A softer, shaggy bark has wrapped around the lower edges of the scar.

The text reads,

This pair of trees provides evidence that fire plays a natural role in the life of giant sequoias. In fact, most owe their lives to fire. The evidence lies not only in their obvious fire scars, but also because they may be twins. Centuries ago, they probably started life at the same time after a fire prepared the ground for them.

Fire creates ideal conditions for sequoia seeds to germinate and for seedlings to grow. Heat rising from a fire dries overhanging cones, causing them to open. Cones then rain seeds onto fire-cleared, ash-fertilized ground - a perfect seedbed. Millions of sequoia seedlings sprout after a fire.

Fire also kills many trees of other species that don't survive fire as well as sequoias. That helps sequoias by reducing competition for sunlight, water, and nutrients. Fire's heat may also kill soil fungus that could harm sequoia root. Groups of same aged sequoias like these tough twins are fairly common. Look for them as you explore the park's sequoia groves.

A photo on the left shows the tree in view on the left, already described. The caption reads,

Healed Fire Scar
Look for this scar near the base of one twin. The bark almost covers the scar now, insulating the wood from further fire damage.

A photo on the right side of the panel shows the tree in view on the right. The caption reads,

Open Fire Scar

This scar is still charred and wood is exposed. If fire returns here soon, this scar may not have time to heal over, as did the scar on the opposite tree.


A photo shows a charred tree trunk with ash, fire and smoke around the base. Inset images show the growth of a sequoia. The text reads,

Growth after fire.

Most fires in the sequoia forest burn low to the ground. They are relatively cool, as fires go. Rarely hot enough to kill mature sequoias, they can still kill trees of thinner barked species.

Sequoia seeds sprout best in a sunny, clear bed of ashes.

Sequoia seedlings sprout by the thousands, but few survive.

Saplings may be thinned by other fires.

Centuries later, long- term survivors tower over the forest, providing seeds for the cycle to begin again.

data.title: Trailbuilders
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "Shaping a Park, Trailbuilders," shows photos and text about the trail builders that shaped this park.

images.altText: Trailbuilders Wayside
images.title: Trailbuilders Wayside
images.caption: Trailbuilders Wayside

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Shaping a Park, Trailbuilders," shows photos and text about the trail builders that shaped this park.
data.audioDescription:
A black and white photo of a steep fractured mountain side. Layers and layers of rock have been carved away to create a path. A worker leans on one knee, using a pickaxe to carve further up the ridge.

The text reads,

You are standing at the start of an amazing footpath that has an inspired story. From here thanks to hardy trailbuilders in the park's early years, you can hike to the Sierra Nevada's highest peaks.

In the 1920s Congress extended Sequoia National Park eastward from the sequoia groves to the crest of the Sierra Nevada.

Superintendent John White knew that people needed access to the new park area. Rather than build roads, he envisioned a "High Sierra Trail" from the Giant Forest to Mount Whitney.

For his trailbuilding project, White set forth two criteria: minimal damage to the land and as few ups and downs as possible. Despite the steep. rocky terrain, trail crews met his challenge. Using White's route, hikers today can travel from sequoia grove to Sierra crest with remarkable ease for such a rugged landscape.

A quote by Park Superintendent John White,

"... the Kern Canyon and High Sierra area should be developed only as a trail park...the honk of the motor horn should never echo in [them}."

A black and white photo of a woman standing with a horse, with a snow dappled mountainside behind her. She is wearing a hat, scarf, long sleeve shirt, gloves, pantaloons with a leather pouch tied around her waist, in tall boots. She stands facing forward, her arm is curled under the neck of the brown horse, touching its cheek. The horse's head is nestled against her side. Next to her, is a pile of large rocks and a wooden sign on a post that reads, "Sierra National Forest, Muir Pass Elevation 12,059 feet" The caption reads,

Susan Thew in the high country

The text below reads,

Getting Involved

When a debate began over whether the High Sierra should be added to Sequoia National Park, a local woman took action, Susan Thew hired a photographer and set off into the mountains. Upon returning, she mailed her photos to every member of Congress, showing them the wild beauty that was at stake.

quickFacts.value: Crescent Meadow Trail, near parking lot
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Tunnel Log
data.listingDescription: This giant sequoia fell across the road in 1937. Rather than remove it, Civilian Conservation Corps workers (the CCC) tunneled through it, creating the only "tree-you-can-drive-through" in these parks. The famous standing tunnel tree in Yosemite collapsed in 1969. Check out the wayside exhibit here for more details.

images.altText: A car drives through a fallen sequoia with a tunnel cut through it.
images.title: Tunnel Log
images.caption: A car drives through a fallen sequoia with a tunnel cut through it.

data.bodyText:
This giant sequoia fell across the road in 1937. Rather than remove it, Civilian Conservation Corps workers (the CCC) tunneled through it, creating the only "tree-you-can-drive-through" in these parks. The famous standing tunnel tree in Yosemite collapsed in 1969. Check out the wayside exhibit here for more details.

Winter Access

To access this area in winter, you will need to hike, snowshoe, or ski into the area.
data.audioDescription: You are in a forest of young sequoia trees. The trunk of a huge, fallen sequoia tree, has a tunnel cut in it large enough that cars can actually drive through it. A paved road runs through that tunnel. Throughout the day, cars approach the tunnel and drive through from either side. Often, one passenger gets out and snaps a photo as their car enters the tunnel log's opening. To the right of the tree, when facing the tunnel, is a wooden sign engraved with yellow lettering. It reads, Tunnel Log. Fell: December 4, 1937. Base: Diameter 21 Feet, Length: 275 Feet. Tunnel: 8 Feet High, 17 Feet Wide. The cracked surface of the tree is covered with carved graffiti, which is illegal. Most of the graffiti shows names or initials, sometimes with the year mentioned. Occasionally, two names or initials are shown within a heart shape. The tangled roots of this sequoia stick up about 6 feet beyond the trunk. Moss is nestled in pockets of the outer edges of the roots, even though the outer wood is dry and bleached.

data.title: Tunnel Rock
data.listingDescription: This granite boulder created a tunnel over the Generals Highway until the road was rerouted. If you want to take a closer look, accessible parking and a paved path provide easy access to the old roadway beneath Tunnel Rock.

images.altText: A large granite slab forms an arch as it balances on neighboring rock. A road one passed under here.
images.title: Tunnel Rock
images.caption: While cars can no longer driver under Tunnel Rock, you can stand below it and pose for a photo.

data.bodyText:
This granite boulder created a tunnel over the Generals Highway until the road was rerouted. If you want to take a closer look, accessible parking and a paved path provide easy access to the old roadway beneath Tunnel Rock.

The KNP Complex Fire: A Variety of Fire Effects 

Both above Tunnel Rock and across the river, you can see a mixture of how the 2021 KNP Complex Fire affected the vegetation. Notice a mosaic of live trees and shrubs, patches of fire-killed vegetation, and other areas where only bare, blackened ground remains. As time passes new plants will sprout in most of these bare areas. 

These different burn  patterns resulted from a variety of fire behavior (or how the fire burned). In places, light upcanyon winds may have pushed the fire cross-slope or it may have backed down the hillside at lower intensity. Further upcanyon, areas with no vegetation and exposed rock are places where flammable shrubs burned at higher intensity. Look on the slope below the pullout for a buckeye tree re-sprouting from its base and other plant re-growth.  

Poison Oak

Beware the three-leaved plant that grows here! Touching it can cause an intensely itchy rash. Even in winter when twigs are bare, oils from this plant can transfer from the plant to hands, clothing, and anything that touches it.
data.audioDescription:
You are in the foothills area. Around you are gently sloping hills covered with grasses, low shrubs, and small trees. On the uphill side of the road, about 20 feet away is a very large rock that spans across two boulders, creating a tunnel. The rock is about the size of a small house, and shaped roughly like a jelly bean, lying on its side. It is mostly pale grey in color, with some reddish color and some dark grey patches underneath. Remnants of a highway with a painted yellow line in the center are beneath the rock, showing that cars actually drove through this tunnel at one time. Today there is a path where you can walk through it.
The path to tunnel rock is strewn with a few small boulders, to keep out cars. Once you are past the boulders, you can easily walk through the tunnel. It is about 20 feet wide, and the top of the tunnel angles from about 10 to about 15 feet in height.

You can feel the boulders around the entrance and on both sides of the tunnel. The base of the boulders has been reinforced with stones and cement, for safety. Once inside, on the side closest to the road, you might be able to touch the ceiling, if you are tall, and jump.

In front of the boulders is a metal sign with an illustration of a sequoia cone. It reads,
Tunnel Rock

quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Twin Lakes Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Twin Lakes Trail area. Twin Lakes Trail is a 6.8 mile (10.9 km) trail at a moderate incline. It travels through forests, meadows, and lakes. The first campsite is at Cahoon Meadow, after 3 miles (4.8 km).

images.altText: A dirt path leads between tall trees
images.title: Twin Lakes Trailhead
images.caption: The start of Twin Lakes Trail

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Twin Lakes Trail area.

Twin Lakes Trail is a 6.8 mile (10.9 km) trail at a moderate incline. It travels through forests, meadows, and lakes. The first campsite is at Cahoon Meadow, after 3 miles (4.8 km).
data.audioDescription:
The text reads,

This trail first climbs through forests of fir trees and past moist meadows. It approaches treeline near Silliman pass, then enters an open landscape of granite and alpine lakes. A branch off this trail leads to J. O. Pass and the USFS Jennie Lakes Wilderness.

Like most park trails, Twin Lakes Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Possible destinations include:

A photo of a lush green meadow that fades to yellow in the center, lined with conifer trees, with a mountain peak in the distance.

The caption reads,

Cahoon Meadow.
2.6 miles (or 4.2 km) one way.
Elevation: 7760 feet (or 2365 m).

After the first steep mile, the trail levels out as it approaches this grassy meadow. Look for wildflowers and wildlife, especially in early summer.

Photo shows a reflective lake lined with fir trees. A snowcapped mountain ridge, with a sharp crag to the left and a rounded peak to the right.

The caption reads,

Twin Lakes.
6.8 miles (or 10.9 km) one way.
Elevation: 9419 feet (or 2871 m).

The two lakes on either side of the trail are well forested, unlike most other lakes in the parks' high country. Just beyond Twin Lakes, Silliman Pass marks the boundary between Sequoia National Park and Kings Canyon National Park.

A map shows the location of Twin Lakes Trailhead.

The bottom photo looks past the tops of a few giant sequoia trees, toward a mountain range with snow dappled ridges in the distance.

The caption reads,

Silliman Crest.

A quote by George Washington Carver,

"Nothing is more beautiful than the loveliness of the woods before sunrise."

data.title: Under The Canopy
data.listingDescription: This outdoor exhibit, titled “Under the Canopy,” shares fun facts about Pacific dogwood trees.

images.altText: An brown-framed, square outdoor exhibit sign is surrounded by forest trees.
images.title: Under the Canopy
images.caption: Under the Canopy exhibit

data.bodyText: This outdoor exhibit, titled “Under the Canopy,” shares fun facts about Pacific dogwood trees.
data.audioDescription: This outdoor exhibit panel is titled, "Under the Canopy," and features three photos, two image captions, and text describing Pacific dogwood trees. A large photo of a green dogwood tree leaf is found on the right of the exhibit panel. Two small photos are found above it. One of the photos features a dogwood flower and its caption reads, “Pacific dogwoods usually flower twice each year, in both spring and fall.” The second photograph features a small, compound red and black-tipped berry on a background of green foliage. Its caption reads, “The dogwood’s showy reddish-orange seed clusters provide a feast for songbirds.” The main text of the exhibit panel reads, “The Pacific dogwood’s leaves are extravagantly large for trees that grow where summers are dry. These wide leaves use much more water than a conifer’s small, waxy needles. But near this mountain meadow, the water they need is available. The melting winter snowpack provides water in spring and early summer. Long taproots help dogwoods access water deep in the soil when the snow is gone. Pacific dogwoods rely on cool temperatures to keep their leaves from losing too much water. Their leaves hang downward to shade the trunk and branches. If an opening in the canopy allows too much sunlight to hit the trunk, the sunlight stimulates the growth of new leaves to provide more shade.”

data.title: Upper Stony Creek Campground
data.listingDescription: Upper Stony Creek Campground is situated on the northern side of Hume Lake, set amidst Douglas fir and Jeffrey pines at an elevation of 5,250 feet (1,600 m).

images.caption: Turn off the Generals Highway at this sign to reach the campground.

data.bodyText:
Upper Stony Creek Campground is situated on the northern side of Hume Lake, set amidst Douglas fir and Jeffrey pines at an elevation of 5,250 feet (1,600 m).
Typically open late May to late September, the campground has 11 tent, RV, and trailer sites. Reservations are available at recreation.gov or by calling (877) 444-6777.

data.title: Want to Climb a Sequoia?
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, "Want to climb a Sequoia?," explains an interactive experience that can show you the height of a giant sequoia named the Sentinel Tree.

images.altText: A metal panel is bolted to a granite rock
images.title: Want to climb a sequoia?
images.caption: This wayside can be found at Giant Forest Museum

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "Want to climb a Sequoia?", explains an interactive experience that can show you the height of a giant sequoia named the Sentinel Tree.
data.audioDescription:
The View: In front of you is the walkway to the Giant Forest Museum and the pedestrian plaza, where the interactive is located. To the left, behind a wooden fence, is a massive giant sequoia-The Sentinel-with a thick trunk, reddish brown bark, and branches that start high above the ground.

On the panel is a darkened photograph looking up from the wide bases of three sequoia trees toward the upper branches, high above. The tops of the trees are not visible. One of the trunks is overlaid with three square illustrations. Each shows a sequoia tree with arrows pointing at either side the trunk, and text explaining the height and trunk width at each position, and asking you to imagine yourself there. The panels are harder to read as they get farther up the tree trunk. The lowest one clearly reads,

40 feet (or 12 m) up Sentinel Tree.
15 ft. (or 4.6 m) thick

On the next higher square, one can read the words,

60 feet (or 18 m) up Sentinel Tree.

On the next only the number 80 is visible.

The wayside exhibit text reads,

Want to Climb a Sequoia?

You can't climb a real sequoia tree, but you can, perhaps, get a sense of it. Look up at the Sentinel Tree, the large sequoia to your left. Then explore the "ruler" that stretches before you on the pavement. The ruler is as long as the Sentinel Tree is tall. A shorter ruler crosses the plaza to show the tree's width at its base. As you "climb" the ruler, markers tell the height and diameter of the tree at that point.

Sequoia trunks remain thick far up the tree. This differs from most other conifers, whose trunks taper to a point. The sequoia's columnar shape provides the huge bulk for which sequoia trees are famous.

images.altText: Clouds reflect off a blue alpine lake nestled in high sierra peaks of Kings Canyon.
images.title: Unnamed Lake Below Black Giant Pass
images.caption: Unnamed Lake Below Black Giant Pass.

tags: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks
data.bodyText:
Weather

Weather can be very different between different park areas, and it can change quickly. Temperatures can vary 20 to 30 degrees as you change elevation. There may be spring flowers in the foothills and snow in the Giant Forest at the same time.

For current weather forecasts in the parks, visit the parks' Weather webpage. Internet access is required.
data.audioDescription: A portal to see current weather conditions at Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks.

data.title: What Brings Them Down?
data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "What Brings Them Down?," shows photos and explains why sequoia trees fall.

images.altText: A metal panel has images and text on it with information about how sequoia trees fall
images.title: What Brings them Down ?
images.caption: This exhibit is found near the accessible parking lot by the General Sherman Tree

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "What Brings Them Down?," shows photos and explains why sequoia trees fall.
data.audioDescription:
The View: To the right of this wayside exhibit, you can touch the trunk of the fallen giant sequoia. It is near the bottom of the accessible trail, about 20 feet after the pavement changes from concrete to a wooden walkway. A tunnel about six feet tall by six feet wide is carved through the log. Inside, on the right, you can feel a deep hole in the center of the trunk. Deep curved cracks with smaller cracks appear along the tunnel "walls," along with illegally carved names and initials. There are areas on the tunnel wall that are blackened.

At the base of the fallen tree trunk, a root ball stretches up about 20 feet.
The text reads,

What brought this huge tree to earth? Ironically, a tree's own size can contribute to its downfall. If the tree starts to become unbalanced, it's weight quickly becomes more than its shallow roots can support.
Sequoias may lose their balance for one or more reasons: road building, underground pipes, or soil fungi can damage roots that hold trees upright. If soil moisture increases, the ground may soften too much to hold the tree. Heavy snows or high winds can cause a tree to lean. Large fire scars at the base of the trunk may leave trees last to stand on.

Sometimes sequoias fall for no apparent reason. First, some unknown factor can cause the tree to lean. Then, gravity and the great mass of the trunk eventually bring the tree down. When and why this sequoia fell are not known.

A black and white photo of the fallen sequoia before you, the giant trunk lying on the ground. The caption reads,

This fallen sequoia might lie here for decades, maybe centuries. Chemicals in the woods, called tannins, resist insects and rot. The same traits that enable the tree to survive for so long now enabled the log to linger after death.

Photos of three famous fallen sequoias. The Auto log with a white mini van parked on the cutout area. The caption reads,

Auto log fell in 1917. Closed to vehicles in 2002 due to rot. Sequoias do decompose eventually.

The Tunnel log with a car driving through the tunnel. The caption reads,

Tunnel log. Fell in 1937.

Tharp's Log, a wooden plank cabin with a stone fireplace that's built onto the hollow end of a fallen sequoia. The caption reads,

Tharp's log. Date of fall unknown. It had already fallen by 1858.

A photo of a woman looking up at a tree's roots that are five times her height. The caption reads,
Buttress tree. Fell in 1959
The text reads,

Most sequoias fall uphill. Why?

When branches and cones fall from trees, they tend to slide downhill until they hit a tree trunk. Also, fire tends to linger on the uphill side of trees due to air currents. Over the course of repeated fires, large scars may develop there. Later, when something causes the trees to fall, it often topples in the direction of the scar.

As you explore, look for fire scars. Are they on the uphill side of the trees? Check out fallen sequoias. Which direction did they fall?

data.listingDescription: This wayside exhibit, titled "What is Good Habitat?," shows the conditions that sequoias need to reproduce and thrive.

images.altText: Wayside Panel explaining What is Good Habitat?
images.title: What is Good Habitat?
images.caption: What is Good Habitat?

data.bodyText: This wayside exhibit, titled "What is Good Habitat?," shows the conditions that sequoias need to reproduce and thrive.
data.audioDescription:
The View: To your left are the grasses of Round Meadow and to your right are the sequoias of Giant Forest. There is a giant sequoia tree a few feet ahead and to the right. The bark of the trunk is fibrous and furrowed. The ground around it has been cleared. Behind you is a green meadow.

On the panel, a background photo, taken from the meadow, shows a dense line of giant sequoia trees against a dark sky.

The text reads,

What is Good Habitat?

What do sequoias need to live long enough to grow this big? This 23-foot-wide (or 7 m) tree and its enormous neighbors give us our first clues. Look around where they are growing.

To reproduce and thrive, sequoias need specific conditions: moist soil, open sunny forest, a climate that is not too cold, and bare, ashy ground. Therefore, they also need the natural processes that create those conditions. As you walk this trail, watch for evidence of these processes.

An illustration of a circular tree slab with a curvy bark edge. The circle is divided into five sections of photos, like slices of a pie. Clockwise, from 1 o'clock:

A photo of a waterfall cascading over large rocks. The text reads, Water.

A photo, looking up through a canopy of leaves, toward sequoia tree tops with a shaft of sunlight. The text reads, Sun.

A photo of the lower trunks of two giant sequoia trees. The ground is covered with dried sequoia needles and twigs, but no plants. The text reads, Clear Forest Floor.

A photo looking upwards from the trunks of two giant sequoias with clear sky above. The text reads, Open Canopy.

A photo of giant sequoia trunks with a low fire burning on the ground around them. The text reads, Fire.

data.title: What's in the Air?
data.listingDescription: This exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, What's in the Air?," has photos and a map describing air quality.

images.altText: An exhibit sign titled "What's In The Air?" discusses air pollution.
images.title: What's In The Air?
images.caption: This exhibit shares information about air quality in the parks.

data.bodyText: This exhibit, titled "Moro Rock: Changing Views, What's in the Air?," has photos and a map describing air quality.
data.audioDescription:
The View: Perched on this ridge you are looking out into The San Joaquin Valley. Moro Rock is to your left. On most days, the sky is smoggy, with a murky brownish layer of air that hangs over that valley.

A photo of a sunset view from this wayside exhibit. The face of Moro Rock is visible on the left, an orange haze with purplish mountains in the distance. The text reads,
What's in the air?

A century ago, forest - fire smoke often clouded summer views from here. Today, particulate pollution--tiny bits of dust and chemicals-more commonly blurs this scene. What's changed? People now limit the spread of most fires. However, many more vehicles, industries, and agricultural processes are producing particulates.

But not all pollution can be seen. Formed from vehicle exhaust and common volatile fumes, ozone by itself leaves views clear. Yet it damages plants and animals, especially along air drainages. The good news: despite population growth, ozone has not increased much. Our efforts can make a difference.

A map of the wind pattern over the California coast and the San Joaquin Valley. The wind stream enters from the Pacific Ocean at the San Francisco Bay area, then divides into northern and southern streams, with a long curl that moves circles into Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks. The text reads,

Take a deep breath. It's not just mountain air you're breathing; it's an exotic mix. It flows here from Asia as well as from the Bay area. It brings pollution from afar, but even more from nearby. Mountains around the San Joaquin Valley trap the air, until warm winds lift the pollutants into the parks.

data.title: When Sequoias Fall
data.listingDescription: This outdoor exhibit, titled “When Sequoias Fall,“ explains why sequoias fall near wet meadows and what happens in the aftermath.

images.altText: A weathered, metal-framed sign has pictures and text that discuss sequoia forest ecology.
images.title: When Sequoias Fall
images.caption: When Sequoias Fall outdoor exhibit

data.bodyText: This outdoor exhibit, titled “When Sequoias Fall,“ explains why sequoias fall near wet meadows and what happens in the aftermath.
data.audioDescription: This outdoor exhibit panel is titled, "When Sequoias Fall" and features two photos and an illustration, and includes a caption and text about giant sequoias and thimbleberries. The main photo features an uprooted and overturned sequoia, which rests on its side. The butt end of the log is full of crevices that harbor mosses. In the background are immature fir trees. The text reads, “Giant sequoias have an exceptionally long life but will eventually fall. Wet soil of mountain meadows provides little support for tree roots. The logs of sequoias and other trees are a common sight around the edges of meadows. Sequoias are especially vulnerable because of their shallow root system. When a tree falls, it creates a new opening that spans the tree canopy to the forest floor. Sunlight fills this space, enriching surrounding trees with extra sunlight. A clear and sunny location offers space for understory plants to grow. Eventually, new trees will reach upward here, filling in the opening.” To the right of the main photo is a photo of a green thimbleberry plant with white blossoms. Next to it is a close-up illustration of thimbleberry leaves and a red fruit that resembles a raspberry. The photo caption reads, “Thimbleberries” , “When space opens up in a sequoia grove, thimbleberries are ready to grow. Their durable seeds last for years underground. When a tree falls, the new patch of sunlight stimulates sprouting. Under the upturned tree roots, exposed bare soil creates an ideal seedbed.”

data.title: Why so big and so old?
data.listingDescription:
This wayside exhibit, titled "Why so big and so old?", shows the sequoia's survival system.

You can also find this exhibit southwest of the General Sherman Tree, closer to the Generals Highway Parking.

images.altText: This outdoor exhibit shows why sequoia trees live so long and grow so fast
images.title: Why so big and so old
images.caption: Giant sequoia trees have any adaptions that allow them to grow so big and get so old.

data.bodyText:
This wayside exhibit, titled "Why so big and so old?," shows the sequoia's survival system.

You can also find this exhibit southwest of the General Sherman Tree, closer to the Generals Highway Parking.
data.audioDescription:
Notice the tactile brass sequoia cone, the size of a small egg, on the upper left corner on the frame of this exhibit.

The text reads,

Why so big and so old?

The sequoia trees that you see here, even medium sized ones, are larger and older than most other trees on earth. Why? How can sequoia trees grow so large and live so long?

Sequoias have a rare combination of traits, fast growth and long life. Put those together with sufficient water and you get a huge tree. Several adaptations help them to survive many challenges that kill other trees.

An illustration titled, "Sequoia Survival System" shows the lower trunk of a sequoia tree, from roots to lower branches. Diamond shaped icons representing dangers to the tree are shown bouncing off the trunk, unable to harm the tree. Starting from the top,

On either side of the trunk, icons for "Insects," and "Disease and Decay" are deflected by a circle inside the tree trunk that reads,

Chemical tannins in bark and wood resist disease, rot, and insects.

An icon that reads, "Fire" is deflected by a circle inside the tree trunk that reads,

Thick fibrous bark provides superior insulation against fire. With little flammable sap, it doesn't burn easily.

An icon of cracked earth that reads, "Drought" is deflected by a circle inside the tree trunk that reads,

Extensive roots reach far for water.
A photo of a sequoia stump with burn scars, reads,

Lifespans

Above the stump, a tall green line with a black silhouette of a sequoia at the top marks the age of a mature sequoia tree. It reads,

Sequoia trees. 3000+ years

A short green line, one tenth the height, three silhouetted trees at the top, marks their age. It reads,

Most other trees. 300+ years

The text reads,
How do we know their age?

Determining the age of a large, living sequoia is hard. Coring techniques used on smaller trees would create big holes in the trunk if drilled to the middle of a huge sequoia. Instead, scientists measure just the outer rings. Then they apply mathematical formulas based on old stumps, whose rings could actually be counted.

Using this method, scientist estimate that the largest sequoias in this area are between 1,800 and 3,000 years old. Earlier, less accurate estimates put them at 6,000 years old. The world's oldest known tree, the small bristlecone pine, has lived over 4,700 years.
