data.title: Winter Wildlife
data.listingDescription: This outdoor exhibit, titled “Winter Wildlife,“ discusses the different types of animals and insects found in this area, and how they survive the seasons.

images.altText: An outdoor exhibit sign features an image of a pine marten in the snow.
images.title: Winter Wildlife
images.caption: This exhibit about wildlife can be found is just a short hike from the Generals Highway.

data.bodyText: This outdoor exhibit, titled “Winter Wildlife,“ discusses the different types of animals and insects found in this area, and how they survive the seasons.
data.audioDescription: This outdoor exhibit panel is titled, "Winter Wildlife" and features a photo and two illustrations with captions, and text about wildlife. A photograph features a brown-phased pine marten standing atop a heavily trafficked path on the snow. The photograph’s caption reads, “Pine martens travel easily through snow and stay active through winter. They walk lightly on the surface without sinking, or use tunnels to move below the snowpack.” The main text reads, “In summer, if you walk carefully and quietly, you’ll find a huge variety of animals here. They range from large mammals like black bears and deer to the tiniest insects. When weather is warm, food is abundant and animals fatten up to prepare for cold weather. As you walk, listen for bird calls, buzzing insects, and other signs of this active community. Frigid temperatures and a deep snowpack quiet this forest in winter, but wildlife is still plentiful. Each species has a strategy to survive the cold months when food is scarce. Some are active beneath the snow’s surface, where temperatures are more stable. Others rest quietly through winter, using food reserves they gathered in warmer months. A few move to warmer locations and return when conditions are less demanding.” To the right of the main photo are two color illustrations. The first is a drawing of a yellow-colored pale swallowtail butterfly with its wings expanded and a green pale swallowtail chrysalis attached to a piece of wood. The illustration caption reads, “Pale swallowtail butterflies spend winter inside their chrysalis and then emerge as adults in spring. Like many insects, the adults die off in fall after reproducing. Their young live through winter as pupae, making the transformation from caterpillars to butterflies.” The second illustration is of a brown water boatmen in an underwater scene. The caption below it reads, “Other insects live through winter as adults. Some hibernate, and some simply slow down. Water boatmen live under the ice in streams and ponds. They slowly “row” through the frigid water, searching for air bubbles, and then rest on the bottom until they need more air.”

data.title: Wolverton Picnic Area, Trailhead, and Snowplay Area
data.listingDescription: In addition to being a great place to stop for lunch, Wolverton offers trailheads to some of the most stunning frontcountry and backcountry hiking in these parks. Wolverton Meadow is an excellent place to view black bears in the late spring and early summer. They are often seen feeding in the meadows. The meadow's wildflowers change throughout the season, so taking this hike in June is a different experience than in August or May.

images.altText: A metal framed sign with information about Wolverton stands in front of a shade covered trail
images.title: Wolverton Trailhead sign
images.caption: The Trailhead for Wolverton

data.bodyText:
In addition to being a great place to stop for lunch, Wolverton offers trailheads to some of the most stunning frontcountry and backcountry hiking in these parks. The Lakes Trail leads to Heather Lake, Emerald Lake, and Pear Lake. The challenging Alta Trail, which climbs more than 4,000 feet in elevation over 12.8 miles (20 kilometers) to the summit of Alta Peak, has some spectacular views. Or go as far as Panther Gap 4 miles, (6.4 kilometers) for a good look at the Great Western Divide. The Watchtower portion of the Lakes Trail leads you along the ridge overlooking Lodgepole, the Marble Fork of the Kaweah River, and Tokopah Falls. This stretch of trail is extremely treacherous if any snow or ice is present; if icy or snowy conditions are present, always choose the Hump Trail instead.

For a much easier hike, try the Wolverton Meadow Loop which circles a wetland. On this trail, you must usually make two easy stream crossings; however, early in the season the water can be high. Wolverton Meadow is an excellent place to view black bears in the late spring and early summer. They are often seen feeding in the meadows. The meadow's wildflowers change throughout the season, so taking this hike in June is a different experience than in August or May. Keep an eye out for pine martens, relatives of the weasel that live high in the branches of pine trees and are relatively common here. They are shy of people and hide well, so you have to stop for a while and search for them.

Sled Safely

Every winter, people get hurt badly while sledding in the park. The most common reason people get hurt is they sled when conditions are bad (icy snow, rock or tree hazards exposed, poor visibility), so if the snow isn't great or you can't see, don't sled! Don’t let an accident ruin your winter fun.

  • When sledding, slide feet first.
  • Consider wearing a helmet.
  • Make sure your path is clear. Don’t slide near rocks, trees, branches, or other people.
  • After sliding, look uphill. Move out of the way of people coming downhill after you.
  • Don’t slide into roads or parking lots.
  • Avoid hard-packed snow or ice, where speed and direction get out of control.
  • Sliding devices that can be steered may be safer than others.

In an emergency, contact a ranger or call 911.
data.audioDescription:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Wolverton Trailhead area.

The text reads,

The Lakes Trail leads to the Watchtower, a rocky outcrop 3.2 miles (or 5.1 km) from here. It offers spectacular views down into Tokopah Valley and up into the Tablelands. If you continue onward, icy lakes and granite peaks await.

Like most park trails, these lead into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Possible destinations include:

A photo of a reflective lake surrounded by rock covered granite slopes and scattered conifer trees.

The caption reads,

Heather, Emerald, and Pear Lakes

Heather Lake lies closest, 4.1 miles (or 6.6 km) from here. For a longer dayhike or overnight trip, continue to Emerald, shown in the photo above, (5.3 miles or 8.5 km one way) or Pear Lake (6.2 miles or 10.0 km one way). When the Watchtower route closes (late fall through early summer), take the Hump route. Never use the Watchtower route when it is icy.

A photo shows a dramatic view of rocky granite peaks with a jagged mountain range dappled with snow.

The caption reads,

Alta Peak.
7.0 miles (or 10.8 km) one way.
Elevation: 11,204 feet (or 3,415 m).

It is one of the easier High Sierra peaks to climb, but Alta's elevation can still slow you down. Consider visiting Alta Meadow, where wildflowers and trees provide a gentle contrast to the granite crags above.

A map shows the location of the Wolverton Trailhead.

A photo of a reflective lake nestled in a valley of granite slopes dusted with snow, with a few conifer trees.

The caption reads,

Emerald Lake in spring

A quote by Dr. Seuss,

"Today is your day! Your mountain is waiting."

data.title: Wolverton Shuttle Stop
data.listingDescription: This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at the Wolverton Picnic Area, Trailhead, and Snowplay Area. Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks. Shuttles within the park are free; round-trip shuttles from Visalia are $20, which includes the park entrance fee. All buses are wheelchair accessible, and either kneel or have lifts.

images.altText: A white shuttle bus is parked next to a sign labeled "Wolverton".
images.title: Wolverton Shuttle Stop
images.caption: The shuttle stop at Wolverton.

data.bodyText:
This Sequoia Shuttle stop is located at the Wolverton Picnic Area, Trailhead, and Snowplay Area.

Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks.

Shuttles within the park are free; round-trip shuttles from Visalia are $20, which includes the park entrance fee.

All buses are wheelchair accessible, and either kneel or have lifts.

Visit the park shuttles page for more information, including a route map.

data.title: Woods Creek, Bubbs Creek, Rae Lakes Loop Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the area around Woods Creek, Bubbs Creek, and Rae Lakes Loop trails. Wilderness permits for these trails are only issued from the Road's End Permit Station.

images.altText: Two metal signs are found at a trailhead, and have a map, mileage, and other trail information.
images.title: Woods and Bubbs Creek Trailhead
images.caption: The Trailhead sign for Woods and Bubbs Creek trails, and Rae Lakes Loop

data.bodyText:
This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the area around Woods Creek, Bubbs Creek, and Rae Lakes Loop trails.

Rae Lakes Loop is a 42 mile (67.6 km) backpacking loop at a difficult incline, featuring canyon views, high alpine lakes, and stunning vistas.

Bubb's Creek Trail is a 12.3 mile (19.8 km) trail starting at a steep, then steady, incline. The first campsite is after 4 miles (6.4 km) at Sphinx Creek Junction.

Woods Creek Trail is a 11.2 mile (18 km) trail with a moderate incline. This trail offers beautiful views, rivers, and alpine lakes, but can be crowded. The first campsite is at Paradise Valley after 6.5 miles (10.4 km).

Wilderness permits for these trails are only issued from the Road's End Permit Station.
data.audioDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Woods Creek and Bubbs Creek Trails area. The text reads, Welcome to where roads end and trails begin. Walk a few hours, or hike farther into a glorious wilderness ruled by elevation and climate. Like most park trails, these lead into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Possible destinations include: Via Woods Creek Trail. A photo of a cascading waterfall, surging through rocks. The caption reads, Mist falls. 3.9 miles (or 6.3 km) one way. Elevation: 5,840 feet (or 1780 m). As the name suggests, mist from this powerful cascade surrounds the area of the falls. The trail and nearby rocks can be slippery here, especially in early summer when the river is at its peak flow. Be extremely careful. Via Bubbs Creek Trail, A photo of a pass through a rocky ridge, with a rounded crag to the left, and a pointed steep crag to its right. Low shrubs and a few conifer trees dot the landscape. The caption reads, Sphinx Creek. 4.1 miles (or 6.6 km) one way. Elevation: 6,240 feet (or 1902 m). Towering over the canyon floor, the Sphinx evokes images of Egypt's giant statues. John Muir named the formation in the later 1800s. A map shows the location of the Woods Creek and Bubbs Creek Trailhead. The bottom photo shows a hillside of large foxtail pines, with a snow-covered mountain range in the distance. The caption reads, Above Vidette Meadow, A quote by Shel Silverstein, "There is a place where the sidewalk ends..."

quickFacts.value: Road's End trailhead area, Kings Canyon National Park
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Wuksachi Restaurant & Lodge
data.listingDescription: The restaurant and lounge are open to all, not just lodge guests. The dining room's open beams lend a rustic feel, and windows look out on forests and peaks. A new pizza deck offers quick and casual food. Hours vary depending on the season.

images.altText: A illuminated lodge sits in between tall trees
images.title: Wuksachi Lodge and Restaurant
images.caption: Wuksachi Lodge and Restaurant

data.bodyText:
The restaurant and lounge are open to all, not just lodge guests. The dining room's open beams lend a rustic feel, and windows look out on forests and peaks. A new pizza deck offers quick and casual food.

Hours vary depending on the season. Information about the restaurant and for lodging availability can be found at the Wuksachi Lodge web page.
data.audioDescription: Surrounded by conifer forest and soaring Sierra peaks, Wuksachi Lodge is easily accessible from the road. A wide paved path leads to this cedar mountain lodge with peaked roofs. Covering the entrance to the building is an extended peaked roof, supported by large wooden beams and posts that rise up from square, stone columns. The outer columns are massive-about 10 feet tall-and taper inward slightly near the top. On the beam above the entrance to this portico is an embossed wood sign, with a rusty red outline and white letters, that reads, "Wuksachi Lodge" The building exterior has clapboard wood plank siding on the front, and wooden shingles on the sides. Two sets of glass front entrance doors open outward. A no smoking sign is posted between them. Flanking the doors are large windows, with wood slatted benches below them, looking out toward the parking area. Accessibility: Paved parking lot to the hotel has a slight incline.

quickFacts.value: Travel along the Generals Highway to Wuksachi Way, one mile north of Lodgepole.
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Wuksachi Restaurant & Lodge Shuttle Stop
data.listingDescription: The Route 3 shuttle that serves this stop only runs on Saturday, Sunday, and holidays. Overflow parking lots in this area almost always have parking. If you can't find a spot in the Giant Forest or Lodgepole, park here and take the shuttle. Please use the overflow lots and leave the closer parking spaces for hotel guests.

Overflow parking lots in this area almost always have parking. If you can't find a spot in the Giant Forest or Lodgepole, park here and take the shuttle. Please use the overflow lots, and leave the closer parking spaces for hotel guests.

Sequoia Shuttles run from late May until early September. Riding the shuttle helps you avoid having to find parking, which can be limited. It also reduces air pollution within our parks.

Shuttles within the park are free; round-trip shuttles from Visalia are $20, which includes the park entrance fee.

All buses are wheelchair accessible, and either kneel or have lifts.

Visit the park shuttles page for more information, including a route map.

data.title: Wuksachi Trailhead
data.listingDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Wuksachi Trailhead area.

images.altText: A metal framed sign stands in front of small trees, behind them loom larger trees
images.title: Wuksachi Trailhead
images.caption: The trailhead for Wuksachi area hikes

data.bodyText: This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and photos of the Wuksachi Trailhead area.
data.audioDescription:
The text reads,

This trail climbs a short way through forests of fir trees and then joins the Twin Lakes Trail. If you continue, the trail leads past meadows and lakes and approaches treeline. At Silliman Pass, the trail crosses into Kings Canyon National Park.

Like most park trails, Wuksachi Trail leads into designated wilderness. One of the highest forms of protection for public lands, wilderness preserves untamed landscapes for you to experience. Possible destinations include.

A photo of a serene meadow, with a hazy forest of fir trees along the edge in the distance.

The caption reads,

Calhoun meadow.
3.8 miles (or 6.1 km) one way.
Elevation: 7760 feet (or 2365 m).

A gentle climb through conifer forests leads to this grassy meadow. Look for wildflowers and wildlife, especially in early summer. North of Cahoon Meadow, another trail branches northward to J.O. Pass in Jennie Lakes Wilderness (USFS).

A photo shows a reflective lake, lined with fir trees. A snowcapped mountain ridge, with a sharp crag to the left, and a rounded peak to the right.

The caption reads,

Twin Lakes.
7.2 miles (or 11.6 km) one way.
Elevation: 9419 feet (or 2871 m.)

The two lakes on either side of the trail are well forested, unlike most other lakes in the park's high country. Just beyond Twin Lakes, Silliman Pass marks the boundary between Sequoia National Park and Kings Canyon Park.

A map shows the location of the Wuksachi Trailhead.

The bottom photo shows the tops of conifer trees, with a craggy mountain peak, streaked with patches of snow.

The caption reads,

Silliman crest.

A quote by Mary Austin (Inyo writer),

"Man is not himself only... he is all that he sees."

quickFacts.value: At Wuksachi Parking Lot, end of Wuksachi Road.
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Zumwalt Meadow
data.listingDescription: Zumwalt Meadow is one of the park's most iconic, scenic meadows. Explore the trail that begins near the Kings River, crosses a riparian corridor, and then climbs gently along a rocky hillside. As you hike through a talus slope, you will catch glimpses of the meadow below. Meadows often attract bears and other animals such as yellow-bellied marmots, deer, birds of prey, and snakes; watch for them all here.

images.altText: Green grass stretche across an open field behind it large green trees and a looming grey mountain
images.title: Zumwalt Meadow
images.caption: Zumwalt Meadow

data.bodyText:
Zumwalt Meadow is one of the park's most iconic, scenic meadows. Explore a trail that begins near the Kings River, crosses a riparian corridor, and then climbs gently along a rocky hillside. From here, as you hike through a talus slope, you will catch glimpses of the meadow below.

Meadows often attract bears and other animals such as yellow-bellied marmots, deer, birds of prey, and snakes; watch for them all here.


Highway 180 closes for the winter in mid-November. This area typically reopens the fourth Friday in April; reopening is conducted by CalTrans.
data.audioDescription: You are standing near an accessible trail that leads across a bridge surrounded by conifer trees and rocky canyon walls on either side. From the bridge, the South Fork of the Kings River may be seen and heard. It may even be possible to feel the spray from the river when the water is high in spring. By fall or during a drought, it may be a meandering, thin flow, as shallow as two feet deep, scattered with branches and tree trunks, looking more like a stream than a river. In spring thaw after a winter with very heavy snowfall, it may be wide and deep, filling much of the meadow, and even covering the trail! Just beyond the bridge are steep rocky cliffs, with loose piles of boulders near the base. The trail here becomes much more rugged and rocky. Growing in patches amid those boulders are conifer trees, willows, and other deciduous trees and shrubs. The mountain slopes at the far end of the meadow are also steep and rocky, with conifer trees growing on top and where the slopes are less steep.

quickFacts.value: Located in Cedar Grove, along Highway 180, Just before Road's End.
quickFacts.name: Location

This trailhead orientation panel shows a map and images of the Zumwalt Meadow area.

River Safety

Most of the year, the river flows gently along one side of the meadow, but in spring and early summer the water is cold an currents are swift. Be careful!
data.audioDescription: This trailhead orientation panel shows photos and accessibility information for Zumwalt Meadow Trail. A photo of a partially shaded wooden deck with two benches, about 20 feet apart, facing each other. Just beyond this seating area is a green meadow, lined with conifer trees and towering granite cliffs in the background. The text reads, Accessibility Information This trail follows the Kings River to Zumwalt Meadow, a lush meadow surrounded by steep granite cliffs. The loop trail is 1.5 miles, but only the first portion is designated as accessible to people in wheelchairs. A photo of a wooden planked bridge, with railings, suspended over a river. There is a conifer forest on the banks of both sides of the river. On either end of the bridge are support towers, about 15 feet high, that straddle the width of the bridge. They are made of open metal framing, so people can walk right under them. A thick cable on each side connects these towers across the river, curving down toward the center of the bridge. Additional cables stretch downward, connecting the curved overhead cable to the bridge. A hiker crosses the bridge from one side of the forested area to the other. The text reads, Along the river side of the meadow, the trail is nearly level, with very little elevation gain and cross slope. The trail begins on a hard-packed surface, then crosses a bridge with a wooden plank surface. Beyond the bridge, a side trail provides easy access to a sandy beach along the river. The main trail continues on a wooden boardwalk to the meadow, and then on a hard-packed surface to Road's End.

quickFacts.value: near end of Kings Canyon Scenic Byway/Highway 180.
